title: 'We come in peace!': Hundreds flood Jersey City, where cops, protesters marched together
text: Only two men wore African-style dashiki shirts to the protest, and one of them was Nevin Perkins. On the sidewalk before the Jersey City Police Department’s Greenville precinct, beneath the warm sun and four police officers with binoculars on nearby rooftops and a police helicopter that hovered in the distance, Perkins raised a red bullhorn into the air. “I speak as a person with police in my family. We come in peace! We know not all cops are bad,” said Perkins, who helped organize the rally. “But if there is no reform, there can be no peace.” In the crowd, some people agreed with Perkins about this question of peace. Others did not. Buy Photo Founder of Black Men United, Nevin Perkins, the organizer of a rally in memory of George Floyd, is shown here holding a mega-phone at Berry Lane at the start of the march to the south precinct in Jersey City. Monday, June 1, 2020 (Photo: Kevin Wexler, NorthJersey.com-USA TODAY NETWORK via Imagn Content Services, LLC) “No justice, no peace!” one person yelled. “Down with the pigs!” shouted another. Only one man in the crowd wore a suit. This was Jim Shea, Jersey City’s director of public safety. Shea is tall — several inches above 6 feet. Every few minutes he stood on the tiptoes of his black dress shoes and scanned the back of the crowd, which numbered 600 people. Shea was looking for trouble. He saw none. When Perkins finished his speech, he handed off the bullhorn and walked over to Shea. “Just make eye contact with me when you want to go,” Shea told the activist. “That way we can get organized. I don’t want a car to come through the crowd.” Story continues below gallery The protest against police violence in Jersey City on Monday afternoon was like this, a delicate balance between cheerfulness and rage. This time, peace won handily. But the rage was there, running like an underground river, and Nevins and Shea and the protesters and all the police officers in their black riot gear knew it. As they marched, protesters and police officers hugged. Other protesters handed out surgical masks to people who had none. Clarence Collins walked up Bramhall Avenue with the first of the protesters, chanting “No justice, no peace!” Approaching a police officer, he paused and reached out his fist. Collins and the cop gently tapped knuckles. “How you doin', Coach C?” said the cop. “What do you say, Papi?” Collins called back. “Jersey City cops are decent. They’re not all buttholes,” said Collins, who works as a life skills coach at University Academy Charter School in Jersey City. “Everybody wants to come home safe. But the video we saw of police killing George Floyd was outright murder.” A balance between anger and peace One protester offered a mask to Gail Albright, who sat on a folding chair on the sidewalk and watched the march go by. Albright smiled and thanked him. Then she frowned. "I hate Jersey City,” Albright said. “I have real bad asthma. But if I had an electric scooter, I’d be right out there marching. I’m tired of cops hurting people.” Reader — covering our local communities takes time and resources. Help us better support your community by becoming a subscriber today — see our special offers. Sometimes the dynamic of anger and peace reversed itself, and anger took the lead. Connor Appleton marched down Martin Luther King Drive holding a sign that read “This Machine KILLS Fascists.” The protesters around him chanted the names of black people killed by police, and Appleton chanted with them. George Floyd in Minneapolis. Trayvon Martin in Sanford, Florida. Ahmaud Arbery in Glynn County, Georgia. Breonna Taylor in Louisville. Eric Garner in Staten Island. IN TRENTON: 'We're going to be on lockdown': Mayhem erupts as rioters loot stores, burn cop car CURFEW: New York City to have curfew from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. amid protests over George Floyd death As he walked, Appleton pulled behind him a blue cooler on wheels. When the marchers reached the police precinct, he opened the lid, retrieved bottles of water and offered them to people in the crowd. Buy Photo Hundreds marched to the south precinct (Greenville Precinct) in Jersey City, in memory of George Floyd. Monday, June 1, 2020 (Photo: Kevin Wexler, NorthJersey.com-USA TODAY NETWORK via Imagn Content Services, LLC) “I’m not here to lead, and I’m not here to start any trouble,” said Appleton, 28, from Jersey City. “I’m just here to help out wherever I can.” This alchemy of anger and peace was a subtle one, too subtle for the cameras of cable news, which prefer obvious narratives of good and evil, attack and retreat, rocks through windows and cars on fire. “I haven’t seen this on Fox. I haven’t seen anything like this on CNN,” said Andre Morris, a Jersey City resident. “It was peaceful. Nothing got looted, nothing got rioted.” Speeches over, Perkins laid his bullhorn on the sidewalk. He locked eyes with Shea. The safety director caught the signal. Turning, he waved his right hand, ordering his officers to prepare to move. Most of the protesters walked away, following the same route by which they’d come. Police officers raced ahead in SUVs, blocking traffic for the people to pass. Following the crowd, Shanelle Smith walked beside her son Duke, 15. She worries someone will kill him, she said. Maybe it will be another black teenager, traumatized by violence and poverty. Maybe it will be a police officer. “The cops are the biggest gang. I think police are killing black people on purpose to keep us afraid,” said Smith, 35. “Peace doesn’t work. I’m done with peace.” Smith carried a white sign with red letters. It read “Off the pigs.” Staff Writer Ricardo Kaulessar contributed to this article. Christopher Maag is a columnist for NorthJersey.com. To get unlimited access to his unique perspective on New Jersey’s most interesting people and experiences, please subscribe or activate your digital account today. Email: maag@northjersey.com Twitter: @Chris_Maag Read or Share this story: https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/hudson/2020/06/01/jersey-city-protest-hundreds-march-peaceful-george-floyd-rally/5308690002/

title: Police in New Jersey praised for marching in George Floyd protests
text: Police officers in one of New Jersey’s largest and most violent cities were praised on social media for marching alongside protesters in rallies held this weekend over George Floyd’s death. Camden County Police Chief Joe Wysocki, who has been working in the city for decades, joined the front line of a march in Camden on Saturday afternoon, sporting his uniform, a protective face mask and a peace sign. ”Yesterday was another example of our ongoing engagement, and a very real dialogue, that we are having with residents throughout Camden that has made our agency part of the fabric of this city,” Wysocki said in an emailed statement to The Associated Press. Since Camden’s police force disbanded and reformed in 2013 as a county agency, officers there have been hyper-focused on community policing. It’s not strange to see them on walking beats or attending neighborhood block parties like the one Saturday night where two officers grilled up hamburgers and hot dogs. Advertisement “We know that together we are stronger, we know that together, in the city of Camden, we can create a space where policing is focused on deescalation and dialogue,” Wysocki said. Protests have been held for days in cities all over the United States in response to Floyd’s death. Floyd, who was black, died Monday after a white police officer pressed his knee on his neck until he stopped breathing. On Saturday night, peaceful protests turned violent in cities like New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles and Atlanta. Store windows were smashed, and items were stolen; police cars were set on fire. Both police officers and civilians suffered serious injuries. There were other instances of police solidarity throughout the U.S. widely shared on social media. Advertisement Marchers in Flint, Mich., arrived at a police station where Genesee County Sheriff Christopher Swanson — responding to chants of “Walk with us! Walk with us!” — said, “Come on!” and joined the protest. Police in Fargo, N.D., held hands with protesters while officers took a knee in Santa Cruz, Calif. On Sunday afternoon in New York, officers clapped on protesters, hundreds of whom stopped and took a knee with fists raised just north of the Empire State Building.

title: Big Tech CEOs Spoke Out On George Floyd Murder—Then Came the Blowback
text: In the wake of widespread protests over the murder of George Floyd by police officers in Minnesota last week, leaders of America’s largest tech companies have begun to make public statements addressing both the incident and the larger problem of systemic racism. For the most part, they have expressed condolences for the tragic incident and offered donations to national groups doing the hard work of dismantling racist systems. Google CEO Sundar Pichai was the first to order a company-level response. On Friday, he wrote a company memo announcing an internal campaign to raise funds for organizations supporting racial justice. He also promised that Google would match any employee contribution up to $10,000. Facebook and Apple quickly followed suit by pledging to support racial justice groups and match employee donations. Facebook said it would donate $10 million to organizations recommended by employees and the company’s “civil rights advisors.” And Apple has pledged to match employee contribution two-for-one in the month of June to support several social groups. In a Facebook post on Sunday, Zuckerberg praised Darnella Frazier, who recorded and posted the video of Floyd’s death on Facebook, saying that, “as hard as it was to watch, we all needed to see that.” Apple’s Cook wrote in a company memo on Monday, calling employees to reflect on America’s painful history of racism and inequality. Even Elon Musk, who was occupied with SpaceX’s NASA launch for the most of last week, found time to engage in a timely Twitter conversation on Monday about Floyd and tweeted “#JusticeForGeorge.” Definitely not right that the other officers were charged with nothing. What message does this send in general to officers who stand by while another does wrong? #JusticeForGeorge — Elon Musk (@elonmusk) June 1, 2020 Jeff Bezos, although yet to make a statement through Amazon, shared an essay by the writer Shenequa Golding about the difficulty of maintaining professionalism while witnessing Black death on Instagram on Saturday. “The pain and emotional trauma caused by the racism and violence we are witnessing toward the Black community has a long reach,” Bezos wrote. “I recommend you take a moment to read this powerful essay, especially if you are a manager or leader.” On Monday, Amazon’s official Twitter account posted a statement that read, “The inequitable and brutal treatment of Black people in our country must stop. Together we stand in solidarity with the Black community—our employees, customers, and partners—in the fight against systematic racism and injustice.” However, watchdogs were quick to call out what they called Amazon’s hypocrisy. “Funny coming from the company that fired a Black man for asking for safer working conditions during [COVID-19], sells Nazi flags and remains the last large advertiser on Breitbart, which once featured a ‘Black Crime’ section, despite being asked to stop by 600+ of your diverse workers,” replied Sleep Giants, a liberal social media activism group, under Amazon’s tweet. Other companies’ gesture of sympathy faced similar blowback. Zuckerberg’s message, for example, “seems to have the opposite effect that was intended,” wrote New York Times tech reporter Mike Issac, “as insiders saw Facebook executives throwing money at the problem.” Also on Monday, a group of Facebook employees staged a virtual walkout to protest Zuckerberg’s decision last week to keep President Donald Trump’s inflammatory posts advocating for violence against black demonstrators on the company’s platform. “Along with Black employees in the company, and all persons with a moral conscience, I am calling for Mark to immediately take down the President’s post advocating violence, murder and imminent threat against Black people,” a Facebook employee participating in the protest wrote in an internal message board, according to The New York Times.

title: Monmouth U. President: 'vile and racists' texts, posts are being investigated
text: CLOSE Seniors from both the township’s public high schools protest virtual graduation for 2020. Other students believe an in-person ceremony would be dangerous and selfish. Asbury Park Press Above: Middletown seniors want in-person graduation. WEST LONG BRANCH - Monmouth University is investigating two incidents of "vile and racist" texts and social media posts from within the university community, President Patrick F. Leahy said in a statement posted to Twitter. "Last night numerous students and alumni brought to my attention the existence of vile and racist text messages and posts from members of the university community shared on social media," the president said Monday. Leahy did not say what the nature of the messages were or who was involved, but said they were discriminatory to black members of the university's community. "They are an affront to the values we hold most dear and a violation of everything we stand for as a university," he said in the statement. "Hate has no place here at Monmouth, and discrimination of any kind will not be tolerated." The university's Office of Judicial Affairs, the Office of Equity & Diversity, the Intercultural Center and the Monmouth University Police Department are aware of the incident and are investigating, the president said. The university is also working with the Monmouth County Prosecutor's Office, he said. "The investigations are just beginning," Leahy said. WATCH LIVE: Asbury Park Justice For George Floyd protest NJ George Floyd protests: Which remained peaceful, where there was violence Amanda Oglesby is an Ocean County native who covers Brick, Barnegat and Lacey townships as well as the environment. She has worked for the Press for more than a decade. Reach her at @OglesbyAPP, aoglesby@gannettnj.com or 732-557-5701. Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/news/education/2020/06/01/monmouth-u-vile-and-racists-texts-posts-being-investigated/5311551002/

title: New round of protests have begun in Philly
text: A large protest against police brutality that flooded parts of Center City Monday mostly dispersed as night began to fall on Philadelphia’s third day of demonstrations denouncing the death of George Floyd at the hands of police in Minnesota. Tensions reached a peak when the group blocked traffic in both directions of I-676. State Troopers intervened, releasing multiple tear gas canisters into the crowd as part of its effort to clear people off the expressway. Catherine Letine, 30, was among those marching. “It’s been mostly peaceful and the police were the first to strike on us,” said Letine, a life-long Philadelphian who is white. “We have no weapons. We’re unarmed. We’re here peacefully and they have continued to use force. And it will only get worse I’m sure.” State Police, in a statement to NBC10, said tear gas was used because some protesters pelted police with rocks and bottles. Protesters rapidly disbursed, heading off the highway back towards 22nd Street and scattering in multiple directions. Dozens of protesters, some lined up against a median on the highway, were detained by police. The tense situation led to the shutdown of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge in both directions. Throughout the day, helicopters whirred above, with people holding signs with messages such as “black lives matter” and “defund the police.” As of 6 p.m., Philadelphia is under a mandatory citywide curfew. It will not lift until 6 a.m. Tuesday. During those hours, people can only leave their homes to go to work at essential businesses or to seek medical attention or police assistance. The larger unrest hit cities across the country after Floyd died when being arrested and restrained by Minneapolis police for allegedly using a counterfeit bill. Officer Derek Chauvin was seen on video with his knee on Floyd’s neck for nine minutes. Chauvin, who had previously faced more than 15 conduct complaints, has been fired and charged with third-degree murder. Three other officers part of the altercation have also been fired. Saturday and Sunday both featured large, mostly peaceful protests during the day, followed by vandalism, property damage and looting in the afternoon and evening. Each day has seen moments of both harmony and extreme tension between protesters and police. On Monday, some police officers knelt on the steps of the police headquarters in a show of solidarity. In other moments, officers have seemed to show little respect for people’s right to assemble, ramming them with bicycles and pepper spraying without provocation. On Sunday, a WHYY reporter covering a peaceful march was tackled and arrested without warning. On Monday, one protester, an African American woman who asked not to be named, said she felt “defeated” and “hurt” based on her interactions with police. “I’ve been flipped off. I’ve been told ‘Fuck you’ by these police officers…” she said. “A police officer drove by in his car and sprayed mace out of his window towards my friends. It’s very disgusting to see how they act.” Since Saturday, the first day the city implemented the mandatory curfew, officers have arrested 161 people for being on the street past 6 p.m, according to police. The vast majority were city residents. Police arrested another 257 people for failure to disperse. The majority of those people were also city residents. Trouble in Fishtown Starting in the early evening, a group of roughly a hundred people, mostly white men, patrolled Girard Avenue in Fishtown, confronting a group of protesters. Some of the men carried bats. Others had golf clubs and billy clubs. Protesters had signs. One man was overheard by a WHYY producer as saying: “I’m ready to fuck shit up. You know, I’ve been looking for a fight for the past 6 months.” Another man holding a hatchet had an angry interaction with a protester in the street. “I’m here to protect this neighborhood,” he said. One guy tells a cop: “im not here to make your job harder. I want to protect you.” A guy in a trump hat raised his fist and greeted his friend by saying “white man!” — Jon Ehrens (@jwehrens) June 1, 2020 ‘No one has listened for years’ Earlier in the day, another group of protesters gathered outside City Hall, with many calling for the removal of the Frank Rizzo statue bolted to the steps of the nearby Municipal Services Building. Barricades now cross JFK Boulevard in between MSB and City Hall, blocking access to the statue. Members of Philadelphia police department, as well as the National Guard, who were brought in to assist local police as civil unrest continued for a third day in a row, stood behind the barricade. On the outside, protesters chanted slogans and burned sage. Mayor Jim Kenney said over the weekend that the Rizzo statue will be removed more quickly than planned, likely within a month. On the opposite side of City Hall, the group Human Rights Coalition 215 held its own protest by the statue of black intellectual and activist Octavius Catto, calling for a variety of national and local reforms.

title: George Floyd: Protesters gather in Asbury Park to demand justice after police killing of black man
text: ASBURY PARK - A rally against police abuses that started peacefully ended with a phalanx of cops pushing demonstrators into the western part of town and arresting them past curfew, including an Asbury Park Press reporter covering the demonstration. Tensions flared between police and protesters when officers in riot gear started forcefully clearing the streets after 10 p.m., two hours after the 8 p.m. curfew. Police began making arrests and some demonstrators hurled rocks at officers. One officer was injured in the melee, according to Sgt. Michael Casey, a spokesman for the Asbury Park Police Department. Police made 12 arrests, including two juveniles, Casey said. He did not immediately say what charges they were facing. Buy Photo People and police fill the parking lot outside the Asbury Park, NJ, Police Headquarters Monday night, June 1, 2020. The group earlier marched through the town in protest over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Photo: Thomas P. Costello) The protest in Asbury Park was the latest demonstration sparked by the death of George Floyd, a black man who died at the hands of a white Minneapolis police officer last week, which led to angry clashes between protesters and police. Hours earlier, more than 1,000 demonstrators gathered outside the Asbury Park Post Office outraged over Floyd's death. Protesters waved signs with phrases like "White Silence=Violence," "No Justice No Peace" and "I can't breathe," a reference to words Floyd uttered on a video showing an officer pressing a knee into his neck. Looking for the trusted place to find the best home service providers? Find local pros. After the rally protesters marched peacefully through the streets of downtown to the boardwalk and back. Officers, urged on by the crowd, at times took a knee in solidarity with the demonstrators. At the start of the rally, faith leaders and community activists spoke through a bullhorn on the steps of the post office — located across the street from the city's police station — denouncing Floyd's death and railing against prejudice and unequal treatment faced by African-Americans and other people of color across the country. In between speeches, demonstrators erupted in chants of "Black Lives Matter," "enough is enough" and a call-and-response chant of "say his name" followed by "George Floyd." “We’re here to say enough is enough and start organizing to create community accountability," said community activist Derek Minno Bloom. "We want justice." Buy Photo Protesters gather in Asbury Park to demand justice for George Floyd. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) Some led the crowd in song, singing renditions of "Amazing Grace" and the Bill Withers classic "Lean on Me." Several activists urged the crowd to remain peaceful. After the 5 p.m. rally, protesters spilled onto the surrounding streets. Many passing cars honked their horns in support. A group of demonstrators walked up the city's famed boardwalk. Buy Photo Rally in Asbury Park protesting the police-involved death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Many marched peacefully in the streets after the rally was over. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) The demonstration grew tense when protesters surrounded an Asbury Park police vehicle at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and Main Street and one of its tires appeared to have been slashed. Some protesters began yelling at the officers who arrived to encircle the vehicle. The group dispersed after a few minutes amid chants of "keep the peace." Buy Photo People surround a police car and officers in the intersection of 5th and Main Streets in Asbury Park, NJ, Monday, June 1, 2020. The group marched through the town in protest over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Photo: Thomas P. Costello) Demonstrators continued to gather outside the Asbury Park Police Department well after an 8 p.m. curfew imposed by city leaders earlier in the day. Authorities largely allowed the crowd to remain undisturbed, but at 9:30 p.m., police made an announcement over a loudspeaker telling the crowd it was past curfew and they had to leave. Protesters and Asbury Park police take a knee together. pic.twitter.com/tbASXZYsDn — Gustavo Martinez (@newsguz) June 2, 2020 Many remained behind, engaging in a heated but peaceful exchange with officers about racial profiling and the treatment of black people by local police. The standoff became increasingly tense as officers in riot gear started pushing the crowd back. A large police presence amassed in the city as officers ordered the protesters to go home. By that point, most had left, but a group of demonstrators remained in the streets, and Casey said police from neighboring jurisdictions were called to help. Hundreds remain outside the Asbury Park Police Department. They hold signs and cheer when cars drive by honking in support of protesters. Protest remains peaceful. @AsburyParkPresspic.twitter.com/sitFC20n7e — Gustavo Martinez (@newsguz) June 2, 2020 Officers began making arrests and some protesters started throwing rocks. Among those taken into custody was Asbury Park Press reporter Gustavo Martínez Contreras, who was arrested despite city officials exempting members of the press from the curfew. Martínez Contreras was transported to the Belmar Police Department and issued a summons for failing to obey an order to disperse. He was released from police custody early Tuesday morning. Column: Arrest of APP reporter covering Asbury Park protest part of a troubling trend The protest was part of a wave of demonstrations in New Jersey and across the country set off by Floyd's death a week ago. The crowd marched following a weekend of tense confrontations between police and protesters in cities throughout the United States. Some demonstrations that began peacefully devolved into violence and looting. Floyd, 46, died May 25 in Minneapolis after police there tried to arrest him following a forgery complaint. Video of the encounter, which spread widely online, showed a white police officer pressing a knee into Floyd's neck for nearly 9 minutes as Floyd gasped that he couldn't breathe. The officer, Derek Chauvin, was charged Friday with third-degree murder and manslaughter. Buy Photo A sign hangs in the window of Confections of a Rock Star on Cookman Avenue in Asbury Park Monday afternoon, June 1, 2020. A 5pm protest over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis is scheduled in the town. (Photo: Thomas P. Costello) It was the latest in a string of incidents in recent years in which unarmed black people have been killed in interactions with the police, deaths that have sparked heated protests and calls for reform. Asbury Park officials imposed an 8 p.m. curfew Monday in anticipation of the rally. Mail service to post offices in the area was suspended earlier in the afternoon. Curfew: Asbury Park announces 8 p.m. curfew ahead of George Floyd protest Monday night Some downtown businesses boarded up their windows as a precaution amid fears that the rally would lead to the violence and chaos seen in other cities. Authorities said no stores were looted amid the mayhem Monday night. Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/news/local/how-we-live/2020/06/01/george-floyd-protest-asbury-park-demand-justice-after-police-killing-black-man/5311921002/

title: Trenton on ‘lockdown’ after violence erupts post-protest (update)
text: Update: Trenton has moved its curfew up by an hour to 7 p.m., according to the mayor’s office. It will remain in effect until 6 a.m. tomorrow morning. A weekend of peaceful protests and marches in Trenton ended with chaos and a curfew Sunday night. The city is now on “lockdown,” said mayor Reed Gusciora, and the 8 p.m. curfew will stay in place through June 1. Hundreds gathered in Trenton on Saturday and Sunday to protest the death of George Floyd, a black man who was killed by police in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Floyd died after Minneapolis Police Department officer Derek Chauvin held his knee on the neck of a subdued and handcuffed Floyd for nearly nine minutes. Floyd was unresponsive for almost three of those nine minutes. Saturday’s protest started on West State Street and was “peaceful and productive,” Gusciora said in a press conference late Sunday night. “I share the outrage of the brutality in the death of George Floyd that should never have happened,” Gusciora said. “I share the outrage of the community.” Sunday’s protest was largely the same, though violence erupted into the evening hours. A liquor store, a sneaker store and a PNC bank were broken into. It is unclear whether or not the protests and after-dark looting are connected. Residents and march attendees have reported a second group that gathered in the city after the protest dispersed was responsible for the violence. Gusciora mentioned “out-of-towners.” “I don’t believe looting a sneaker store or a liquor store really is productive or keeps the discussion going,” Gusciora said. “We have so many things that we need to focus on in this city, whether it be economic development or creating a better city and moving it forward. This sends us backwards. It sends the wrong message. I understand that there is anger across America, from New York to Philadelphia to Los Angeles, and we’re no different.”

title: Curfews announced for four Mercer County towns tonight
text: Four Mercer County towns—Ewing, Hamilton, Lawrence and Trenton—have declared curfews in anticipation of civil unrest tonight. The curfew decrees order business to close and residents to remain indoors effective 7 p.m. tonight through 6 a.m. tomorrow morning. The curfew decrees follow an outbreak of violence and looting in Trenton and areas in the townships bordering Trenton last night. Ewing and Lawrence townships announced the curfew this afternoon, following announcements by Trenton Mayor Reed Gusciora last night and Hamilton Mayor Jeff Martin at noon today. The Ewing curfew prohibits all travel except for essential services. “This closure includes restaurants, gas stations, and other establishments,” said an announcement on the township’s website. “Thank you for your patience, your calm and your understanding as we work to ensure the safety of all our residents and our community.” “The mayor has made a finding that violence, including the looting and damage to local businesses and properties in neighboring municipalities during the past 24 hours, creates a danger to the public and to property, which has created a public emergency requiring a closure of businesses and the imposition of a curfew until he of such emergency,” states the Lawrence Township proclamation ordering the curfew.

title: Trenton on ‘lockdown’ after violence erupts post-protest (update)
text: Update: Trenton has moved its curfew up by an hour to 7 p.m., according to the mayor’s office. It will remain in effect until 6 a.m. tomorrow morning. A weekend of peaceful protests and marches in Trenton ended with chaos and a curfew Sunday night. The city is now on “lockdown,” said mayor Reed Gusciora, and the 8 p.m. curfew will stay in place through June 1. Hundreds gathered in Trenton on Saturday and Sunday to protest the death of George Floyd, a black man who was killed by police in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Floyd died after Minneapolis Police Department officer Derek Chauvin held his knee on the neck of a subdued and handcuffed Floyd for nearly nine minutes. Floyd was unresponsive for almost three of those nine minutes. Saturday’s protest started on West State Street and was “peaceful and productive,” Gusciora said in a press conference late Sunday night. “I share the outrage of the brutality in the death of George Floyd that should never have happened,” Gusciora said. “I share the outrage of the community.” Sunday’s protest was largely the same, though violence erupted into the evening hours. A liquor store, a sneaker store and a PNC bank were broken into. It is unclear whether or not the protests and after-dark looting are connected. Residents and march attendees have reported a second group that gathered in the city after the protest dispersed was responsible for the violence. Gusciora mentioned “out-of-towners.” “I don’t believe looting a sneaker store or a liquor store really is productive or keeps the discussion going,” Gusciora said. “We have so many things that we need to focus on in this city, whether it be economic development or creating a better city and moving it forward. This sends us backwards. It sends the wrong message. I understand that there is anger across America, from New York to Philadelphia to Los Angeles, and we’re no different.”

The curfew decrees order business to close and residents to remain indoors effective 7 p.m. tonight through 6 a.m. tomorrow morning. The curfew decrees follow an outbreak of violence and looting in Trenton and areas in the townships bordering Trenton last night. Ewing and Lawrence townships announced the curfew this afternoon, following announcements by Trenton Mayor Reed Gusciora last night and Hamilton Mayor Jeff Martin at noon today. title: Curfews in several NJ towns, hopes of keeping protests peaceful
text: Curfews have been put in place in communities around New Jersey, as local officials look to keep protests peaceful Monday night. The restrictions follow two instances where looting and vandalism broke out following Sunday marches in Trenton and Atlantic City. In Asbury Park, the city imposed a curfew from 8 p.m. until 5 a.m., as throngs of people gathered for a protest at 801 Bangs Avenue in support of "social justice and police accountability." The crowd was sizable based on images posted to social media, including Jean Dortissant on Twitter. As of early Monday evening, the demonstration appeared to remain peaceful. City officials, including the Mayor and Council and Asbury Park Police, "stand in full solidarity with the Asbury Park community in promotion of a peaceful demonstration and denounce the actions of the officers involved in the murder of George Floyd and any acts of police misconduct," the city's announcement of its curfew said. It added the curfew was "to protect the safety of the organizers and attendees of the protest, and our residents." Atlantic City announced its overnight curfews will remain in effect until June 8, after the arrests of 17 New Jersey residents Sunday, for what city officials said was rioting and looting following a peaceful protest. Of those arrested, 12 are residents of Atlantic County. The Atlantic City curfew begins each night at 7 p.m. At least four Mercer County communities issued stringent overnight curfews, a day after 27 people were arrested in Trenton after attempted looting and vandalism hours after peaceful events in honor of George Floyd and against systemic racism. Ewing, Hamilton Township, Lawrence Township and Trenton all set curfews of 7 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday. The curfews prohibit all travel except for essential services and the closure includes restaurants, gas stations, and other establishments, according to Ewing officials. More from New Jersey 101.5:

title: In a peaceful demonstration, protesters in Vineland call for justice after death of George Floyd
text: CLOSE About 75 protesters, marched through the Vineland downtown, demanding justice for George Floyd. June 1, 2020. Vineland Daily Journal VINELAND – “Say his name,” chanted about 75 protesters who marched through downtown on Monday, demanding justice for George Floyd, the black man whose death in police custody has sparked national outrage. Reaching Landis Park, the crowd, that included acting Police Chief Pedro Casiano and half-dozen police officers, knelt for eight minutes to observe the length of time a Minneapolis police officer held his knee to the neck of Floyd, who was face-down and handcuffed. Protest organizers, Tahira Davis and Mia Arbona, childhood friends who are now college students, said they were looking add their voices to an area protest when they opted to pursue something more personal. “Why wait, we can do it ourselves,” Arbona said. On Sunday night, they turned to social media to invite the public to join them. About 1 p.m., cars pulled up to the designated Landis Avenue meeting spot and the sign-carrying crowd swelled. “This whole thing has really hit a nerve; we can’t sit back and just repost and tweet as much as we can, we have to take action,” Arbona said. Many carried "Black lives matter" and "Enough is Enough" posters. “You can feel it in the air, something’s different,” Davis said, “Before there would be a death, and then social media would go crazy for a little bit, and then it would die down.” The goal of their march “is to make sure that people know that no matter what color you are, you are accepted and that nobody deserves to be abused or killed or racially profiled,” Arbona told The Daily Journal. “We don’t want any more black people to leave their houses fearing for their lives.” Vineland police escorted the procession to ensure their safe passage to the park. Casiano and about a half-dozen officers walked alongside the chanting protesters. Protesters Tahira Davis (left) and Mia Arbona, speak with Acting Vineland Police Chief Pedro Casiano before their peaceful march to demand justice for George Floyd, the black Minneapolis man who died in police custody. Casiano and other police officers walked alongside the protesters during the march. June 1, 2020 (Photo: Deborah M. Marko) “We want the community to know that we are part of this community too,” Casiano said. Justin Young, 21, of Vineland, said he felt compelled to participate in the march “as soon as I heard about it.” Like Reps. John Lewis and the late Elijah Cummings, Young is a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. “They have been a part of the civil rights movement, I want to continue that legacy in my town,” Young said. “This is just the first step, I believe it’s not just about protesting or just about talking, the conservation started decades before any of us were born,” he said. “We need to become more involved in our community,” Young said, calling upon the public to hold their elected leaders accountable. Jaiden Santiago, 12, of Vineland, carried his sketch of George Floyd during a peaceful protest June 1 in Vineland. (Photo: Deborah M. Marko) While marchers shouted Floyd’s name, 12-year-old artist Jaiden Santiago held up a portrait. The youngster sketched Floyd’s portrait which he framed with the words "Justice for Floyd." “We have a lot of black family members, and they are all important to me,” the youngster said when asked why he participated in the march. As the protest concluded, Arbona thanked the crowd, and the police, for their support. “Our job is not done, our job doesn’t end here with the protest today,” she said, noting another group is reportedly planning another protest in the city later this week. “We hope to see you guys there again,” she said. Safety Director Edwin Alicea was among those at the Landis Park observance and added his support to the protesters. “We support their views in reference to the injustice that was done in Minneapolis,” Alicea said. During a peaceful protest in Vineland, participants knelt for eight minutes, signifying the length of time a Minneapolis police officer held his knee on George Floyd's neck. (Photo: Deborah M. Marko) “I don’t know of any officer, any agency, anywhere that I can think of that would condone the actions of those officers there,” Alicea said. “By no means, do we condone such activity.” Supporting and attending the march was a step toward bringing the community together, he said. “They need to know that we are here for them, that they can come and talk to us,” Alicea said. “They can come and ask for help, they don’t need to fear us." "They need to know that we here at their service, and the only way we can fix a situation is by communicating with each other," Alicea said. Deborah M. Marko is a senior reporter with The Daily Journal. Currently focused on breaking news and education issues, she also oversees community outreach programs that promote literacy and public safety. Got a story idea? Call 856-563-5256. Follow on Twitter: @dmarko_dj Instagram: deb.marko.dj Help support local journalism with a The Daily Journal subscription. Read or Share this story: https://www.thedailyjournal.com/story/news/2020/06/02/protesters-vineland-call-justice-after-death-george-floyd/5312631002/

title: Ex-deputy fire chief's incendiary Facebook posts on George Floyd cause trouble for Clifton
text: CLOSE Protesters speak prior to marching at the George Floyd protest in Jersey City. NorthJersey.com A retired Clifton deputy fire chief who posted incendiary comments on Facebook regarding George Floyd protests has done damage to the city, officials said. "If you are out at any of these 'protest' you are a scum bag and deserve to get shot," read a post Monday by Norm Tahan, who retired in 2014 but used a photo of himself in uniform as a profile image. That post and others by Tahan were shared on social media by users who urged people to contact the city of Clifton to lodge complaints. City Manager Nick Villano said he spent all day fielding phone calls and answering emails. He said he had received complaints from all over Passaic and Bergen counties, the state of New Jersey and former fire officials. A Twitter user responding to a Facebook post by former Clifton Deputy Fire Chief Norm Tahan. (Photo: NorthJersey.com) Villano said what Tahan does now is his own business, but added, "Don't wear the uniform that you took off six years ago." Villano said he asked Tahan to remove the picture from Facebook. The photo had been changed to one of Tahan in civilian dress as of Monday evening. NJ: 'We need structural change': NJ leaders demand reform after death of George Floyd OPINION: Justice for George Floyd: Black Lives Matter in New Jersey and America He said Tahan's comments reflected badly on him as city manager, his administration and the city as a whole. "What he said was unwarranted, especially now," Villano said. Fire Chief Frank Prezioso took it further. "Comments like this are a danger to the Fire Department," he said. "They jeopardize the lives of firemen." George Tahan on Facebook (Photo: Facebook post) He, too, said he had been fielding emails since the post appeared, and was continuing to do so late into Monday evening. "I am aggravated," he said. "It's unacceptable behavior." Tahan could not be reached for comment, but in a subsequent post on Facebook he tried to clarify his position: "I was in NO WAY, saying that a peaceful march, or protest, whatever you want to call it, is bad or you are bad for attending. So I apologize for those who did not get it, but I understand how some did not. A sit down to discuss is always welcome." In 2009, a group of about 10 residents protested outside City Hall after Tahan's promotion to deputy fire chief. They pointed to comments he had made in the past that they deemed racist, anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim. Sometimes-violent protests have erupted nationwide over the death of George Floyd at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer. Dozens of cities have imposed curfews in an effort to restore order. Read or Share this story: https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/passaic/clifton/2020/06/01/george-floyd-ex-deputy-fire-chief-facebook-posts-trouble-clifton/5312899002/

title: As chaos engulfed Philadelphia, peace reigned across the river in Camden
text: CLOSE In this Saturday, May 30, 2020, photo, Camden County Metro Police Chief Joe Wysocki raises a fist while marching with Camden residents and activists in Camden, N.J., to protest the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Police officers in one of New Jersey's largest and most violent cities were praised on social media for marching alongside protesters in rallies held this weekend over Floyd's death. (April Saul via AP) (Photo: April Saul, AP) Barack Obama visited Camden in 2015 and lauded the Camden County Police Department's commitment to achieving public safety through community-engaged policing. On Monday, while what began as peaceful protests condemning the death of George Floyd at the knee of Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin continued to descend into violence, arson, vandalism and looting, the 44th President once again praised the department for its part in keeping the peace in Camden. In a Medium post entitled "How to Make this Moment the Turning Point for Real Change," Obama calls protests across the country a representation of "a genuine and legitimate frustration over a decades-long failure to reform police practices and the broader criminal justice system in the United States." Peaceful demonstrators, said Obama, "deserve our respect and support, not condemnation — something that police in cities like Camden and Flint have commendably understood." So why did Camden, a majority-minority city where riots in 1969 and 1971 accelerated the blight, crime and poverty which challenge it still, remain peaceful as cities from Los Angeles to New York, Minneapolis to Atlanta, have seen chaos and anger spill over? How it began Yolanda Deaver, a mother of three sons, already knew the unfathomable pain of losing a child. Her oldest died three years ago from leukemia at just 15. When she saw the video of George Floyd's life and breath being squeezed from him, as she heard him call out for his own mother, her thoughts went to her surviving sons, ages 13 and 4. "It weighed heavily on me," she said. "I thought about my sons; I am trying to raise them to be successful, smart, respectful young men, and I hate for them to go through any racial profiling." Deaver, who owns Prissy Chic Hair Company, a salon and beauty supply on Mount Ephraim Avenue in Camden, "had a feeling in my heart that I had to do something." She mulled going to Minneapolis but worried it might be dangerous; instead, she posted her intention to march from her salon to the Camden County Police Department building at Haddon Avenue and Federal Street. Shortly after posting her plan, a friend who is also a Camden County police officer asked if she could join, telling Deaver, "even though I am a police officer, I feel the same way you do." Deaver's reply: "As long as we march in solidarity." Soon, more police officers asked to join. By Saturday morning, the police chief was standing with Deaver, holding a banner and joining her in a "Black Lives Matter" chant. Different department, different emphasis The Camden County Police Department formed in 2013 in the aftermath of a city financial crisis that prompted mass layoffs within the existing Camden City Police Department. In 2012, with a decimated police force, the city set a grim milestone with a record high 67 homicides. The new, county-run department, initially led by Chief J. Scott Thomson, hired some of the city officers and recruited new officers. Thomson began his career with the city department and rose through its ranks to become its youngest chief. With the newly-formed department, he placed an emphasis on community policing, drawing national attention and presidential praise. Buy Photo President Barack Obama gestures towards the crowd prior to speaking at the Ray & Joan Kroc Corps Community Center in Camden on Monday. (Photo: Chris LaChall/Courier-Post) Thomson retired last year, and Joe Wysocki, who'd served as his second-in-command since 2016, took over, intent on continuing and expanding upon Thomson's emphasis on engagement. The department has not been without its critics. There were initial charges of union busting (officers are now members of a local Fraternal Order of Police) and worries that bringing recruits from outside the city — many of them young and inexperienced in urban policing — would soon abandon Camden for more lucrative jobs with suburban departments. The county-run department led many city activists to cry foul, saying the county was imposing the change upon disenfranchised residents. Vida Neil, a city resident and activist, called it a "rogue police force." "Their idea of community policing is to set up a barbecue grill and pull up an ice cream truck," said Neil, who lives in the city's Morgan Village section. "But whatever happened to foot patrols? Whatever happened to cops who know residents, and walk the streets? They don't even respond to calls." Singling out officers who remained from the city force — Neil is a retired Public Works employee whose last job was at the department's headquarters — she said that "some of the new officers aren't trained right and they're not getting socialized. The young white ones were raised with the dangers of Camden, and they're just thrown into this." County spokesman Dan Keashen said the department is now 54 percent minority, in a city that is 42 percent African American, 50.3 percent Hispanic and 21.9 percent white, according to 2019 U.S. Census estimates. Many in the city believe the department should hire more minorities to better reflect those they are policing. Wysocki, speaking to the Courier-Post Monday, said he "can't say we're perfect." "To be honest, I agree with their complaint," said the chief. "I 100 percent support them, but my hands are tied" by state Civil Service requirements on hiring. He said he's spoken with state legislators representing Camden to loosen requirements so the department can hire more city residents. "To the naysayers, I would say that's seven years ago," said Wysocki. "Get to know us. I am happy to sit down and talk to anyone who wants to talk with us. Communities and police have to work together. Give us a chance." Marching in Camden "We didn't want to destroy our neighborhood," said Tawanda Jones, a city resident and founder of Camden Sophisticated Sisters, a dance and drill team that places academic and community service requirements on its members. The march was Deaver's vision, Jones said, but as more people reached out to participate, concern began to grow about keeping it orderly. "There was a fear of outsiders coming in to riot in our city," said Rev. Levi Combs III of First Refuge Progressive Baptist Church in Camden. "Our focus was to make sure this was in memory of George Floyd." "What was in the back of my mind was helping people understand why we as African Americans are frustrated with the system. My perspective as a minister and someone educated in the city was more about ensuring our people were safe (from COVID-19), how to not spread the virus, make sure we did this in a safe manner, and sending the message that Camden is not what it is perceived to be." Deaver, who moved from Camden to Sicklerville three years ago, said, "I know it's a rough city. I have friends who were murdered in the city, and it's a rough city to have police come and march with us." Yolanda Deaver, right, talks to U.S. Rep. Donald Norcross (left) and Camden County Police Chief Joe Wysocki at a march in memory of George Floyd in Camden on Saturday. (Photo: Courtesy Yolanda Deaver) "Tensions are so high with the death of George Floyd," said Wysocki, "it's horrible, what happened to him is just horrible, and I thought, I have got to go. So I asked the clergy if I could go and they said yes." Wysocki and Deaver were introduced Saturday before the march. "It was an honor (to participate)," he said. He asked, he said, "because this was her march. I was learning from her." At one point, Deaver said, she yelled, "Black lives matter!," but turned to Wysocki, who is white, worried he might be upset. "But I understood," he said. "That's what we were there for. People were able to voice their frustration at the Police Administration Building" — with policing in Camden and all over — "and I am glad they did. This was all about the community and I'm honored they let us be part of it." "What I will give credit to (Wysocki) for is, he is willing to come to the people," said Combs. "He does not want a riot on his hands. He wants community policing and he wants them engaged, and he's admitted there have been problems." The department, Combs said, needs more minority officers; complaints of disenfranchisement are valid, he said. "Residents feel that they don't have any power or influence over their police department and don't have a say in how they police the city. Some feel they are profiled and marginalized. People want to see diversity in law enforcement. "These were the cries of the people in the march and I believe the chief sees that." Ugliness across the river As the march ended in Camden, peace settled over the city on a mild late spring Saturday. But in Philadelphia, what began as a peaceful assembly at the Philadelphia Museum of Art dissipated as some protesters marched back to City Hall and north on Broad Street. By nightfall, the city was engulfed in chaos, flames, rioting and looting. The Delaware River Port Authority kept its PATCO Hi-Speedline trains out of the city; the Benjamin Franklin Bridge was closed to vehicle and foot traffic and Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney imposed a curfew before ordering all retail businesses within the city to closed. From Camden, residents could see the black smoke rising, and at night they could hear the sounds of unrest. "As we were on our march, my phone started going off like crazy," said Jones. "I have some babies in Philadelphia and I told them to stay in the house, don't go outside. One was stuck in the city and I was on my GPS trying to help her get out." She called Philadelphia's violence "so disheartening." She believes the many peaceful protesters from earlier in the day went home and people from outside the city instigated the violence. "People are desperate; some of them are in it for the cause and some were just out there to see what they could get. Some people were just in survival mode." Combs agreed the rioting "is not a black thing. I see white instigation. We need to be fair: What saddens me as I see it unfold (for a third day Monday) is it's only one-sided (in media portrayals). What's being done is in equal share in my opinion; it's white instigation and agitation and it's blacks looting and rioting, but this is not what we do in our culture and our community. This is not common, but this is a narrative in the media, that only blacks loot and riot." "My heart went out to," Philadelphia Police Commissioner (Danielle Outlaw, said Wysocki. She came to the city from Portland and within weeks the city, like the entire country, found itself in the midst of a global pandemic. "She hasn't been dealt a fair hand. But she's extremely bright and I hope she gets the chance to prove herself." Like Combs, he believes outsiders are the primary drivers of the violence and mayhem in Philadelphia. "Social media is the driver," he said. "It's coming from somewhere else, outsiders hijacking peaceful protests." So why not Camden? Neil, the city resident and longtime activist who makes her way around in a shiny, new motorized blue-and-white scooter, has a simple theory of why there is not rioting or looting in Camden. "There's nothing in Camden!" she said. "What are they going to do: Go to the aquarium and steal the fish?! We don't have enough stores, there's nothing to steal. I wish they would steal the politicians." "I don't fear any of that in Camden because of the dynamics in Camden," said Combs. "We don't have a concentration of stores. We're still fighting for a full-service supermarket in Camden. The stores are all in the neighborhoods and they're protected by the people who live there." In this Saturday, May 30, 2020, photo, Lt. Zack James of the Camden County Metro Police Department marches along with demonstrators in Camden, N.J., to protest the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Police officers in one of New Jersey's largest and most violent cities were praised on social media for marching alongside protesters in rallies held this weekend over Floyd's death. (April Saul via AP) (Photo: April Saul, AP) Kimberly Mutcherson, co-dean of Rutgers-Camden Law School (its first black, female and LGBT dean in the school's history) and an expert on race and the law, said Camden's law enforcement leaders set themselves apart from those in other cities in a "profound" way. "One thing that's interesting about Camden is that there was, from the beginning, a police department and chief who recognized that the protesters, the people out there, their cause is righteous. "The bottom line is, we've seen this over and over and over, and if people in law enforcement don't take it seriously, we will see it again." Riots, she said, paraphrasing the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., are the expression of people who have been otherwise unheard. Mutcherson, who's taught at the school since 2002 and lives in Collingswood, a diverse suburb next to Camden, said "there's this unfair reputation that Camden has as a city of crime, but that's not the city I see. It's a city of people working and raising families, people who just want to live safely and in peace, like any other people." Wysocki called the national attention and praise from Obama "humbling." The son of a Camden police officer, Wysocki is acutely aware of the impact riots have on cities like his — its earlier riots were precipitated by tension between police and minority residents. "We love Camden and we love the people of Camden," he said. "It gets a bad rap but crime is down; we had 15 homicides last year and this year it's four." Jones admitted she's anticipating "a lot of sleepless nights" as cities across America continue to experience violent unrest. "We're talking about the City of Brotherly Love — we're neighbors. We're all affected by this." But, she said, she's "incredibly proud of my city" for remaining peaceful. "Since Camden has been in a negative light for so long, I'm happy to see it be a model for peaceful protest to the rest of the country." Phaedra Trethan has been a reporter and editor in South Jersey since 2007 and has covered Camden since 2015. She’s called South Jersey home since 1971. Contact her with feedback, news tips or questions at ptrethan@gannettnj.com, on Twitter @CP_Phaedra, or by phone at 856-486-2417. Help support local journalism with a Courier-Post subscription. title: As chaos engulfed Philadelphia, peace reigned across the river in Camden
text: CLOSE In this Saturday, May 30, 2020, photo, Camden County Metro Police Chief Joe Wysocki raises a fist while marching with Camden residents and activists in Camden, N.J., to protest the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Police officers in one of New Jersey's largest and most violent cities were praised on social media for marching alongside protesters in rallies held this weekend over Floyd's death. (April Saul via AP) (Photo: April Saul, AP) Barack Obama visited Camden in 2015 and lauded the Camden County Police Department's commitment to achieving public safety through community-engaged policing. On Monday, while what began as peaceful protests condemning the death of George Floyd at the knee of Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin continued to descend into violence, arson, vandalism and looting, the 44th President once again praised the department for its part in keeping the peace in Camden. In a Medium post entitled "How to Make this Moment the Turning Point for Real Change," Obama calls protests across the country a representation of "a genuine and legitimate frustration over a decades-long failure to reform police practices and the broader criminal justice system in the United States." Peaceful demonstrators, said Obama, "deserve our respect and support, not condemnation — something that police in cities like Camden and Flint have commendably understood." So why did Camden, a majority-minority city where riots in 1969 and 1971 accelerated the blight, crime and poverty which challenge it still, remain peaceful as cities from Los Angeles to New York, Minneapolis to Atlanta, have seen chaos and anger spill over? How it began Yolanda Deaver, a mother of three sons, already knew the unfathomable pain of losing a child. Her oldest died three years ago from leukemia at just 15. When she saw the video of George Floyd's life and breath being squeezed from him, as she heard him call out for his own mother, her thoughts went to her surviving sons, ages 13 and 4. "It weighed heavily on me," she said. "I thought about my sons; I am trying to raise them to be successful, smart, respectful young men, and I hate for them to go through any racial profiling." Deaver, who owns Prissy Chic Hair Company, a salon and beauty supply on Mount Ephraim Avenue in Camden, "had a feeling in my heart that I had to do something." She mulled going to Minneapolis but worried it might be dangerous; instead, she posted her intention to march from her salon to the Camden County Police Department building at Haddon Avenue and Federal Street. Shortly after posting her plan, a friend who is also a Camden County police officer asked if she could join, telling Deaver, "even though I am a police officer, I feel the same way you do." Deaver's reply: "As long as we march in solidarity." Soon, more police officers asked to join. By Saturday morning, the police chief was standing with Deaver, holding a banner and joining her in a "Black Lives Matter" chant. Different department, different emphasis The Camden County Police Department formed in 2013 in the aftermath of a city financial crisis that prompted mass layoffs within the existing Camden City Police Department. In 2012, with a decimated police force, the city set a grim milestone with a record high 67 homicides. The new, county-run department, initially led by Chief J. Scott Thomson, hired some of the city officers and recruited new officers. Thomson began his career with the city department and rose through its ranks to become its youngest chief. With the newly-formed department, he placed an emphasis on community policing, drawing national attention and presidential praise. Buy Photo President Barack Obama gestures towards the crowd prior to speaking at the Ray & Joan Kroc Corps Community Center in Camden on Monday. (Photo: Chris LaChall/Courier-Post) Thomson retired last year, and Joe Wysocki, who'd served as his second-in-command since 2016, took over, intent on continuing and expanding upon Thomson's emphasis on engagement. The department has not been without its critics. There were initial charges of union busting (officers are now members of a local Fraternal Order of Police) and worries that bringing recruits from outside the city — many of them young and inexperienced in urban policing — would soon abandon Camden for more lucrative jobs with suburban departments. The county-run department led many city activists to cry foul, saying the county was imposing the change upon disenfranchised residents. Vida Neil, a city resident and activist, called it a "rogue police force." "Their idea of community policing is to set up a barbecue grill and pull up an ice cream truck," said Neil, who lives in the city's Morgan Village section. "But whatever happened to foot patrols? Whatever happened to cops who know residents, and walk the streets? They don't even respond to calls." Singling out officers who remained from the city force — Neil is a retired Public Works employee whose last job was at the department's headquarters — she said that "some of the new officers aren't trained right and they're not getting socialized. The young white ones were raised with the dangers of Camden, and they're just thrown into this." County spokesman Dan Keashen said the department is now 54 percent minority, in a city that is 42 percent African American, 50.3 percent Hispanic and 21.9 percent white, according to 2019 U.S. Census estimates. Many in the city believe the department should hire more minorities to better reflect those they are policing. Wysocki, speaking to the Courier-Post Monday, said he "can't say we're perfect." "To be honest, I agree with their complaint," said the chief. "I 100 percent support them, but my hands are tied" by state Civil Service requirements on hiring. He said he's spoken with state legislators representing Camden to loosen requirements so the department can hire more city residents. "To the naysayers, I would say that's seven years ago," said Wysocki. "Get to know us. I am happy to sit down and talk to anyone who wants to talk with us. Communities and police have to work together. Give us a chance." Marching in Camden "We didn't want to destroy our neighborhood," said Tawanda Jones, a city resident and founder of Camden Sophisticated Sisters, a dance and drill team that places academic and community service requirements on its members. The march was Deaver's vision, Jones said, but as more people reached out to participate, concern began to grow about keeping it orderly. "There was a fear of outsiders coming in to riot in our city," said Rev. Levi Combs III of First Refuge Progressive Baptist Church in Camden. "Our focus was to make sure this was in memory of George Floyd." "What was in the back of my mind was helping people understand why we as African Americans are frustrated with the system. My perspective as a minister and someone educated in the city was more about ensuring our people were safe (from COVID-19), how to not spread the virus, make sure we did this in a safe manner, and sending the message that Camden is not what it is perceived to be." Deaver, who moved from Camden to Sicklerville three years ago, said, "I know it's a rough city. I have friends who were murdered in the city, and it's a rough city to have police come and march with us." Yolanda Deaver, right, talks to U.S. Rep. Donald Norcross (left) and Camden County Police Chief Joe Wysocki at a march in memory of George Floyd in Camden on Saturday. (Photo: Courtesy Yolanda Deaver) "Tensions are so high with the death of George Floyd," said Wysocki, "it's horrible, what happened to him is just horrible, and I thought, I have got to go. So I asked the clergy if I could go and they said yes." Wysocki and Deaver were introduced Saturday before the march. "It was an honor (to participate)," he said. He asked, he said, "because this was her march. I was learning from her." At one point, Deaver said, she yelled, "Black lives matter!," but turned to Wysocki, who is white, worried he might be upset. "But I understood," he said. "That's what we were there for. People were able to voice their frustration at the Police Administration Building" — with policing in Camden and all over — "and I am glad they did. This was all about the community and I'm honored they let us be part of it." "What I will give credit to (Wysocki) for is, he is willing to come to the people," said Combs. "He does not want a riot on his hands. He wants community policing and he wants them engaged, and he's admitted there have been problems." The department, Combs said, needs more minority officers; complaints of disenfranchisement are valid, he said. "Residents feel that they don't have any power or influence over their police department and don't have a say in how they police the city. Some feel they are profiled and marginalized. People want to see diversity in law enforcement. "These were the cries of the people in the march and I believe the chief sees that." Ugliness across the river As the march ended in Camden, peace settled over the city on a mild late spring Saturday. But in Philadelphia, what began as a peaceful assembly at the Philadelphia Museum of Art dissipated as some protesters marched back to City Hall and north on Broad Street. By nightfall, the city was engulfed in chaos, flames, rioting and looting. The Delaware River Port Authority kept its PATCO Hi-Speedline trains out of the city; the Benjamin Franklin Bridge was closed to vehicle and foot traffic and Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney imposed a curfew before ordering all retail businesses within the city to closed. From Camden, residents could see the black smoke rising, and at night they could hear the sounds of unrest. "As we were on our march, my phone started going off like crazy," said Jones. "I have some babies in Philadelphia and I told them to stay in the house, don't go outside. One was stuck in the city and I was on my GPS trying to help her get out." She called Philadelphia's violence "so disheartening." She believes the many peaceful protesters from earlier in the day went home and people from outside the city instigated the violence. "People are desperate; some of them are in it for the cause and some were just out there to see what they could get. Some people were just in survival mode." Combs agreed the rioting "is not a black thing. I see white instigation. We need to be fair: What saddens me as I see it unfold (for a third day Monday) is it's only one-sided (in media portrayals). What's being done is in equal share in my opinion; it's white instigation and agitation and it's blacks looting and rioting, but this is not what we do in our culture and our community. This is not common, but this is a narrative in the media, that only blacks loot and riot." "My heart went out to," Philadelphia Police Commissioner (Danielle Outlaw, said Wysocki. She came to the city from Portland and within weeks the city, like the entire country, found itself in the midst of a global pandemic. "She hasn't been dealt a fair hand. But she's extremely bright and I hope she gets the chance to prove herself." Like Combs, he believes outsiders are the primary drivers of the violence and mayhem in Philadelphia. "Social media is the driver," he said. "It's coming from somewhere else, outsiders hijacking peaceful protests." So why not Camden? Neil, the city resident and longtime activist who makes her way around in a shiny, new motorized blue-and-white scooter, has a simple theory of why there is not rioting or looting in Camden. "There's nothing in Camden!" she said. "What are they going to do: Go to the aquarium and steal the fish?! We don't have enough stores, there's nothing to steal. I wish they would steal the politicians." "I don't fear any of that in Camden because of the dynamics in Camden," said Combs. "We don't have a concentration of stores. We're still fighting for a full-service supermarket in Camden. The stores are all in the neighborhoods and they're protected by the people who live there." In this Saturday, May 30, 2020, photo, Lt. Zack James of the Camden County Metro Police Department marches along with demonstrators in Camden, N.J., to protest the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Police officers in one of New Jersey's largest and most violent cities were praised on social media for marching alongside protesters in rallies held this weekend over Floyd's death. (April Saul via AP) (Photo: April Saul, AP) Kimberly Mutcherson, co-dean of Rutgers-Camden Law School (its first black, female and LGBT dean in the school's history) and an expert on race and the law, said Camden's law enforcement leaders set themselves apart from those in other cities in a "profound" way. "One thing that's interesting about Camden is that there was, from the beginning, a police department and chief who recognized that the protesters, the people out there, their cause is righteous. "The bottom line is, we've seen this over and over and over, and if people in law enforcement don't take it seriously, we will see it again." Riots, she said, paraphrasing the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., are the expression of people who have been otherwise unheard. Mutcherson, who's taught at the school since 2002 and lives in Collingswood, a diverse suburb next to Camden, said "there's this unfair reputation that Camden has as a city of crime, but that's not the city I see. It's a city of people working and raising families, people who just want to live safely and in peace, like any other people." Wysocki called the national attention and praise from Obama "humbling." "Since Camden has been in a negative light for so long, I'm happy to see it be a model for peaceful protest to the rest of the country."
