title: Pride Month: How LGBTQ community, allies will be celebrating differently due to COVID-19
text: CLOSE The Pride March in New York City moves down 5th Ave, through the village and up 7th Ave. 50 years since Stonewall. Sunday, June 30, 2019 NorthJersey There's no stopping the spirit of Pride. The global coronavirus pandemic has changed every aspect of life, and the resulting cessation of public gatherings means June's commemoration of Pride Month will be decidedly different. Organizations across the region are getting creative, hosting celebrations, gatherings and shows as the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer community perseveres during a trying time, facing an uncertain future. This summer's now-canceled NYC Pride schedule of in-person events was originally planned for June 14 to 28 by organization Heritage of Pride. The Pride March moves north on 7th Ave. Sunday June 30, 2019 (Photo: Kevin R. Wexler/NorthJersey.com) “While this pandemic prevents us from coming together to march, it will in no way stop us from celebrating the indelible contributions that the LGBTIA+ community has made to New York City or from recommitting ourselves to the fight for equal rights,” New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said in an April statement. It's been half a century since the modern LGBTQ rights movement was born with the Gay Pride March presented by the Christopher Street Liberation Day Committee in June 1970. That landmark march came a year after the historic uprising at the Stonewall Inn in Manhattan's Greenwich Village, when on June 28, 1969, a riot broke out as New York City police raided the bar, enforcing a law against selling alcohol to homosexual patrons. It should have been a banner year. Instead, like everything else during the pandemic, events have had to be rethought. Here are some of the inventive ways. 'Enormous virtual hug' The New Jersey LGBTQ Pride Parade, Rally and Festival, an Asbury Park fixture since 1992 historically held on the first Sunday in June was moved by event organizers Jersey Pride, Inc. from June 7 to National Coming Out Day, Sunday, Oct. 11. NJ HISTORY: How the LGBTQ community saved Asbury Park That delay isn't stopping Paradise, a hub of gay nightlife in Asbury Park, from planning to celebrate online. Paradise will present a Virtual Pride Zoom Party 5 to 9 p.m. Sunday, June 7. Created by DJs Steven Jay and Steve Sidewalk, the night will feature music from Jay and Sidewalk and fellow DJs Tyler Valentine and Mikey Mo, as well as drag performances. "For some people (Paradise) is just like their safe haven, seeing everybody, making those kinds of connections with people and having that availability," said Jay, also assistant manager at the club. "Maybe there’s somebody you’ve missed that you haven’t exchanged numbers with that will be there (at the Zoom party), maybe there’s someone that you’ve been worried about or you just want to see people, see their face, see that they’re OK. Sometimes hearing them isn’t enough.” Want access to all of our stories? Consider purchasing a digital subscription to the Asbury Park Press to keep up with the latest news in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. Paradise was opened at the Jersey Shore by record producer Shep Pettibone in 1999, the same year President Bill Clinton proclaimed June as Gay and Lesbian Pride Month and a decade before President Barack Obama's recognition of June as Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Pride Month in 2009. "We were very, very connected and now we’re all feeling that loss and a lot of people are feeling that loss and they’re home alone in their apartments," said Paradise event coordinator Kelly J. Martin. So it is really important for us to be able to see each other and attend something together, even if it is only virtual. What they really, really need right now is a huge, enormous virtual hug.” Jersey Pride and Asbury Park-based organization Garden State Equality will present United in Pride noon Sunday, June 7 via Facebook Live and YouTube. Sponsored by Bank of America, the virtual celebration will feature entertainment from artists including La Bouche and Felipe Rose of the Village People, and United in Pride will also raise funds for organizations working for racial justice in New Jersey, according to the event's website. Fellow Asbury Park destination Georgies Bar will host a Virtual Pride Tea Dance 3 to 6 p.m. Sunday, June 7 via Zoom, Instagram and Facebook Live, hosted by drag star Pissi Myles and featuring DJ UnclesNephew. The Jersey City LGBT Pride Festival will sponsor a Drag Queen Story Hour via Instagram Live featuring Harmonica Sunbeam and hosted by bookshop WORD Jersey City 11 a.m. Saturday, June 6. Keep the momentum going A pair of New Jersey towns that held their inaugural Pride celebrations in 2019, Toms River and Princeton, are likewise finding ways to keep the momentum going. Exit 82 Theatre Company, which launched Toms River Pride last year, reconfigured its June 20 celebration with social distancing guidelines. Saturday morning will feature a "Drive-Through Pride" with a closed path so attendees can participate from their own cars, followed in the afternoon and evening by online events including make-up demonstrations, drag performances and presentations by Garden State Equality. "This is something we wanted to do because in Toms River and Ocean County, the tradition stands stronger than the party," said Billy Cardone, executive director of Exit 82 Theatre Company. "We cared more about the visibility of our community so people are reminded that they are not alone." Robt Seda-Schreiber, chief activist with the Bayard Rustin Center for Social Justice, pictured center at the center's inaugural Princeton Pride Parade in 2019. (Photo: Courtesy of the Bayard Rustin Center for Social Justice) The first Princeton Pride Parade, presented by the Bayard Rustin Center for Social Justice, drew more than 3,000 people in June 2019, including Gov. Phil Murphy and New Jersey first lady Tammy Murphy, according to Rustin Center chief activist Robt Seda-Schreiber. With the possibility of an in-person gathering out of the question this June, the Rustin Center pivoted to Virtual Pride '20, an online parade happening 7 to 10 p.m. on Saturday, June 20. Virtual Pride '20 is expanding on online community gatherings nightly through Rustin Center's Social Justice Power Hours on its Facebook page. “We want to dedicate ourselves to always being true to our local community but also with our eyes on that national outreach where we can really bring together folks in this unique opportunity," Seda-Schreiber said. Buy Photo Best friends Sarah Briante, 16, and Yustina Alexander-Himlah, 16, pause for a moment of silence at the North Jersey Pride Festival in Maplewood on June 12, 2016. (Photo: Jennifer Brown/special to the record) The Pride Center of New Jersey, based in Highland Park, will host the online showcase and fundraiser "Pride Idol" 7 p.m. Friday, June 5. The event will feature appearances by performers including Josh Zuckerman, Hedda Lettuce and more. North Jersey Pride, a Maplewood-based group, has been staging Pride events for 10 years. Their North Jersey Pride Festival is usually held the second Sunday in June at Memorial Park in Maplewood with a PG-rated, family orientation. Last year’s festival drew upwards of 5,000. “We’re designed with families in mind,” said executive director C.J. Prince. Obviously, they’re facing a bit of a challenge, in this socially-distanced year. North Jersey Pride serves the entire northern part of the state. The events draw people from even beyond New Jersey. Somehow, on some platform, the show will go on, Prince promised. “We definitely didn’t want to let June go by without marking it,” Prince said. “People really need something to look forward to and celebrate. Our theme this year is, ‘Resilient and Proud.’" CJ Prince, Executive Director of North Jersey Pride, stands near rainbow painted crosswalks in Maplewood on Tuesday, June 19, 2018. (Photo: Michael Karas/NorthJersey.com) A lot of ideas are still being batted around for June. Among them: a virtual raising of the rainbow flag, with appropriate speeches and commentary, on Sunday, June 7; a “make your own pride banner” event in which community kids and adults make signs to be displayed outside of homes which locals can then see from their cars or on foot.; Instagram live segments boosting local LGBTQ-owned businesses, and a big June 28 virtual event featuring celebrities, music, performances and videos of North Jerseyans celebrating Pride in their homes. Details, for these and other programs, will be worked out in the next few weeks: visit northjerseypride.org to stay in the loop. In New York, more changes NYC Pride, with the support of LGBTQ advocacy organization GLAAD, presents Pride 2020 Drag Fest from 6:30 to 8 p.m. Friday, June 19 to Sunday, June 21. The online festival from New York City drag artist Marti Gould Cummings and The Only Productions will feature more than 100 performers appearing on NYC Pride and GLAAD Facebook pages, with viewers able to support each performer via Venmo and other donation platforms. People cheer for the Pride March in Greenwich Village. Sunday June 30, 2019 (Photo: Kevin R. Wexler/NorthJersey.com) Heritage of Pride also will participate in the 24-hour streaming event Global Pride on Saturday, June 27 and will present a two-hour Pride special noon Sunday, June 28 on WABC Channel 7. Losing your job overnight: How the LGBTQ community has been affected by coronavirus With "Schitt's Creek" co-creator Dan Levy, homeless LGBTQ youth organization The Ali Forney Center and activists Yanzi Peng and Victoria Cruz as grand marshals, the June 28 broadcast will feature performances by Janelle Monáe, Deborah Cox, Billy Porter and Luísa Sonza. Looking for the trusted place to find the best home service providers? Find local pros. Fighting bullying with Pride Beyond Pride Month, Southern New Jersey Gay Pride’s 12th annual festival in at Cooper River Park in Cherry Hill is planned for noon to 6 p.m. Sept. 13 but it’s unclear if that date will change due to the current pandemic. The celebration’s theme is #YouAreIncluded in collaboration with WorldPride. This is the fifth year of an anti-bullying program. The free, rain-or-shine event includes vendors, live performances and dancing. Participants are asked to bring their own blankets, chairs and tables. Southern New Jersey Gay Pride director and founder DeAnn Cox said they’re also looking at options for a virtual Pride celebration and will see how other festivals unfold virtually in June. Philadelphia-based LGBTQ+ film festival qFLIX Philadelphia, originally scheduled to launch March 22, was also postponed and has switched gears to launch PrideFLIX, an online iteration of the festival launching Monday, June 1, with a portion of ticket proceeds supporting local LGBTQ+ charities. While the Philly Pride Parade and Festival originally scheduled for June 14 has been canceled, the day's planned Philly Pride Run 5K race has been reconfigured as a virtual run. Registered participants pick their own start time, location and course and will have from 10 a.m. Sunday, June 14 to 10 a.m. Sunday, June 21 to complete the race supporting the William Way LGBT Community Center. CLOSE See Gov. Phil Murphy and U.S. Sen. Cory Booker speak at Jersey Pride, Asbury Park's 27th annual celebration of the LGBTQ community. Asbury Park Press 'We’re a particularly resilient bunch' The LGBTQ Prom has been held by the Hudson Pride Center in New Jersey's Hudson County for more than 10 years. This year’s online edition will allow young folks, age 15 to 22, to significantly expand their dating pool. You can hook up with a hot guy in Melbourne or a sexy lady in Mumbai and bring them — virtually — to the prom. “We believe every kid should be able to have a prom and go with their date of their choice, in the attire of their choice,” said Elizabeth Schedl, chief operations officer for Hudson Pride Center. The event, which will feature a DJ, vogue competition, and the crowning of “royals” (king and queen is too cisgender) is from 4:30 p.m. to 7 p.m. June 13. The Hudson County group, based in Jersey City, will be hosting many other Pride events, including a SAGE LGBTQ yoga event (for 55 and older) 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. June 3 on Zoom, a live happy hour from 5 p.m. to 6 p.m. June 11 in which folks 21 and up can learn to make cocktails, Pride yoga events on June 16 and 22 (6 p.m. to 7 p.m.), an open mike night on June 18 (6 p.m. to 7:30 p.m., ages 18 and up), a queer book reading on June 25 at 11 a.m., and a Pride watch party on June 28. “Our main focus is really to make sure to connect with individuals and celebrate our pride — especially the most isolated individuals,” Schedl said. “I think there’s a sense of loss, in that the community won’t be able to be together and celebrate,” said Rick Kavin, vice-president of operations for The Pride Center of New Jersey. “But at the same time I think we’re a particularly resilient bunch.” More than 65,000 people participated in Rochester, New York's Pride parade and festival last year. Organizers hope to reschedule the week-long series of events sometime this fall, depending on how the state's re-opening plans proceed. Carlos Merriweather of Rochester takes a selfie during the Rochester Pride Parade in 2018. (Photo: Carlos Ortiz/Rochester Democrat and Chronicle) The Connecticut Virtual Pride Facebook page serves as a guide to how Pride is being commemorated online by groups across the state in June. At 7 p.m. Monday, June 8, the page will premiere a virtual parade of sorts in the form of a video featuring contributions from local organizations and community members. In Delaware, there will be no annual Pride Festival and Parade this year. It would have been the second parade for Delaware Pride Inc., which has been run by a small group of volunteers since the late '90s. Because the organization is run by only a handful of people, it does not have the capability to host something virtually, explained Vice President Amanda White. Madeline Porter of Wilmington displays a rainbow flag during Delaware Pride Festival in Dover on June 1, 2019 (Photo: Jeanne Kuang/The News Journal) The group also is looking into virtual events for June and beyond. The festival and parade have been rescheduled for Saturday, June 5, 2021. The event is free to the public. Fay Jacobs, who is the editor of Letters from Camp Rehoboth, a non-profit community service organization and publication, said efforts to connect the community have gone virtual. The group will celebrate Pride Month with the June 15 issue of Letters, Jacobs said. “At this point, everyone is worried about a couple of things,” the local author said. “They’re worried about the upcoming election. They’re worried about the pandemic. A lot of people are home and paying attention more than ever to the news and, personally, I hope to see Pride celebrations on the network news, on the cable channels. I don’t know if we will. I’m certainly very hopeful we will.” On Tuesday, May 26, Delaware Governor John Carney lifted more social restrictions in the First State, announcing that gatherings of up to 250 people will be allowed starting June 1. Whether that will change plans for Pride Month celebrations is yet to be determined. White said because Delaware Pride does not have a membership count, it may be hard to hold in-person events even with the relaxing of restrictions because it would be difficult to figure out how many people might show up. 'Stay home, stay connected' Baltimore Pride, in its 45th year and one of the oldest pride events in the nation, has been postponed and has not yet announced a new date for its celebration. The festival is usually three days long and draws around 30,000 people. When it does occur, the celebration is slated to include a drag show, high heel race, pet parade and more. The Frederick Pride Parade in Frederick, Maryland, is rescheduled for Sunday, Oct.4. Now in its ninth year, the event is part of an all-day festival at Carroll Creek Linear Park. Elsewhere in Maryland, The Cumberland Pride Festival in Allegany County will be two weeks later on Sunday, Oct. 18. And the Westminster Pride Extravaganza in the Baltimore suburb of Westminster, is postponed with a new date not yet determined. According to howardcountypride.org, Howard County Pride organizers are postponing HoCO Pride 2020 “to continue taking protective measures against the spread of the virus.” Meanwhile, the group plans to celebrate pride in other ways in Howard County mainly through interactive online activities. Annapolis Pride is going virtual with its parade on Saturday, June 27 at 4 p.m. As Annapolispride.org says, “The parade and festival have been cancelled, but Pride is not!” The webpage offers a virtual festival with links to businesses, spiritual groups, community organizations and other resources. The Hagerstown, Maryland, Pride Parade also will take place virtually. Hagerstown Hopes released a letter online at hagerstownhopes.org: “Please remember that ours is a community of survivors,” it says. “While this news may feel like a setback ...we see it as a way to become more creative and as an opportunity to plan an extra-special Pride Festival in 2021.” Alicia Notarriani, The Herald-Mail, contributed to this report. title: Police march with protestors at George Floyd rally in Toms River
text: TOMS RIVER - Township police joined with about 200 protesters here this morning to demand justice for the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis. About 200 people marched from the parking lot of the Toms River Shopping Center, heading south on Main Street and then east on Washington Street, where they gathered in front of the Ocean County courthouse. They were joined by Freeholder Jack Kelly. "This march is for us to be heard and seen," said Toms River resident Katrina Garcia, one of the event's organizers. "This is not about black and white. It's about everyone." Buy Photo Toms River Law enforcement march with George Floyd protesters in unity through downtown Toms River on June 2, 2020. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) Police Chief Mitch Little, Deputy Chief Michael Belcher, Ocean County Prosecutor Bradley Bilhimer and the Rev. Michael Mazer, former pastor and member of the congregation at St. Andrew United Methodist Church, walked with Garcia at the front of the group of demonstrators. Freehold protest: Freehold Township protest against the death of George Floyd described as ‘peaceful’ They carried a banner the police department had brought to the march: "We are with you. Toms River Police Department." Councilman Terrance Turnbach and Capt. Anthony Carrington of the Prosecutor's Office walked with the marchers. Looking for the trusted place to find the best home service providers? Find local pros. When they reached the courthouse, protesters knelt on one knee to observe a moment of silence in George Floyd's memory. The video playlist above this story has scenes from today's march. Floyd, 46, died May 25 in Minneapolis after police there tried to arrest him following a forgery complaint. Video of the encounter, which spread widely online, showed a white police officer pressing a knee into Floyd's neck for nearly 9 minutes as Floyd gasped that he couldn't breathe. Blackout Tuesday: George Floyd protests: Jersey musicians will, and won't, take a pause on Blackout Tuesday Gov. Murphy: NJ George Floyd protests: Murphy expresses support at 'transformational moment' Protests: NJ George Floyd protests: Which remained peaceful, where there was violence The officer, Derek Chauvin, was charged Friday with third-degree murder and manslaughter. It was the latest in a string of incidents in recent years in which unarmed black people have been killed in interactions with the police, deaths that have sparked heated protests and calls for reform. Buy Photo Toms River Law enforcement march with George Floyd protesters in unity through downtown Toms River on June 2, 2020. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) "We've been trying to build relationships with the rest of the community for years," Little said. "Everyone here needs to know that we feel the same way about what happened. No good police officer agrees with what happened." Bilhimer said he attended the protest to show that law enforcement in Ocean County "stands together with the peaceful protesters." "We're all on the same side," Bilhimer said. "Hopefully, Ocean County can set an example that peaceful demonstrations are possible." The protest in Toms River was one of several demonstrations in recent days in the Shore area that was sparked by the death of George Floyd, a black man who died at the hands of a white Minneapolis police officer last week. Some of the initially peaceful protests have devolved into violence and looting, particularly after dark. Buy Photo Protesters raise their arms in solidarity during rally. Toms River Law enforcement march with George Floyd protesters in unity through downtown Toms River on June 2, 2020. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) "The pain is real right here," Mazer said, in a prayer before the march started. "The life of Mr. Floyd does matter. May we hold this memory as a guiding light today." George Floyd: Ocean County prosecutor, sheriff issue statements on George Floyd’s death As the walked through the parking lot and headed south on Main Street, protesters waved signs and chanted: "Black lives matter!" "Hands up, don't shoot," "I can't breathe," and "George Floyd!" Signs read: "Toms River for equality, #BLM," "Justice 4 Floyd," "No Justice, No Peace," and "White Silence is Compliance." "I'm really happy that everybody's here in peace," said Toms River resident Breana Renda, who helped organize the march. "The violence has to stop. We have to respect the wishes of the Floyd family. They called for peace." Toms River resident Devon Orozco said she came to the protest because "I want everybody to know that we care, that their lives matter." Referring to Martin Luther King Jr., Garcia said, "Let's continue his dream and make it a reality." Jean Mikle covers Toms River and several other Ocean County towns, and has been writing about local government and politics at the Jersey Shore for nearly 35 years. A finalist for the 2010 Pulitzer Prize in public service, she's also passionate about the Shore's storied music scene. Contact her: @jeanmikle, 732-643-4050, jmikle@gannettnj.com. Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/news/local/toms-river-area/toms-river/2020/06/02/police-march-protestors-george-floyd-rally-toms-river/3124146001/

title: Police, prosecutor help lead George Floyd protest in Toms River
text: TOMS RIVER — A peaceful march of about 100 people went through downtown on Tuesday morning to protest last week's death of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police. The group started its march at the Kohl's at the Toms River Center shopping center where members of Toms River police and the Ocean County Sheriff's Office handed out water and hand sanitizer to the marchers. Police also arranged for buses to take the marchers back to the shopping center. The group was joined by officers from both agencies, including police Chief Mitch Little and Ocean County Prosecutor Bradley Billimer, both of whom are white, along with protest organizer Katrina Garcia, who held a banner during the march. The march ended at the Ocean County Courthouse where the group chanted "black lives matter." Garcia, who is not part of any organization, put the march together after watching the video of Floyd crying for his mother while he lied facedown with Officer Derek Chauvin's knee on his neck. "I lost my mother when I was 9-years-old. I had to be a voice for my two children and for the community and the youth of this community. That's why I felt I had to do this. This was my purpose. For awareness, for peace, equality, unity, all of us to stick together," the 29-year-old told New Jersey 101.5. "The changes I would like to see are continuous change. I would love for Martin Luther King's dream to become our reality for real, for real and not just to end with Tuesday's march," Garcia said. Little praised Garcia for how she organized the rally. "She wanted to get all the best people from our community together to show support. We want to show support for what we all believe in in the community. I couldn't be more proud of this community right for the way everyone came together peacefully, we all walked peacefully, we had a nice demonstration downtown peacefully and we all dispersed peacefully," Little said. Little said no outside organizations were part of the march. Rumors has swirled about the protest turning violent. leading two downtown stores to board up their windows. The Ocean County Prosecutor's Office issued a statement that there was no evidence suggesting the march would turn violent. "It was a peaceful march. It was important for us to send a message from law enforcement in Ocean County and throughout New Jersey that we stand with peaceful protesters and we appreciate their right to protest," Billhimer said. He said that law enforcement and the community are on the same side about what happened to George Floyd but there is a difference in opinion in how to protest against it. "I think we proved that here today, and hopefully we can set an example for the rest of the country and for the state, that peaceful demonstrations are possible. Law enforcement, we were happy to walk with them and we're proud to be here today," Billhimer said. Marches are also scheduled for Highland Park, Hightstown, Morristown, Ocean City and Parsippany. on Tuesday. A protest of about 500 on Georges Road in South Brunswick was "uneventful," according to South Brunswick police deputy chief James Ryan. Protest march on Georges Road in South Brunswick (Sputh Brunswick Police) Tom Trembly and Kevin Williams contributed to this report. Contact reporter Dan Alexander at Dan.Alexander@townsquaremedia.com or via Twitter @DanAlexanderNJ Enter your number to get the NJ 101.5 app More from New Jersey 101.5:

title: Amid protests, Fairleigh Dickinson basketball coach offers support daily to his players
text: CLOSE Longtime coach Greg Herenda is in daily contact with the players on his Fairleigh Dickinson men’s basketball team. Herenda and his staff listen to the Knights’ concerns and provide support and guidance as the student-athletes watch the national unrest generated by the killing of George Floyd by a police officer in Minnesota. “We talk on the phone, we Zoom, and at night I make them check in with me,” Herenda said Tuesday, “because it’s a very dangerous time that we’re living in.” FDU, which last year celebrated its first NCAA tournament victory, has Knights living across the country, including New York City, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C., places where protests often have been overshadowed by looting. “When we Zoom, they talk, and my assistants talk, real talk, and what I hear from them is very positive,” said Herenda, who has led FDU for seven seasons. “But they’re scared, and they’re concerned. But it’s ‘Coach, we’re gonna be OK.’ And as a 59-year-old man, that’s reassuring to hear that from 20-year-old people.” Head coach Greg Herenda, center, of the Fairleigh Dickinson Knights celebrates with his team after defeating the Prairie View A&M Panthers 82-76 in the First Four of the 2019 NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament at UD Arena on March 19, 2019 in Dayton, Ohio. (Photo: Gregory Shamus, Getty Images) Herenda said his players, a majority of whom are African American, are well aware of racism, more than he or fellow coaches from an 11-team Northeast Conference that stretches across seven states. “The kids are smarter than we all think,” said Herenda, a New Jersey native and graduate of St. Peter’s Prep in Jersey City. “They just know there are really good people protesting, and then there’s people who are taking advantage. I’m confident, because my kids are not as down as the adults are, because they have a better scope. They live it. “Our whole conference is in major metropolises where there’s been racism going on for a while, so they see it way more than our coaches see it. They have a more positive attitude.” Buy Photo Commencement Speaker FDU Knights Men's Basketball Coach Greg Herenda during the Fairleigh Dickinson graduation ceremony at MetLife Stadium on Tuesday, May 21, 2019. (Photo: Michael Karas/NorthJersey.com) Herenda, a college coach since 1983, encourages his players to stay positive, and stay home and safe at night. “I tell them straight up, ‘Guys, the right to protest – we wouldn’t be America without protest – but as your head basketball coach, you cannot go out at night, because it’s not protests, it’s danger,”' he said. He knows student-athletes across the country are viewing the protests and looting, either via television or social media, and tells his Knights to gain strength from family and those close to them. Cooper: Coaches Benjie Wimberly, Sam Griffin using platforms to promote healing of racial disharmony | Cooper Rebuilding America: Staggered schedules, single dorm rooms may be 'new normal' for NJ colleges NJ reopening: NJ high school and college sports practices can resume under executive order, Murphy says “You watch television, and I tell recruits all the time, and it’s coming true right now, ‘The heroes in the world are the people you watch television with, not the people on television,’” Herenda said. "And I just think there are so many more good people than the bad that are being shown every night on television," Herenda added, "but we have to overcome that and stay together and be focused." Herenda does not believe that the unrest in the metropolitan area, most notably in New York City, will deter recruits from attending colleges in the tri-state region. “Every state has numerous metropolitan areas that are affected, so it’s not like it’s just in New York and New Jersey, or in Los Angeles,” said Herenda, whose Knights were 11-19 this season. “It’s in Dallas, it’s in Sacramento, it’s in Phoenix.” The Knights’ incoming recruits look forward to attending the school located in Hackensack and Teaneck, Herenda said, and the veterans look forward to returning. “These kids can’t wait to get on campus and start going to school,” Herenda said of the newcomers. “That’s the overriding feeling. These guys want to get back, and go to school, and especially play basketball.” Greg Mattura is a high school sports reporter for NorthJersey.com. For full access to live scores, breaking news and analysis from our Varsity Aces team, subscribe today. To get breaking news directly to your phone, sign up for our newsletter and download our app. Email: mattura@northjersey.com Twitter: @gregmattura

title: Paramus police investigate racist social media posts by students
text: CLOSE Newark NJ Protest for George Floyd NorthJersey.com PARAMUS — The Police Department and school board are investigating "racially and sexually offensive" social media posts that were circulated online by Paramus students. "The messages in these social media postings were clearly hurtful," Superintendent Michelle Robinson said in a statement on the school district's website. "As educators, we must use this incident as an opportunity to help our students grow and better understand their responsibility to respect the dignity and the rights of all individuals." The offensive postings were in response to the Black Lives Matter demonstrations occurring throughout the country after the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man, at the hands of Minnesota police. Officer Derek Chauvin was captured on video on May 25 kneeling on Floyd's neck for nearly nine minutes. Chauvin is charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter, and two independent autopsies have ruled the death a homicide. PEACEFUL PROTESTS: Newark, Englewood, Paterson protest to express frustration over police violence FOR SUBSCRIBERS: What would police reform in America look like? Many don't even know what it means Robinson said in the statement that the Board of Education, administration, staff, student body and community, and many others outside of Paramus, "are justifiably outraged by these racially and sexually charged messages." Paramus Mayor Richard LaBarbiera said in a Facebook post that he was "sickened, disgusted and most disappointed" by the postings. "Cannot simply ignore and hope that this goes away," LaBarbiera said in the post. "Instead must make it abundantly clear that this is entirely unacceptable, inexcusable and will not be tolerated here or anywhere; and will hold those involved accountable for their actions." Reader — covering our local communities takes time and resources. Help us better support your community by becoming a subscriber today — see our special offers. Chief Kenneth Ehrenberg said the Paramus Police Department is working with the Bergen County Prosecutor’s Office and the borough school district to investigate the situation. Because the parties involved are juveniles, he could not provide further information, Ehrenberg said. Stephanie Noda is a local reporter for NorthJersey.com. title: Social injustice has no home in Bergen County — now or in the future | Opinion
text: One hundred and sixty two years ago Abraham Lincoln stood on a platform in his home state of Illinois and uttered the immortal words “A house divided against itself cannot stand.” Unfortunately, these words ring as true today as they did in 1858. From the foundation of this American continent to the present day, race relations have been and continue to be a seminal issue. From colonization through slavery, reconstruction and the civil rights movement to this very moment, we as a nation have never adequately confronted the evils of prejudice. Over the last several months we have shamefully watched as young black men like Ahmaud Arbery and George Floyd were murdered for no apparent reasons. These are just the latest in a string of murders dating back to lynchings in the south after the Civil War. Why have these murders occurred? The answer is simple. They have occurred as a result of hatred for a person just because of the color of their skin. MIKE KELLY: What would police reform in America look like? Many don't even know what it means CHARLIE STILE: Trump blasts governors as 'weak' in face of George Floyd protests. Murphy has other ideas EDITORIAL: Reporters must not be charged or detained as they cover demonstrations | Editorial We as a nation cannot and will not tolerate these actions any further. It is time for us as Americans to heal ourselves with firm action. Albert Einstein wrote “the world will not be destroyed by those who do evil, but by those who watch them without doing anything.” The time has come for us to do something. We are asking for an open and frank discussion on race relations to start now. We must realize and address problems such as job creation, educational opportunities, better healthcare initiatives and housing. We can do nothing less. The systemic racism we have experienced for over four-hundred years must be eradicated from this nation’s soul. Buy Photo Following a solidarity march to protest over the death of George Floyd, a protester holds a placard as protesters gather outside of NJ State House in Trenton on 05/31/20. (Photo: Mitsu Yasukawa/ Northjersey.com) As Bergen County elected constitutional officials, we cannot control what the federal government does on this most important issue, but as representatives of all of the people of Bergen County we can start that dialogue here at home. As Martin Luther King, Jr. proclaimed “injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.” We are asking our elected officials, police departments, clergy and community leaders to join us in beginning this discussion. It very well might be the most important discussion we ever have. We ask those individuals to contact us to begin this open and frank dialogue. We as a people cannot let the words of Abraham Lincoln be prophetic. We cannot allow this house to be divided against itself. Michael R. Dressler is Bergen County Surrogate. John S. Hogan is Bergen County Clerk. Anthony Cureton is Bergen County Sheriff. Read or Share this story: https://www.northjersey.com/story/opinion/2020/06/02/social-injustice-has-no-home-bergen-county-nj/3124384001/

title: Toms River Police March With Protesters
text: TOMS RIVER – Police and protesters marched side by side in reaction to the murder of George Floyd, the Minneapolis man killed by police. His death sparked protests – and riots – throughout the nation. Here in New Jersey, there have been peaceful protests, like in Freehold and looting like in Atlantic City. In many of the more violent clashes that were reported, witnesses said that peaceful protests were disrupted by outside agitators. In Toms River, police and the public joined together. There were prayers, discourse, and marching. Photo by Ocean County Scanner News There were rumors early on that militant protestors would show up and damage property and go door to door attacking residents. These turned out to be only rumors – started by a white nationalist group trying to agitate emotions and foment a race war. “We’re going to walk with these people. We’re going to support them,” Police Chief Mitch Little said. He said he hoped that people from outside the community don’t come in and ruin the peaceful demonstration that local residents are trying to accomplish. “We stand in solidarity with those that wish to protest peacefully,” Ocean County Prosecutor Bradley Billhimer, who also marched Tuesday morning, said in a statement. “We are aware of rumors circulating on social media…and there is no evidence at this time to support those rumors. In collaboration with our law enforcement partners, we will be ready to handle any situation that may arise.”

title: Parsippany rally to demand justice for George Floyd
text: CLOSE Morris County residents end their march for George Floyd by dancing at Veteran's Memorial Park in Parsippany. Morristown Daily Record PARSIPPANY — The Patel family left a case of water outside their driveway, but feared it wouldn't be enough for the thousand people marching outside their home. "I have never seen this many people here before," a family member said. A protester walked by and approached the family. "This is the coolest thing Parsippany has ever done," he said as he grabbed a bottle of water before rejoining the march. Hundreds representing a number of generations gathered outside Parsippany High School on Tuesday to demand justice for George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man killed at the hands of Minneapolis Police Officer Derek Chauvin. The officer was fired from the Minneapolis Police Department and charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter. Protesters hold signs citing George Floyd's last words before he was killed by Minneapolis Police Officer Derek Chauvin. (Photo: Jessie Gomez) Parsippany residents and organizers Mitchell Petit-Frere, Jabari Jackson and Maurice Matthias said it was the first time they had ever planned a protest. "I had no idea this would become so big," Matthias said as he addressed the crowd of more than 1,200. "I can't just do nothing after seeing [George Floyd] die. This brings me to tears, because my father has to worry about me when I go for a run or for a drive. They worry about me because I'm a black man." Aside from justice for Floyd, organizers are demanding the implementation of an anti-racism curriculum in the Parsippany school district and anti-racism and de-escalation training for all township law enforcement officers. More: Randolph teens respond to racism with peaceful teach-in More: Will large George Floyd protests lead to a spike in NJ coronavirus cases? More: Hundreds gather in Morristown to demand justice for George Floyd and end police brutality With the help of Black Lives Matter Morristown and immigrant rights group Wind of the Spirit, protesters were told to stand in lines, ensuring that they were 6 feet apart. Wind of the Spirit Lead Organizer Brian Lozano led the first chant. "No Trump, no KKK, no racist USA," Lozano yelled. The crowd made its way down Vail Road as neighbors stood outside their homes and used their cellphones to record the swarms of protesters holding signs and chanting Floyd's name. A family watched through their window as Parsippany resident Chandu Bhorani knelt and raised his hands in front of protesters. "Look at this — it's beautiful! I'm here to support them," Bhorani said. On the sidelines, demonstrators kept off residents' lawn. Many residents left cases of water outside their homes for protesters to grab. Parsippany police officers waved at the crowd and a Morris County sheriff's officer high-fived a protester. A group of elderly residents sat outside Vail Manor, and one made the sign for peace with his fingers. A bystander thanked the crowd for marching outside his home. "Thank you, white folks," he said. Marchers made their way across Route 46 and into Veterans Memorial Park, filling an empty field. The marchers knelt and held their fists in the air as they chanted Floyd's name. The crowd heard from Wind of the Spirit Co-president Karol Ruiz, organizers and local clergy, including Pastor Charles Perez and the Rev. Sidney Williams, who said he was tired of thoughts and prayers. "We are tired of being sick and tired. Let freedom ring!" he said as the crowd cheered. Demonstrators hold their fists up in the air and kneel while chanting "George Floyd." (Photo: Jessie Gomez) Black Lives Matter Morristown co-founders T'Anna Kimbrough and Oliver Starnes spoke about the killings of Philando Castile, who was fatally shot by Minnesota police during a motor vehicle stop, and Alton Sterling, who was shot by police in Louisiana. Kimbrough recalled the last moments before Floyd's death. "He called for his momma! I can't breathe!" she yelled. A student read her school essay on racism. She talked about the moments of racism she experienced as a Muslim woman and about the killings of young black men. Those in the crowd teared up as they clapped for each speaker. By the end of the evening, protesters were encouraged to "keep the momentum going" and continue their education on racial injustices and police reforms. "Already, after Newark, Morristown, Jersey City, Paterson, Randolph and Parsippany rose up, already New Jersey is implementing reforms. There will be more. The people demand more. That's why we do what we do," Ruiz said. Jessie Gomez is a local reporter for DailyRecord.com and NorthJersey.com. For unlimited access to the most important news from your local community, please subscribe or activate your digital account today. Email: jgomez@gannettnj.com Twitter: @jessiereport Read or Share this story: https://www.dailyrecord.com/story/news/2020/06/02/parsippany-activists-want-peaceful-protest-george-floyd/3125095001/

title: Philly police say tear gas used because 676 protest turned hostile, but there’s no evidence that happened
text: Philadelphia officials are struggling to produce evidence to back up their claims that protests Monday on Interstate 676 had turned hostile before officers unleashed tear gas on demonstrators cornered on the highway. A peaceful protest over the killing of George Floyd and other Black people at the hands of law enforcement began around 3 p.m. at city police headquarters. Organized by the Philadelphia chapter of the political group “Party for Socialism and Liberation,” it moved through Chinatown to the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. Around 5 p.m., some of the estimated 3,000 to 5,000 protesters poured down embankment onto I-676, halting traffic in both directions. The demonstration ended a few minutes later with Philadelphia police using tear gas canisters and pepper spray to disperse the crowd, according to videos that spread quickly online. Viewers around the world expressed shock and outrage at the sight of demonstrators struggling to escape a fenced portion of the highway trench as officers continued to gas the area. They just got us all pretty good. The parkway is a mess right now. pic.twitter.com/RAO049eM82 — Jeff Neiburg (@Jeff_Neiburg) June 1, 2020 In a joint statement issued by Mayor Jim Kenney’s office shortly before midnight Monday, Police Commissioner Danielle Outlaw said law enforcement on site had no choice. Outlaw said an unnamed incident commander on the ground ordered tear gas delivered because a Pennsylvania state trooper was trapped in his patrol vehicle on the highway and surrounded by protesters, some of whom allegedly pelted law enforcement with rocks from an overpass. “While on the roadway, the crowd surrounded a state trooper, who was alone and seated in his vehicle, and began rocking the vehicle, with the trooper having no safe means of egress,” she said in a prepared statement. “The SWAT officers gave numerous orders for the crowd to disperse, to which the crowd did not comply.” Mayor Kenney and Outlaw cosigned the use of tear gas while raising questions about a separate incident in which a SWAT trooper was seen pepper-spraying kneeling protesters in the face. Both said the entire encounter would be fully investigated. But neither Kenney’s office nor Outlaw could immediately produce evidence showing any hostile actions had actually occurred. “We’re still gathering information,” Outlaw said at a Tuesday press conference. Many protesters who were there, like 31-year-old Fishtown resident Kara Khan, disputed the city’s version of events. “It’s appalling,” Khan said of the mayor’s office statement. “I have not seen any evidence that is true. It’s really shocking and hurtful watching the mayor lie.” Aerial footage does show some protesters moving past a lone Pennsylvania State Police vehicle in a gridlocked eastbound traffic lane –– but does not show individuals tampering with the vehicle. Later, a state trooper is visible outside the vehicle armed with a long gun, with Philly SWAT officers already approaching the protesters, some of whom had already begun to scatter. In one video, individuals are visible kneeling before an unidentified trooper. “No one seemed distressed. They just seemed like tough guys,” Khan said of the law enforcement present. “I didn’t see anyone throwing rocks at anybody.” Not long afterward, the crowd surged again, and SWAT teams began firing pepper pellets, with tear gas canisters following. Panicked protesters struggled to climb up the embankments, abandoning bicycles and backpacks to escape the gas. Some were trapped in the highway trench, unable to get over the fence before the gas hit them. Others in the back who couldn’t see police shooting tear gas said they thought protesters were running to escape oncoming cars—a similar event occurred on a Minneapolis highway taken over by protesters a few days ago. At the Tuesday press conference, Kenney said his office stood by their initial description of what transpired. “We stand by that statement about a state trooper being surrounded in his vehicles,” he said. In his initial statement supporting the use of teargas, Kenney indicated he had been “disturbed” by the footage he had seen of the protest. But Mike Dunn, a spokesperson for the mayor, later clarified the mayor had not actually seen footage of protesters rocking the vehicle or throwing projectiles. “The Mayor, in using the term ‘footage,’ was referring to video publicly broadcast by news organizations and on social media,” Dunn said. “The Mayor never said he saw the vehicle being rocked back and forth; that specific moment was referenced by the Commissioner. He said he saw footage of the incident that was disturbing.” Dunn could not confirm that the state police vehicle visible in aerial videos was the one in question –– or even where the vehicle in question was located. A state trooper spokesperson said the agency could also not immediately verify the specific details from Outlaw’s statement. A statement from the state police about the incident does not reference protesters throwing rocks or tampering with a trooper’s vehicle. “Law enforcement encountered a very difficult situation in a roadway that could have resulted in harm to protesters or motorists, and we, collectively, took steps to mitigate the risk to everyone on the road,” said spokesperson Ryan Tarkowski.

title: Police, prosecutor help lead George Floyd protest in Toms River
text: TOMS RIVER — A peaceful march of about 100 people went through downtown on Tuesday morning to protest last week's death of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police. The group started its march at the Kohl's at the Toms River Center shopping center where members of Toms River police and the Ocean County Sheriff's Office handed out water and hand sanitizer to the marchers. Police also arranged for buses to take the marchers back to the shopping center. The group was joined by officers from both agencies, including police Chief Mitch Little and Ocean County Prosecutor Bradley Billimer, both of whom are white, along with protest organizer Katrina Garcia, who held a banner during the march. The march ended at the Ocean County Courthouse where the group chanted "black lives matter." Garcia, who is not part of any organization, put the march together after watching the video of Floyd crying for his mother while he lied facedown with Officer Derek Chauvin's knee on his neck. "I lost my mother when I was 9-years-old. I had to be a voice for my two children and for the community and the youth of this community. That's why I felt I had to do this. This was my purpose. For awareness, for peace, equality, unity, all of us to stick together," the 29-year-old told WOBM News. "The changes I would like to see are continuous change. I would love for Martin Luther King's dream to become our reality for real, for real and not just to end with Tuesday's march," Garcia said. Little praised Garcia for how she organized the rally. "She wanted to get all the best people from our community together to show support. We want to show support for what we all believe in in the community. I couldn't be more proud of this community right for the way everyone came together peacefully, we all walked peacefully, we had a nice demonstration downtown peacefully and we all dispersed peacefully," Little said. Little said no outside organizations were part of the march. Rumors has swirled about the protest turning violent. leading two downtown stores to board up their windows. The Ocean County Prosecutor's Office issued a statement that there was no evidence suggesting the march would turn violent. "It was a peaceful march. It was important for us to send a message from law enforcement in Ocean County and throughout New Jersey that we stand with peaceful protesters and we appreciate their right to protest," Billhimer said. He said that law enforcement and the community are on the same side about what happened to George Floyd but there is a difference in opinion in how to protest against it. "I think we proved that here today, and hopefully we can set an example for the rest of the country and for the state, that peaceful demonstrations are possible. Law enforcement, we were happy to walk with them and we're proud to be here today," Billhimer said. Marches are also scheduled for Highland Park, Morristown, Ocean City, Parsippany and South Brunswick on Tuesday. Tom Trembly and Kevin Williams contributed to this report.

title: Eagles owner breaks silence on George Floyd killing: 'I am heartbroken and repulsed,' and more white players speak out
text: CLOSE A mostly peaceful protest in Philadelphia escalated as police gassed a crowd marching on the I-676 freeway. Here's how the afternoon progressed. Delaware News Journal Eagles owner Jeffrey Lurie said in a statement Tuesday that "silence is not an option," after leading an emotional discussion on race relations in the team's virtual meeting the day before. Lurie's statement came four days after a wave of protests raged across the United States after the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last week. PROTESTS IN PHILLY: Soon after National Guard arrives in Philadelphia, protesters take to city streets, close I-676 "Silence is not an option," Lurie said in the statement. Then he continued: "I am heartbroken and repulsed. There are no words strong enough to describe the horrific deaths and injustices that the black community continues to endure." Eagles coach Doug Pederson added to the conversation at the Monday virtual team meeting, and players, both black and white, did, too. WENTZ SPEAKS OUT: Eagles' Carson Wentz on racism after death of George Floyd in Minneapolis When it was over, several white players said they were moved by the description of what some black players and their friends and relatives have been through in dealing with racism. Philadelphia Eagles owner Jeffrey Lurie. (Photo: AP ) Among those who reportedly spoke were black players DeSean Jackson, Malik Jackson and Rodney McLeod, and white players Carson Wentz and Zach Ertz. NO FANS AT EAGLES GAMES?: DeSean Jackson, others have ideas to get 'soundtrack' of the fans in empty stadiums Wentz and Ertz released statements last week expressing their outrage at the police killing of Floyd. Eagles kicker Jake Elliott, who is white, tweeted about the meeting, saying that he was "truly heartbroken" and "devastated for my brothers and everyone directly affected by racism." As I sat in our virtual team meeting this morning and listened to some of my black teammates share their thoughts and experiences related to what is going on, I am truly heartbroken. Devastated for my brothers and everyone directly effected by racism in America. IT IS A PROBLEM — Jake Elliott (@jake_elliott22) June 1, 2020 "IT IS A PROBLEM and that is obvious," Elliott posted on Twitter. "Being a white male I’ll never be able to understand or relate but I stand behind you 100%. I am here to listen and learn in any way I can. Sports has always been a platform that has brought all races together and I am beyond thankful for that. I’ve learned a lot in The City of Brotherly Love and one thing for certain is that we are Stronger Together. I love you all. #BlackLivesMatter" Elliott wasn't alone. Center Jason Kelce took to social media Monday night, saying that he was so moved by what he heard, particularly from DeSean Jackson, that he decided to post something. Jason Kelce says he decided to post a message about the death of George Floyd and the protests after listening to DeSean Jackson and his teammates speak during Eagles virtual team meeting today pic.twitter.com/ytVGwiL3Hu — John Clark (@JClarkNBCS) June 1, 2020 "Until now, I've been holding off making a post regarding George Floyd and the protests going on around our country. The cynical side of me questions people's motives, and gets infuriated at people exploiting another man's death for attention or a social media trend. But after hearing some discussion today at our team meeting, in particular from DeSean Jackson, I now believe I have an obligation as an influential member of our community to share my thoughts ..." Eagles. Phillies. College and high school sports. Subscribe to delawareonline.com to get every story. Kelce continued: "Whether you are Republican, Democrat, Libertarian, Socialist, none of that should matter, and it frustrates me to see people making this incident party rhetoric. A man was killed! Only Officer Chauvin (the Minneapolis police officer who had his knee on the back of Floyd's neck for several minutes) knows what his intentions were, but what we know is another unarmed black man was killed. "Police officers are custodians of Justice, and serve to protect our community and its inhabitants. But this is not justice, this was not protection of our community, and there must be accountability ..." The Eagles as a team had not released any statements about Floyd's death or the days of protests that followed until Tuesday afternoon. Statement from Jeffrey Lurie, Chairman/CEO pic.twitter.com/Qwp7RZ9ofT — Philadelphia Eagles (@Eagles) June 2, 2020 "I have spent a great deal of time over the last few days reflecting, listening to my own heart, listening to others," Lurie began. "At times, I have too many words. At times, I have no words. But silence is not an option." He continued: "I am heartbroken and repulsed. There are no words strong enough to describe the horrific deaths and injustices that the black community continues to endure ... Systemic racism, discrimination, violence and oppression of minorities – it has been our past and it is our present. It remains who we are. We need to be honest with ourselves and own that." Lurie goes on to say that "many of us, myself included, cannot truly understand the burden of a weight we have never had to carry through life. We must at least try, as best we can, to imagine ourselves as the person who is hurting, neglected and oppressed." Lurie has always been among the more progressive NFL owners, often standing with former Eagles safety Malcolm Jenkins in his efforts to point out social injustices both in Philadelphia and around the country. Still, Lurie was mostly silent when Colin Kaepernick knelt during the national anthem in the 2016 season to bring awareness of police brutality. Kaepernick has not been signed by any team since the end of that season, and many players believe that he has been blackballed by the league. During that time, Jenkins would raise his fist during the anthem. Lurie supported that, saying Jenkins backed up his protests with his actions in the community. Martin Frank, sports reporter I cover the Philadelphia Eagles for the News Journal. I've learned that there's never an offseason for a team that has such a hold over people in Delaware. I enjoy bringing that passion for the Birds to readers, whether it's in-season or out, a Super Bowl run or the drama leading up to the draft. But I mostly enjoy bringing you the stories of the players, from the 53rd man on the roster to star quarterback Carson Wentz. Your support as a News Journal subscriber enables me to bring those stories to you. Contact Martin Frank at mfrank@delawareonline.com. Follow on Twitter @Mfranknfl.

title: Parsippany rally to demand justice for George Floyd
text: CLOSE Morris County residents end their march for George Floyd by dancing at Veteran's Memorial Park in Parsippany. Morristown Daily Record PARSIPPANY — The Patel family left a case of water outside their driveway, but feared it wouldn't be enough for the thousand people marching outside their home. "I have never seen this many people here before," a family member said. A protester walked by and approached the family. "This is the coolest thing Parsippany has ever done," he said as he grabbed a bottle of water before rejoining the march. Hundreds representing a number of generations gathered outside Parsippany High School on Tuesday to demand justice for George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man killed at the hands of Minneapolis Police Officer Derek Chauvin. The officer was fired from the Minneapolis Police Department and charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter. Protesters hold signs citing George Floyd's last words before he was killed by Minneapolis Police Officer Derek Chauvin. (Photo: Jessie Gomez) Parsippany residents and organizers Mitchell Petit-Frere, Jabari Jackson and Maurice Matthias said it was the first time they had ever planned a protest. "I had no idea this would become so big," Matthias said as he addressed the crowd of more than 1,200. "I can't just do nothing after seeing [George Floyd] die. This brings me to tears, because my father has to worry about me when I go for a run or for a drive. They worry about me because I'm a black man." Aside from justice for Floyd, organizers are demanding the implementation of an anti-racism curriculum in the Parsippany school district and anti-racism and de-escalation training for all township law enforcement officers. More: Randolph teens respond to racism with peaceful teach-in More: Will large George Floyd protests lead to a spike in NJ coronavirus cases? More: Hundreds gather in Morristown to demand justice for George Floyd and end police brutality With the help of Black Lives Matter Morristown and immigrant rights group Wind of the Spirit, protesters were told to stand in lines, ensuring that they were 6 feet apart. Wind of the Spirit Lead Organizer Brian Lozano led the first chant. "No Trump, no KKK, no racist USA," Lozano yelled. The crowd made its way down Vail Road as neighbors stood outside their homes and used their cellphones to record the swarms of protesters holding signs and chanting Floyd's name. A family watched through their window as Parsippany resident Chandu Bhorani knelt and raised his hands in front of protesters. "Look at this — it's beautiful! I'm here to support them," Bhorani said. On the sidelines, demonstrators kept off residents' lawn. Many residents left cases of water outside their homes for protesters to grab. Parsippany police officers waved at the crowd and a Morris County sheriff's officer high-fived a protester. A group of elderly residents sat outside Vail Manor, and one made the sign for peace with his fingers. A bystander thanked the crowd for marching outside his home. "Thank you, white folks," he said. Marchers made their way across Route 46 and into Veterans Memorial Park, filling an empty field. The marchers knelt and held their fists in the air as they chanted Floyd's name. The crowd heard from Wind of the Spirit Co-president Karol Ruiz, organizers and local clergy, including Pastor Charles Perez and the Rev. Sidney Williams, who said he was tired of thoughts and prayers. "We are tired of being sick and tired. Let freedom ring!" he said as the crowd cheered. Demonstrators hold their fists up in the air and kneel while chanting "George Floyd." (Photo: Jessie Gomez) Black Lives Matter Morristown co-founders T'Anna Kimbrough and Oliver Starnes spoke about the killings of Philando Castile, who was fatally shot by Minnesota police during a motor vehicle stop, and Alton Sterling, who was shot by police in Louisiana. Kimbrough recalled the last moments before Floyd's death. "He called for his momma! I can't breathe!" she yelled. A student read her school essay on racism. She talked about the moments of racism she experienced as a Muslim woman and about the killings of young black men. Those in the crowd teared up as they clapped for each speaker. By the end of the evening, protesters were encouraged to "keep the momentum going" and continue their education on racial injustices and police reforms. "Already, after Newark, Morristown, Jersey City, Paterson, Randolph and Parsippany rose up, already New Jersey is implementing reforms. There will be more. The people demand more. That's why we do what we do," Ruiz said. Jessie Gomez is a local reporter for DailyRecord.com and NorthJersey.com. For unlimited access to the most important news from your local community, please subscribe or activate your digital account today. Email: jgomez@gannettnj.com Twitter: @jessiereport Read or Share this story: https://www.dailyrecord.com/story/news/2020/06/02/parsippany-activists-want-peaceful-protest-george-floyd/3125095001/

title: Curfews remain in effect in Ewing, Hamilton, Lawrence and Trenton
text: The overnight curfews implemented in four Mercer County towns yesterday will be in effect again tonight. The curfews will be in force until further notice in the City of Trenton and Lawrence Township. The decision will be made on a day-by-day basis by officials in Ewing and Hamilton townships, according to authorities. The curfews, which are in effect between 7 p.m. through 6 a.m., were declared following an outbreak of violence and looting in Trenton and areas in the townships bordering the city on Sunday night and early Monday. A statement released today by Hamilton Mayor Jeff Martin through chief of staff Bianca Jerez stated: “While minor incidents occurred last evening, Hamilton Township will continue the regional curfew imposed yesterday in Trenton, Ewing and Lawrence.” Lawrence Township municipal manager Ken Nerwinski discussed the curfew on Facebook, and stated that the curfew is in effect until further notice. “There is no way to know when the protests and rioting will not pose a threat to our community,” he said. “We understand this is some pretty significant restrictions on personal liberties—especially now—so as soon as we can, the curfew will be lifted.”

title: George Floyd protests: Jon Bon Jovi pauses but doesn't hashtag for Blackout Tuesday
text: CLOSE Groups of people from coast to coast protest police brutality after George Floyd died in Minneapolis police custody. USA TODAY Jon Bon Jovi has paused, but he didn't hashtag. That's a good thing, say critics of the music industry-wide movement called “The Show Must Be Paused,” hashtag #thshowmustbepaused, that’s meant to reflect on the events of the past week related to the death of George Floyd and the issue of institutional racism in the United States. It's also known as “Blackout Tuesday.” Bon Jovi, like other participants, posted a blank black screen on his social media platforms on Tuesday. He included #theshowmustbepaused in the lower center of the screen. A man screams with emotion as he sees a policeman take a knee while hundreds protest the death of George Floyd next to the White House on May 31, 2020 in Washington, DC. (Photo: ROBERTO SCHMIDT, AFP via Getty Images) But Bon Jovi did not include a hashtag #blacklivesmatter, or any other hashtags, in the description or comments and that's a good thing, according to critics who say that doing so ties up the lines of communication of the Black Lives Movement in a time of urgency among national protests. “We know that's it no intent to harm but to be frank, this essentially does harm the message,” said Black Lives Matter activist Kenidra Woods on Twitter on Tuesday. “We use hashtag to keep ppl updated. PLS stop using the hashtag for black images!!” George Clinton, Queen Latifah, the Bouncing Souls, Gaslight Anthem, Everett Bradley of Bon Jovi, Nicole Atkins, Jarod Clemons, and Patti Scialfa of the E Street Band were Jersey artists who posted blank screens, or message of support, without the hashtag #blacklivesmatter by Tuesday afternoon. They joined fellow Jerseyans Jay Sean of Demarest, Danny Clinch, Phish and more in the movement. Want to keep up with the latest in the Jersey music scene? Subscribe to APP.com and download our mobile app today so you don't miss thing. Brianna Agyemang and Jamila Thomas of Atlantic Records founded the movement as “an initiative created by two Black women in music in observance of the long-standing racism and inequity that exists from the boardroom to the boulevard,” according to the group's mission statement. “We will not continue to conduct business as usual without regard to Black lives.” Yet, many are wary of potential negative effects of the movement, intentional for not. “What I hate about it is that it completely takes the focus off of what you can do and places it on what we apparently shouldn't be doing,” said Graham Alexander, head of Victor Records near Camden. “The biggest negative of this is that at a crucial moment when protesters and Black Lives Matter organizers need the lines of communication that Instagram and Twitter and Facebook affords them, now you have a glut of hashtag #blacklivesmatter posts that are keeping protesters from connecting together.” More: Washington, DC, police chief says more than 300 arrested in protests over George Floyd More: George Floyd protests: Jersey musicians will, and won't, take a pause on Blackout Tuesday More: George Floyd: P-Funk legend George Clinton shows what unity looks like as nation teeters Instead of posting, Alexander says musicians should “get down to the protest.” “Change doesn't happen if you just talk about,” Alexander said. This is not a time to be silent, said Kurt Reil of Highland Park's Grip Weeds, who was upset over the actions of police and federal agencies who released tear gas and fired rubber bullets at protesters near the White House on Monday, June 1. “When a president orders the military to assault its people, a line has been crossed,” said Reil of the action. “Then, after crossing said line, he goes to church and holds up a Bible for a cynical photo-op, effectively using the church as a partisan political prop. I'm outraged and ashamed at how far we have fallen as a nation, and I won't be silent today.” Organizers have heard. They released a statement on Tuesday afternoon stating that the “purpose was never to mute ourselves.” Chris Jordan, a Jersey Shore native, covers entertainment and features for the USA Today Network New Jersey. His multiple awards include recognition for stories on both Bruce Springsteen and “Jersey Shore.” Contact him at @chrisfhjordan; cjordan@app.com. Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/06/02/george-floyd-protests-jon-bon-jovi-pauses-but-doesnt-hashtag-blackout-tuesday/3127520001/

I’ve learned a lot in The City of Brotherly Love and one thing for certain is that we are Stronger Together. I love you all. #BlackLivesMatter" Elliott wasn't alone. Jason Kelce says he decided to post a message about the death of George Floyd and the protests after listening to DeSean Jackson and his teammates speak during Eagles virtual team meeting today pic.twitter.com/ytVGwiL3Hu — John Clark (@JClarkNBCS) June 1, 2020 "Until now, I've been holding off making a post regarding George Floyd and the protests going on around our country. The cynical side of me questions people's motives, and gets infuriated at people exploiting another man's death for attention or a social media trend. But after hearing some discussion today at our team meeting, in particular from DeSean Jackson, I now believe I have an obligation as an influential member of our community to share my thoughts ..." Eagles. Phillies. College and high school sports. Subscribe to delawareonline.com to get every story. Kelce continued: "Whether you are Republican, Democrat, Libertarian, Socialist, none of that should matter, and it frustrates me to see people making this incident party rhetoric. A man was killed! Only Officer Chauvin (the Minneapolis police officer who had his knee on the back of Floyd's neck for several minutes) knows what his intentions were, but what we know is another unarmed black man was killed. "Police officers are custodians of Justice, and serve to protect our community and its inhabitants. But this is not justice, this was not protection of our community, and there must be accountability ..." The Eagles as a team had not released any statements about Floyd's death or the days of protests that followed until Tuesday afternoon. Statement from Jeffrey Lurie, Chairman/CEO pic.twitter.com/Qwp7RZ9ofT — Philadelphia Eagles (@Eagles) June 2, 2020 "I have spent a great deal of time over the last few days reflecting, listening to my own heart, listening to others," Lurie began. "At times, I have too many words. At times, I have no words. But silence is not an option." He continued: "I am heartbroken and repulsed. There are no words strong enough to describe the horrific deaths and injustices that the black community continues to endure ... Systemic racism, discrimination, violence and oppression of minorities – it has been our past and it is our present. It remains who we are. We need to be honest with ourselves and own that." Lurie goes on to say that "many of us, myself included, cannot truly understand the burden of a weight we have never had to carry through life. We must at least try, as best we can, to imagine ourselves as the person who is hurting, neglected and oppressed." Lurie has always been among the more progressive NFL owners, often standing with former Eagles safety Malcolm Jenkins in his efforts to point out social injustices both in Philadelphia and around the country. Still, Lurie was mostly silent when Colin Kaepernick knelt during the national anthem in the 2016 season to bring awareness of police brutality. Kaepernick has not been signed by any team since the end of that season, and many players believe that he has been blackballed by the league. During that time, Jenkins would raise his fist during the anthem. Lurie supported that, saying Jenkins backed up his protests with his actions in the community. Martin Frank, sports reporter I cover the Philadelphia Eagles for the News Journal. I've learned that there's never an offseason for a team that has such a hold over people in Delaware. I enjoy bringing that passion for the Birds to readers, whether it's in-season or out, a Super Bowl run or the drama leading up to the draft. But I mostly enjoy bringing you the stories of the players, from the 53rd man on the roster to star quarterback Carson Wentz. Your support as a News Journal subscriber enables me to bring those stories to you. Contact Martin Frank at mfrank@delawareonline.com. Follow on Twitter @Mfranknfl.

title: PHOTOS: George Floyd protest in Willingboro
George Floyd protests: Jon Bon Jovi pauses but doesn't hashtag for Blackout Tuesday
text: CLOSE Groups of people from coast to coast protest police brutality after George Floyd died in Minneapolis police custody. USA TODAY Jon Bon Jovi has paused, but he didn't hashtag. That's a good thing, say critics of the music industry-wide movement called “The Show Must Be Paused,” hashtag #thshowmustbepaused, that’s meant to reflect on the events of the past week related to the death of George Floyd and the issue of institutional racism in the United States. It's also known as “Blackout Tuesday.” Bon Jovi, like other participants, posted a blank black screen on his social media platforms on Tuesday. He included #theshowmustbepaused in the lower center of the screen. A man screams with emotion as he sees a policeman take a knee while hundreds protest the death of George Floyd next to the White House on May 31, 2020 in Washington, DC. (Photo: ROBERTO SCHMIDT, AFP via Getty Images) But Bon Jovi did not include a hashtag #blacklivesmatter, or any other hashtags, in the description or comments and that's a good thing, according to critics who say that doing so ties up the lines of communication of the Black Lives Movement in a time of urgency among national protests. “We know that's it no intent to harm but to be frank, this essentially does harm the message,” said Black Lives Matter activist Kenidra Woods on Twitter on Tuesday. “We use hashtag to keep ppl updated. PLS stop using the hashtag for black images!!” George Clinton, Queen Latifah, the Bouncing Souls, Gaslight Anthem, Everett Bradley of Bon Jovi, Nicole Atkins, Jarod Clemons, and Patti Scialfa of the E Street Band were Jersey artists who posted blank screens, or message of support, without the hashtag #blacklivesmatter by Tuesday afternoon. They joined fellow Jerseyans Jay Sean of Demarest, Danny Clinch, Phish and more in the movement. Want to keep up with the latest in the Jersey music scene? Subscribe to APP.com and download our mobile app today so you don't miss thing. Brianna Agyemang and Jamila Thomas of Atlantic Records founded the movement as “an initiative created by two Black women in music in observance of the long-standing racism and inequity that exists from the boardroom to the boulevard,” according to the group's mission statement. “We will not continue to conduct business as usual without regard to Black lives.” Yet, many are wary of potential negative effects of the movement, intentional for not. “What I hate about it is that it completely takes the focus off of what you can do and places it on what we apparently shouldn't be doing,” said Graham Alexander, head of Victor Records near Camden. “The biggest negative of this is that at a crucial moment when protesters and Black Lives Matter organizers need the lines of communication that Instagram and Twitter and Facebook affords them, now you have a glut of hashtag #blacklivesmatter posts that are keeping protesters from connecting together.” More: Washington, DC, police chief says more than 300 arrested in protests over George Floyd More: George Floyd protests: Jersey musicians will, and won't, take a pause on Blackout Tuesday More: George Floyd: P-Funk legend George Clinton shows what unity looks like as nation teeters Instead of posting, Alexander says musicians should “get down to the protest.” “Change doesn't happen if you just talk about,” Alexander said. This is not a time to be silent, said Kurt Reil of Highland Park's Grip Weeds, who was upset over the actions of police and federal agencies who released tear gas and fired rubber bullets at protesters near the White House on Monday, June 1. “When a president orders the military to assault its people, a line has been crossed,” said Reil of the action. “Then, after crossing said line, he goes to church and holds up a Bible for a cynical photo-op, effectively using the church as a partisan political prop. I'm outraged and ashamed at how far we have fallen as a nation, and I won't be silent today.” Organizers have heard. They released a statement on Tuesday afternoon stating that the “purpose was never to mute ourselves.” Chris Jordan, a Jersey Shore native, covers entertainment and features for the USA Today Network New Jersey. His multiple awards include recognition for stories on both Bruce Springsteen and “Jersey Shore.” Contact him at @chrisfhjordan; cjordan@app.com.
