title: Over 500 march through downtown Paterson to protest George Floyd's death
themes: police, demonstrations and riots
text: CLOSE Protesters hold their placards during a protest over the death of George Floyd, photographed outside of Clifton City Hall in Clifton on 06/02/20. NorthJersey.com PATERSON – With anger but no violence, more than 500 people protested the police custody death of George Floyd by chanting, kneeling, singing and marching for three hours in the city's downtown on Tuesday night. The rally – which community leaders said was Paterson’s largest in the past decade – began on the steps of the historic city library on Broadway where protesters kneeled for eight minutes in honor of Floyd’s final moments pinned to the ground by police officers in Minneapolis. The throng then marched four blocks to Paterson police headquarters where tensions escalated as protesters pushed against barricades, cursing at cops standing out front. But the hostilities were defused when seven high-ranking police department members – including Chief Ibrahim “Mike” Baycora and Public Safety Director Jerry Speziale – kneeled in response to the crowd’s “Take a Knee” chant. Over 500 people gathered in downtown Paterson on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 to protest the murder of George Floyd. (Photo: Paterson Press) The rally next moved on to City Hall, clogging Market Street, where the group sang, “Lean on Me,” and listened to speeches decrying racism by law enforcement officers against African Americans. During the speeches, a few protesters posed for photos with cops and one man climbed atop a statute in City Hall plaza so that a 19th century political figure ended up holding a “F--- the police” sign. Throughout the event, Paterson police followed what officials said was a “non-adversarial” strategy as the cops assigned to the event mostly stayed in the background. Police officers in marked vehicles blocked cross streets to allow the crowd to march through the downtown district unimpeded by traffic, and even accommodated the protesters when they chose to take a route slightly different from the one set up by authorities. NYC: Peaceful protesters' message: 'Looters have nothing to do with us' Paterson Black Lives Matter leader Zellie Thomas, one of the rally’s organizers, told the crowd that justice won’t be served until authorities prosecute the three Minneapolis police officers who assisted former officer Derek Chauvin as he kneeled on Floyd’s neck. Chauvin has been charged with third degree murder and second-degree manslaughter. “He wasn’t resisting arrest, he was resisting death,” Thomas said. “Just as cops are trying to go home to their families, so are we” Thomas then urged the crowd to kneel for eight minutes to recall Floyd’s ordeal and people went down on one knee on the library steps, on the concrete sidewalk and on the asphalt of the street. When each minute that passed, Thomas led the protesters in a “George Floyd” chant and during the final 60 seconds they repeatedly chanted some of Floyd’s last words, “I can’t breathe.” About 10 people spoke from the microphone during the protest. Larry Hamm, an activist from Newark, told the crowd about a pending state Supreme Court case that may give civilian review boards in New Jersey unprecedented powers for overseeing the conduct of police. Alexis Miller, a recent Rutgers graduate from Paterson, asserted to the protesters that taxpayers should “divest” from police department funding. “Do you want to keep paying the police?” Miller asked. “No,” the crowd responded resoundingly. “Do you want to pay somebody who will kneel on your neck for eight minutes?” she continued. “No,” the crowded roared even louder. One speaker, Shombay Burton of Paterson, noted the large numbers of white people among the protesters. “I’m glad to see you’re here,” Burton said to them. “When you go back to your communities, speak out against the police terrorism that’s going on in the black community.” At the start of the protest, Paterson activist Bilak Hakeem warned the group against engaging in the violence and looting that has overshadowed the purpose of other rallies around the country. He said organizers wanted the Paterson event to remain peaceful, adding, “We have the street soldiers here to make sure it stays that way.” Indeed, several times during the event, the rally’s informal security staff admonished protesters who threw water bottles towards police officers. At one point, a protester climbed atop the roof of a Paterson police SUV and others in the crowded convince him to get off the vehicle. “We’re not getting off message,” Hakeem told the crowd. “We’re not tearing up where we live at.” Read or Share this story: https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/paterson-press/2020/06/02/500-march-through-downtown-paterson-protest-george-floyds-death/3130308001/

title: Clifton protest march travels to Passaic City Hall
themes: police, demonstrations and riots
text: CLOSE Protesters hold their placards during a protest over the death of George Floyd, photographed outside of Clifton City Hall in Clifton on 06/02/20. NorthJersey.com There was moment Tuesday around 6:30 p.m. when there was real concern about Clifton's protest at City Hall that things could have turned ugly when hundreds of attendees spontaneously began marching down Clifton Avenue. In back of many people's minds, there was a real fear that peaceful protest could turn violent as passions have been inflamed following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis last week and sparked a firestorm of protests and riots throughout the country. Clifton police said beforehand they had prepared for the worst. Extra officers were on hand and entrances to the front of city hall were blocked off by police and public works vehicles. There were even two cops stationed on the roof overlooking the crowd and technically the protest was in violation because no permit was secured. Story continues after gallery As it later turned out, the precautions were needed later in the night when police said there were some who confronted them by throwing rocks and bottles. Late in the evening, there was still reported to be a large crowd in front of Clifton City Hall. Before that happened, hundreds had already left the rally, which the organizers had initially hoped would be limited to city grounds. Paterson: Over 500 march through downtown to protest George Floyd's death NYC: Peaceful protesters' message to America: 'Looters have nothing to do with us' Passaic's Howard Pujols said he witnessed a group started yelling and marching and soon a throng was following them down Clifton Avenue. First Clifton's police and later Passaic's cleared a path for the marchers who chanted "Hands up. Don't shoot," and "No justice, no peace" as people lined up on the porches or peered out their apartment windows to watch. Thankfully, the march ended peacefully as the group marched down Clifton Avenue where they turned down Main Avenue where they headed to Passaic's City Hall. Passaic Police Chief Luis Guzman said the whole thing was unplanned. "We just did what Clifton did," he said, which was to let the marchers blow off steam as they marched three-plus miles from Clifton to Passaic. "I am impressed with these kids," the chief said. "I don't know that I would have the wisdom at that age." Passaic Mayor Hector Lora said he when he heard of the march, he encouraged police to let them go to Passaic's City Hall. Protest organizer Justin Rivera told the hundreds that gathered around 5 p.m. in front of City Hall the march had to be cancelled. They had no permit to march. He added he was initially concerned when the crowd broke away from the rally. He hesitated before joining them. "It turned out beautiful," Rivera said. "I am overwhelmed from emotions." Rivera sent out the message about the protest on Monday and people responded. By 5:15 there were hundreds of people most of them holding signs. People came from all over. Athos Nash drove up with his family from Westfield to participate. "We are trying to support and join in the the solidarity," he said. Things need to change, he said. He has an 18-year-old son and had the talk with him telling him how the realities can be for a person of color. Things like the need to be careful when driving and doubly so if you get pulled over. "It is a very important conversation," he said. The whole point of the rally is to see that attitudes, societal and law enforcement change. Local resident Shen Grant agreed that things need to change. A great grandmother, she has an 18-year-old grandson she worries about. When asked if she any significant change in attitudes over her lifetime she replied "no." "They got to stop holding down black men and black woman," Grant said. Story continues after gallery Kristiana Ocasio, a freshman at Clifton High, said she was there because she would like to see change. "It is a disgrace we have to do this for people of color to have justice," she said. While the march dispersed peacefully in Passaic, a crowd later gathered in Clifton and things turned violent for a bit, police said, but didn't provide much detail. Clifton police said they were working on report concerning the later incidents involving the rocks and bottles thrown so they didn't have any firm information to give out. Matt Fagan is a local reporter for NorthJersey.com. For unlimited access to the most important news from your local community, please subscribe or activate your digital account today. Email: fagan@northjersey.com Twitter: @fagan_nj Read or Share this story: https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/passaic/clifton/2020/06/02/george-floyd-clifton-nj-protest-march-travels-passaic-city-hall/3123366001/

title: Peaceful New York protesters' message to America: 'Looters have nothing to do with us'
themes: education and schools, police, demonstrations and riots, murders and attempted murders
text: CLOSE Healthcare workers clap and kneel in support of NYC protestors at Union Square on Tuesday, June 2, 2020. NorthJersey.com NEW YORK — If you’ve been watching the news lately, then you might believe that all the people protesting police brutality in Atlanta and Cleveland and Reno and New York City aren’t really protesting at all. On television, on Facebook and Twitter, the people we see are mostly skinny young men smashing windows and stealing electronics from Verizon stores. If you’ve only been watching the protests from afar, you probably have never heard from people like Eloise Paterson and her friend Ramona Cordero. So please allow me to make the introduction. You may know Paterson’s brother-in-law David, the former governor of New York. Eloise and Cordero both work as attorneys in Harlem. Paterson’s teenage sons attend Collegiate School and The Calhoun School, and Cordero’s daughter attends The Chapin School, three of the most expensive, most rigorous private high schools in this country. And every time their children leave home, Paterson and Cordero worry a police officer might murder them. “I’m terrified if my son just goes out for a jog,” said Paterson, 54. “I hope people realize that this isn’t about the looting. The looters have nothing to do with us. We are out here because we want our children to be safe.” All day on Tuesday, protesters repeated different versions of this message. They marched all over Manhattan, all day long and into the evening. From police headquarters in Foley Square they marched north to Union Square, up to Park Avenue, Lexington Avenue and all the way to Gracie Mansion on 88th Street, 10 miles of zigs and zags intended to keep thousands of people marching together while leaving the police guessing about where they all might go next. Story continues after gallery The speed of the march, and its convoluted path, also was designed to reduce opportunities for protesters and police officers to face off. For nine hours, the protesters and the police maintained this detente, with no windows broken, nor any bones. “We just want police to see black people as people,” said an organizer who gave his name as Jai. “We don’t want them to see a black person and get triggered into the fear response of fight or flight. We just want them to relax.” Few people were actually relaxed in Manhattan on Tuesday. The main protest march appeared to number about 6,500 people, who occupied a half-mile of pavement as it moved. Other marches occupied other streets and parks downtown. Every so often, protesters screamed expletives at police officers standing sentry behind steel barricades. MAAG: Peaceful protests in New York City marred by looters along Fifth Avenue MAAG: Missing quarantine? It's OK. As the world comes back online, many people miss the quiet When organizers of the march witnessed such interactions, they hustled over and began screaming instructions. “Do not engage! Do not engage!” yelled an organizer with a bullhorn, who refused to give her name. “Keep moving! We are not here to fight!” The converging and diverging marches snarled traffic all over the city. Some drivers minded intensely, and laid on their horns. Others enjoyed the opportunity to participate by accident. Paul Sanchez, an exterminator from Brooklyn, was driving to his next appointment at a town house in the East Village when his red work van became engulfed by the sea of protesters. The delay would make him late, but Sanchez didn’t mind. Instead he rolled down his windows and beeped his horn in time with the protesters’ chants. “This march must have just started. It didn’t show up on Waze,” he said. “I think it’s great. I hope it causes some change. All lives matter.” A few hours later, the march trapped Damien Yates in traffic. After dropping his mother off at her job as a nurse’s aide at New York Presbyterian Hospital in Queens, he was driving to his home in Irvington. Instead of getting angry at the delay, Yates climbed onto the roof of his Chrysler minivan, took off his purple Nike sneakers, and cheered the protesters on. “It’s a tragedy what happened to George Floyd,” said Yates, 38. “Protests are good, but nothing changes. Two weeks later, somebody else gets killed. I just hope this time it’s different.” The sea of protesters flows past Sophra Grill on 3rd Ave.  ⁦@northjersey⁩ pic.twitter.com/iIppjzlL7h — Christopher Maag (@Chris_Maag) June 2, 2020 On Monday night, as looters sacked stores on Fifth Avenue, there was no time for anyone to relax. Looters and onlookers ran, shouted expletives at police, then ran some more. Tuesday’s march was larger, and much more mellow. Even people who yelled angrily at police seemed to calm down quickly. Alex Langue led one of the angriest chants of the day. As the crowd marched east on 14th Street past Union Square, Langue looked police officers in the eye and raised his voice. “How do you spell murderer?” he yelled. “NYPD!” the crowd shouted back. “How do you spell racist?” “NYPD!” called the crowd. As the chant petered out, Langue was asked why he’d come. “George Floyd really was the last straw,” said Langue, 21, a student at New York University. “All we want is to live in peace.” At the southeast corner of Union Square, Langue and hundreds of other protesters stopped before a group of nurses gathered outside a Mount Sinai Hospital facility there. The nurses wore green scrubs and blue surgical masks to guard against COVID-19. Many held up their phones to shoot videos. Others held up their fists. All cheered. The protesters, struck by this show of solidarity, stopped and knelt. The nurses, about 50 in all, knelt, too. Story continues after gallery One of the nurses was Lori Howard. She grew up in Los Angeles, and the last time she marched in a protest was in 1991, after police were videotaped beating Rodney King. Howard said she’s too scared to protest this time — between her age and the prevalence of COVID, she doesn’t think it’s safe. But she was happy to cheer the protesters on. “Every time my brother stepped out of our neighborhood when he was a teenager, he got stopped and harassed” by police in Los Angeles, said Howard, 50, who lives in Brooklyn. “And now I see that same type of police behavior here in New York. So yes, I think it’s absolutely great what these kids are doing.” It wasn’t just kids who marched, of course. Jai, the organizer, declined to give his age, but his mustache and goatee were silver and coated in sweat when he lowered his N95 mask. He kept imploring the younger protesters around him to slow down and keep the massive crowd together, partly for strategic reasons and partly because he was getting tired. “Please! People in the front, you’ve got to slow down. Please!” he said. “If we get separated, the police will cut us off. And we have to give the slower people time to catch up.” Paterson and Cordero seemed content to dawdle along toward the rear. Paterson waved a T-shirt printed with Floyd’s face and the words “Justice for George Floyd.” When people sitting on the sidewalk at 54th Street complimented her on the shirt, Paterson was more than happy to stop for a rest. “I don’t want our message and the looters to get mixed up,” she said. “We have great respect for police officers. Several members of my family are police officers. But the treatment of people of color as second-class citizens has got to stop.” Christopher Maag is a columnist for NorthJersey.com. To get unlimited access to his unique perspective on New Jersey’s most interesting people and experiences, please subscribe or activate your digital account today. Email: maag@northjersey.com Twitter: @Chris_Maag Read or Share this story: https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-york/2020/06/02/george-floyd-new-york-protesters-looters-have-nothing-do-us/3125968001/

title: 'Keansburg stands with George Floyd': Police and protesters keep the peace
themes: blacks, police, demonstrations and riots, police brutality and misconduct

title: How a City Once Consumed by Civil Unrest Has Kept Protests Peaceful
themes: politics and government, police, demonstrations and riots, police brutality and misconduct
text: The director of the Newark Police Department, Anthony F. Ambrose, who is white, made a tactical decision not to position police officers in military-style gear along the route. And members of the Newark Community Street Team, an entity formed six years ago to de-escalate violence in the city, and other community groups were deployed throughout the crowd to try to isolate those intent on destruction. But in more than a dozen interviews, protesters and city leaders said it was the potent determination of predominantly young African-American members of the Newark community — many of whom have had past run-ins with the police — who stood in the way of widespread destruction. “It was a combination of anarchists and opportunists waiting for a window to be broken so they could go in and grab something,” said Aqeela Sherrills, the director of the 50-person street team. “But I tell you: The community wasn’t having it.” At one point during the march, protesters lit an American flag on fire in the middle of Broad Street as a young man used a bat to strike a window of a Dunkin’ Donuts store, witnesses said. “He hit the window one time and there was like 20 people standing in front of him,” Mr. Sherrills said. As protesters whom he called “provocateurs” moved toward buildings owned by Prudential Financial, the city’s most prominent business anchor, which has maintained a presence in Newark for 145 years, a similar standoff was defused, he said. James Wright Jr., a Newark resident and a student at Boston University, said he initially was not planning to march. But Mr. Wright, who is black, decided it was important to be heard.

title: New Jersey announces law enforcement reforms in wake of protests against police brutality
themes: blacks, police, demonstrations and riots, police brutality and misconduct
text: Lt. Zack James of the Camden County Metro Police Department marches along with demonstrators in Camden, N.J., to protest the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. | April Saul via AP New Jersey announces law enforcement reforms in wake of protests against police brutality New Jersey Attorney General Gurbir Grewal on Tuesday announced several initiatives designed to increase trust between police and the communities they serve, including an expansion of the state‘s use-of-force database and a proposed licensing program for law enforcement. The measures, detailed during Gov. Phil Murphy’s daily briefing in Trenton, come as residents in New Jersey and across the country take to the streets to protest police brutality in the wake of the death of George Floyd, a 46-year-old black man who died while in police custody in Minneapolis after an officer pinned him down with his knee until he stopped breathing. Advertisement “The pain and fatigue felt by many in our black and brown communities is real and it is palpable,” Murphy said. “It is the pain and fatigue of decades, generations — at this point, centuries — of inequality and systemic racism. It is pain that has eroded the ties that bind some of our communities and the men and women whose sworn duty it is to protect them.” As part of restoring those ties, Grewal outlined steps the state will take as part of the “Excellence in Policing” initiative launched late last year to foster increased accountability, transparency and professionalism in law enforcement. One of the steps will be to expand the state’s use-of-force database, adding police departments that don’t yet have access by July 1. By the end of the year, New Jersey will use information from the database to update its use-of-force policies for the first time in two decades to “reflect the values of today,” Grewal said. The state will also launch a pilot program in Paterson, Trenton, Atlantic City and Millville to expand crisis intervention team training, in which law enforcement partners with mental health professionals to more safely respond to crises involving mental health. Plus, New Jersey will establish an incident response team to “serve a vital role in defusing tensions and healing a community after a moment of collective trauma,” Grewal said. The team, which will exist within the Division of Civil Rights, will deploy to areas following major civil rights incidents. Grewal also requested that the Police Training Commission implement a statewide licensing program for all law enforcement. “Just as we license doctors, nurses, lawyers … we must ensure that all officers meet a baseline level of professionalism,” Grewal said, adding that those who don’t meet the standard cannot work in New Jersey. The latest updates on law enforcement reforms come amid protests held across the country since last week’s arrest and subsequent death of Floyd. A bystander’s video of Floyd’s encounter with Minneapolis police officers, which sparked national outrage, showed one of the officers, Derek Chauvin, holding his knee on Floyd’s neck as he repeatedly pleads for air. Floyd eventually becomes motionless and is put onto a gurney by paramedics. Chauvin has been charged with third-degree murder. Three other officers involved in the incident have been fired, but not charged. “Mr. Floyd’s death reminds us that our country has a long way to go, not only in healing our country’s racial divides, but also in addressing the systemic and implicit biases that affect all Americans,” Grewal said. “To the thousands of New Jerseyans who assembled peacefully this week … we share your anger and we share your commitment to change.” While some cities, including New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles and Washington, D.C., have seen demonstrations turn violent, with attacks on officers and widespread looting, protests in New Jersey — especially in Newark and Camden Monday night — remained mostly peaceful and without incident. Downtown Trenton saw vandalism, looting and attacks on police Monday, and protests in Asbury Park became chaotic, as well. Overall, 12 people were arrested Monday night, State Police Superintendent Patrick Callahan said during Tuesday‘s briefing, but it was not clear whether that total included the arrest of an Asbury Park Press reporter, the charges against whom were later dropped. Nearly two dozen protests are planned across the state on Tuesday. “We respect completely the folks who want to protest peacefully,” Murphy said. “Let’s keep it that way.”

title: Protests over George Floydu2019s death planned across N.J. for upcoming week
themes: police, demonstrations and riots, police brutality and misconduct
text: Protests against police brutality following the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis are planned throughout New Jersey over the next few days. Saturday marked the first protests in New Jersey, with thousands of people marching through the streets of Newark chanting ‘No justice, no peace!’ and ‘I can’t breathe’ in a peaceful demonstration against racism and police brutality. The protests continued into Sunday, with police officers in Atlantic City and Trenton kneeling with protesters, while in Camden there was a peaceful protest with police, including Police Chief Joseph D. Wysocki, walking side-by-side with demonstrators. Sunday evening came reports of groups taking to the streets of Trenton and Atlantic City to smash window, loot stores and set vehicles on fire. Some communities that saw protests earlier in the day, including Glassboro, Pitman, Rahway and Linden, did not report in violence afterward. A protest in Asbury Park on Monday remained peaceful for about four hours, but tensions rose and a melee later broke out, with several protesters arrested and a police officer injured. Among the protests planned in New Jersey this week: NOTE: NJ.com has removed information about a protest in Summit, Short Hills and New Providence Thursday because it could not be verified Protests over Floyd’s death spread across the country into early Sunday, spilling into New York City, Atlanta, Detroit, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, Portland and Washington, D.C. Four police officers who were at the scene of Floyd’s death have been fired, and one, Derek Chauvin was charged with third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in the case. In New Jersey, all 21 N.J. county prosecutors offices call images of George Floyd death “deeply disturbing” and said police are not exempt from law. In a statement Saturday, New Jersey State PBA President Pat Colligan condemned Chauvin and the four officers also at the scene. “The actions that we saw on video are contrary to all our training and does harm to the good reputation of the overwhelming number of brave men and women in law enforcement trying to do their job in an honorable and lawful manner," Colligan said. “Nobody in law enforcement can look at that video and justify the actions of those officers.” Our journalism needs your support. Please subscribe today to NJ.com. Andrew Koob may be reached at akoob@njadvancemedia.com.

title: George Floyd Protests In NJ Continue- 'Police Brutality Ends Now' - Newark, NJ Patch
themes: blacks, demonstrations and riots
text: NEWARK, NJ — It's been less than a week since George Floyd died in the custody of police in Minneapolis, Minnesota. But since then, a massive wave of anger, outrage – and hope – has swept the nation, including New Jersey. Protests were held in cities and towns throughout New Jersey, and Gov. Phil Murphy praised the crowds for maintaining social distance and wearing masks amid the coroanvirus pandemic, while also maintaining civility. "The unity we displayed this weekend in New Jersey showed the world that we are ready to be the ones to help lead the way," Murphy said. "New Jersey is ready to fight the sin of racism and the stain it has left on our state and nation." There were some reports of vandalism and violence. In Trenton, the protests began peacefully before some bystanders said a different group moved in and set a police car on fire, according to The Trentonian. See related article: Violence Follows Peaceful Protest In Trenton Over Floyd Killing There were also reports of looting after a peaceful protest in Atlantic City on Sunday. See related article: Atlantic City Mayor Condemns Looting, Addresses Police Brutality However, the majority of protests that took place in New Jersey were largely violence-free, reports say. In Asbury Park, protesters gathered against "systemic racial injustice and police brutality." Organizers asked people to wear a mask and practice social distancing. Patch was covering the scene live: Asbury Park Protests For George Floyd On Monday (WATCH LIVE) In Newark, local officials were praised for joining the thousands of protesters who filled Market Street on Saturday to protest police brutality. Signs listed the names of black men and women who died at the hands of police.  "I think for [them] to hold a rally is appropriate," Mayor Ras Baraka said. "In fact, people would have thought something was wrong if there was no rally to have." The Camden County Police Department joined members of the community for a unity walk on Saturday. One widely shared image showed Camden County Police Chief Joe Wysocki marching with protesters and holding a sign that reads, "Standing in Solidarity."  See related article: Camden Offers Picture Of Police Unity After George Floyd's Death The protests stem from the May 25 incident involving Derek Chauvin, a white Minneapolis police officer who kneeled on Floyd's neck for several minutes during an arrest as three of his fellow officers stood by. and bystanders pleaded with him to stop. Floyd, 46, who is black, was captured on video pleading for his life and saying "I can't breathe." It's a harrowing lament that's been picked up by protesters decrying his death as yet another example of police brutality. Last weekend, protests in Floyd's name took place across the U.S. Although some states saw rioting and arrests, the rallies in New Jersey were overwhelmingly peaceful, aside from a handful of isolated incidents. In Morristown, a Black Lives Matter vigil drew mourners from across Morris County. Morris Township Chief of Police Mark DiCarlo said he felt responsible to acknowledge the "horrific incident" and offered condolences to the family, friends and relatives of George Floyd on behalf of his department. "We do not condone those actions and behaviors," he said. "As an agency, we have provided tools and equipment to our officers in order to have alternatives to the use of deadly force, as well as teach de-escalation techniques." See related article: Morristown Vigil Honoring George Floyd Remains Peaceful Three peaceful protests were held in Somerset County over the weekend in Somerville, Manville and Franklin. Protesters in Manville were captured on video as they marched along North Main Street holding signs and chanting "I can't breathe."  In Princeton, Courtney Navas, a local police officer, stood in solidarity with protesters on Nassau Street on Sunday. The peaceful protest consisted of residents holding signs stating "Stand Against Racism," "Sooo.. it IS ok to Kneel? (I Can't Breathe)," "It IS okay to be white... it ain't okay to be racist! END stupidity," and "Honk To End Racism." See related article: Princeton Police Stand With Protesters Over George Floyd's Death More than 300 residents of Haddonfield and the neighboring communities gathered in a peaceful display of solidarity, which included support from the Haddonfield Police Department.  See related article: Haddonfield Police, Residents Show Unity After George Floyd Death The Long Branch community came together Sunday for a peaceful protest against the killing of George Floyd. "This is what it looks like when you have trust, love and respect for each other — law enforcement and its community members," one participant said. In Bloomfield, the town saw a "very peaceful, productive protest," police stated. "Now more than ever, it is critical that we come together as a community to chart a path toward equity and justice," Councilwoman Wartyna Davis said during a virtual vigil on Sunday evening. Rallies in other parts of New Jersey, including Englewood and Paterson, were also predominantly violence-free, reports say. See related article: Englewood, Paterson Protests Remain Peaceful The protests continued on Monday with a rally in Jersey City. As of about 1:45 p.m., there appeared to be dozens of people outside the south precinct, holding signs as officers barricaded the door. Among the protesters was Mayor Steve Fulop, who said he was there "in solidarity." See related article: Jersey City Protesters Rally At South Precinct, Mayor In Crowd Story continues below MORE PROTESTS PLANNED IN NJ  Community activists and organizers are trying to keep the momentum from last weekend going with more rallies and protests in New Jersey. Here's where some are slated to take place. JERSEY CITY The Black Men United coalition tweeted that a protest is planned for Jersey City on Monday. The group was asking interested participants to contact them directly via social media for the location of the rally. Another protest is being planned for Jersey City on Saturday, June 6 from 4 to 9 p.m. in front of City Hall at 280 Grove Street, an eponymously named Twitter page says. ATTENTION! JERSEY CITY, NEW JERSEY WILL BE PROTESTING AT CITY HALL. WE WILL NOT SIT BACK ANY LONGER. REFER TO THE FLYER FOR DATE, TIME, AND LOCATION. RETWEET. LIKE. SCREENSHOT AND SHARE. POLICE BRUTALITY ENDS NOW. #BlackLivesMatter #protests #JusticeForGeorgeFloyd pic.twitter.com/MDdLOKnMDI — JERSEY CITY PROTEST 6/6 (@Isthatchance) May 30, 2020 HOBOKEN Nearby in Hoboken, a protest is being planned at Maxwell Park Place on Friday, June 5 at 1 p.m. That poster subsequently encouraged participants to wear masks, "maintain social distancing protocol," and bring first aid.  See related article: Hoboken Mayor Makes Statement On George Floyd To all my Hudson County/NJ mutuals, please circulate this flyer so we can put solidarity to action. #BlackLivesMatter pic.twitter.com/FuHMbRV1lq — G(@gaaabycx) May 28, 2020 KEANSBURG, OLD BRIDGE A gathering is planned in Keansburg on Tuesday. Protesters marching for justice for George Floyd say they will meet at 6 p.m. on the baywalk across from La Playa Mexican restaurant. The same group is holding a protest at Lombardi Field in Old Bridge at 1 p.m. on Thursday, June 4. See related article: Protest Planned For Keansburg Tuesday, Old Bridge Later This Week NEWARK, OTHER PROTESTS  Another Twitter user posted that there are rallies in the works on the following dates in Jersey City, Asbury Park, Newark, Middletown, Carteret, Union, Hoboken, Perth Amboy, North Bergen and West Orange.  At least one of the rallies, the June 5 event in Perth Amboy, has since been discredited by organizers. Another of the events, Tuesday's rally in Middletown, has been canceled and rescheduled for Keansburg at 6 p.m. the same day. Patch was unable to immediately confirm the authenticity of the following events: Monday, June 1 – Jersey City, Asbury Park (5 p.m.) Jersey City, Asbury Park (5 p.m.) Tuesday, June 2 – Jersey City (vigil, 6 p.m.) Jersey City (vigil, 6 p.m.) Thursday, June 4 – Carteret (4 p.m.) Carteret (4 p.m.) Friday, June 5 – Union (1 p.m.), Hoboken (1 p.m.), Newark (unconfirmed), Perth Amboy (2 p.m.) Union (1 p.m.), Hoboken (1 p.m.), Newark (unconfirmed), Perth Amboy (2 p.m.) Saturday, June 6 – North Bergen (3 p.m.), West Orange (12:30 p.m.), Jersey City (4 p.m.) Send feedback and correction requests to eric.kiefer@patch.com  Learn more about posting announcements or events to your local Patch site. Sign up for Patch email newsletters.

title: Toms River Police March With George Floyd Protesters - Toms River, NJ Patch
themes: blacks, hurricanes and tropical storms, demonstrations and riots
text: TOMS RIVER, NJ — Joined by Toms River and Ocean County law enforcement, a couple hundred demonstrators marched to the Ocean County Courthouse on Tuesday in a peaceful protest over the death of George Floyd. Toms River Police Chief Mitch Little, Ocean County Prosecutor Bradley Billhimer and members of their respective agencies joined the group, which chanted "Say his name — George Floyd," "Black Lives Matter," "Hands up — Don't Shoot" and "I can't breathe" as they marched from Kohl's in the Toms River Shopping Center, down Main Street to Washington Street. "This is not about black or white, it's everyone vs. racism," said Katrina Garcia, a Toms River South graduate who was one of the march's organizers. "The fight for civil rights applies to everyone." The protest later moved to Route 37, where demonstrators stood along the highway chanting and cheering as passing cars and trucks honked in support. The number in the group ebbed and flowed as temperatures heated up, and at one point, the group along Route 37 kneeled, single fists raised in the air. Demonstrators wave signs and cheer along Route 37 in Toms River as passing cars honk in support of the protest over the death of George Floyd. (Karen Wall photo) At the courthouse, the group formed lines on either side of the sidewalk leading to the historic portion of the courthouse. There, Jamaal Holmes, a Toms River North graduate who was one of the organizers, thanked Little and Billhimer, before urging everyone in attendance to take a knee. "It was important for everyone to see law enforcement in Ocean County stands with these demonstrators and supports peaceful protests," Billhimer said afterward. "Standing in solidarity should not be controversial; it's crucial for the future generations," Garcia said. "Change stems from within, which is why even communities that have not experienced police brutality are coming together to stand against it." Pastor Michael Mazer also addressed the group, offering prayer. "Your word teaches us that if part of the body burns the whole body burns. Let us feel the pain that the black community has at this moment and let us bring healing not only to the black community, but to the entire community that we will no longer look at people as inferior but rather that we are children of God." Katrina Garcia (in white shirt) addresses the crowd in front of the Ocean County Courthouse. (Karen Wall photo) The protest was one of dozens around the country and around New Jersey that have arisen in the wake of the death of Floyd, 46, who died after a Minneapolis police officer kneeled on his neck on May 25 after being arrested following a 911 call reporting a counterfeit $20 bill.  Derek Chauvin, the police officer who was seen in multiple videos kneeling on Floyd's neck for more than 8 minutes before he died, was fired and has been charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter. Three other Minneapolis police officers involved in the incident have been fired but no charges have yet been filed against them. Before the protest, Billhimer addressed rumors that swirled on social media about plans for violence in Toms River, saying they have not been substantiated. "We are expecting a peaceful protest/gathering," Billhimer said in a statement issued Monday night. "We stand in solidarity with those that wish to protest peacefully. We are aware of rumors circulating on social media regarding this protest/gathering and there is no evidence at this time to support those rumors." Garcia reminded the marchers that they need to set an example for the younger generations, who are watching these events unfold all over the country. "This march is for us to be heard and seen and to lead by example," she said. "For it to be effective, we must remain focused and safe. To be taken seriously, we must remain peaceful." Even as the protest moved to Route 37, it was peaceful into the afternoon. Toms River police had a very visible presence for the morning march, and police and members of the Ocean County Sheriff's Department were in the parking lot of the Toms River Shopping Center monitoring the Route 37 group. "It is our priority to maintain the safety of our entire community while allowing a peaceful demonstration," Toms River police said in a statement Monday. "Over the years we have built an amazing relationship with our community. We stand with you together."  The rumors have claimed people would be bused in from outside the area to cause damage and engage in violence similar to what has been seen in some cities across the country. Five businesses — four at the Toms River River Shopping Center and one downtown — boarded up windows at their stores. But others operated with seemingly little concern, moving sale items out onto the sidewalk for the day. Have a news tip? Email karen.wall@patch.com Follow Toms River Patch on Facebook.

title: After hours of peace, Asbury Park protest ends in arrests, officer injured
themes: police, demonstrations and riots
text: Several protesters were arrested and a police officer was injured during a melee in Asbury Park Monday at the end of a protest prompted by the police killing of George Floyd a week ago in Minnesota. The protest had been peaceful for four hours after the 5 p.m. start, with officers from multiple nearby departments at times kneeling with the demonstrators in support. As the night wore on, protesters had heated verbal exchanges with officers outside the police department headquarters. Tensions arose when officers in riot gear, at around 9:30 p.m., began attempting to physically disperse the remaining 200 or so protesters outside the department, in keeping with an 8 p.m. curfew announced earlier in the day by Asbury Park officials. Officers yelled “back up” and “time to go” while approaching protesters who chanted “no justice, no peace.” A smaller group continued walking down Bangs Avenue past the post office as an advancing police line followed. Some demonstrators threw rocks at the police. Several protesters were arrested a police officer was taken to Jersey Shore University Medical Center in Neptune with a head injury. Other officers rushed him from the scene with a bloody head wound. It was not immediately clear how he was injured. A reporter for the Asbury Park Press, Gustavo Martínez Contreras, was arrested while streaming a video on Twitter of police clearing the street, the newspaper reported. NJ Advance Media journalists also witnessed the arrest. While filming the arrest of a protester, an officer approached Martínez Contreras and yelled, “you’re under arrest” and “get your f---ing hands behind your back," the video shows. He later tweeted that he was released from custody after being issued a summons. I was arrested during the protest against police brutality in Asbury Park earlier tonight. I was just released from the Belmar PD headquarters with a summons for failing to obey an order to disperse. — Gustavo Martinez (@newsguz) June 2, 2020 It was at least the third New Jersey protest over the killing of Floyd that started out peacefully, only to turn confrontational at night. Dozens of other protests were held throughout the state over the weekend without incident. Atlantic City and Trenton imposed curfews starting Monday, after peaceful protests in both cities on Sunday afternoon were followed by looting and damage in the evening. Gustavo Martínez Contreras, a reporter for the Asbury Park Press, is taken into police custody during the protest Monday June 1, 2020.Andrew Mills | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com Our journalism needs your support. Please subscribe today to NJ.com.

title: Singh wants Trump to send troops into New Jersey  Globe
themes: politics and government, elections, police, demonstrations and riots
text: Republican Senate candidate Hirsh Singh said he’d support President Donald Trump approving military operations within the state of New Jersey. “I agree with President Trump. We are a nation of laws. Law and Order must be restored. We must protect peaceful protestors, law enforcement, businesses, innocent bystanders, and personal property,” Singh said in a post on Facebook. “If Gov. Phil Murphy continues to fail to protect the aforementioned and fails to deploy the National Guard, I support President Donald J. Trump invoking the Insurrection Act of 1807 to send in the US Military and Protect America.” Protests against police brutality have sprung up across the nation in the wake of the police killing of George Floyd. Floyd, who is black, died after now-former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin pinned his neck with a knee for nearly nine minutes. New Jersey has had its share of protests, and while most have been peaceful, protests in Trenton and Atlantic City turned riotous on Sunday, and a protest in Asbury Park that remained peaceful throughout Monday turned violent after officers in riot gear attempted to enforce an 8 p.m. curfew. Gov. Phil Murphy said his office was aware of 21 protests planned for Tuesday.

title: People march peacefully with police during daytime protests in N.J. towns
themes: blacks, police, demonstrations and riots
text: A day of peaceful protests continued in a few New Jersey towns on Tuesday as demonstrators gathered to call for an end to police brutality after the death of George Floyd last week. A mid-morning march was held in Toms River where police walked alongside residents from a shopping center on Route 37 down to the Ocean County courthouse, chanting “I can’t breathe,” according to video from the scene. Further south along the Jersey Shore, people gathered in Somers Point and marched toward Ocean City over the 9th Street Bridge Tuesday and ended at the public safety building where police officers spoke to the crowd, took a knee with fellow protestors and joined them in a nine-minute moment of silence. “Black lives matter. All lives matter,” said Michelle “Kola” Hunt, a Somers Point resident who was marching across the bridge Tuesday morning. “Right is right and wrong is wrong. It’s time to take a stand, a peaceful stand, which we’re out here doing now. Hopefully, it stays like this.” The marches stem from those who are protesting against the death of Floyd, a Minneapolis man who died after an officer, Derek Chauvin, placed a knee on his neck, hampering Floyd’s ability to breath. Chauvin and three other officers from the Minneapolis Police Department were fired, and Chauvin was charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter. Demonstrations have sprung up across the county, calling for an end to police brutality. The dozens of demonstrations held in New Jersey have for the most part been peaceful, however there have also been looting and other acts of violence and vandalism that occurred in Atlantic City, Trenton and again in Asbury Park on Monday night that have kept police departments and some local businesses on edge. Ocean City Mayor Jay Gillian said in a statement Monday that the police were coordinating with several other agencies and "preparing for any potential situation.” Windows of some storefronts appeared to be boarded up in Somers Point ahead of the demonstration. Police gather in the parking lot of a liquor store in Somers Point as a protest gets underway. Windows were boarded up of nearby businesses as a precaution after vandalism and looting has occurred after other protests in New Jersey and across the country. Cars are still honking their horns in support pic.twitter.com/VSnVcrkbk5 — Chris Franklin (@cfranklinnews) June 2, 2020 Protestors wore masks while carrying signs reading “No Justice, No Peace” and “Black Lives Matter” as they marched across the bridge on the pedestrian walkway into the Jersey Shore town. Cars honked to show support as they traveled across the bridge into Ocean City. Police officers on bikes rode alongside the demonstrators. The crowd continued over the causeway and into Ocean City, down West Avenue — more than a 2.5-mile walk. Multiple teachers were seen in the crowd. One carried a sign that said “My black students matter," and another’s read “teachers know how much black lives matter.” In Ocean City, the march continued to the front of the police station where laid face-first on the ground saying “I can’t breathe” and “mama” as well as reciting the names of people who were killed by police. In another moment, they all sat in complete silence. Meanwhile, police looked on quietly until the joined in and spoke to the crowd. “I get it from both sides. I understand both sides,” said Ty Rolls, an Ocean City police sergeant who is black. His voice cracked with emotion as he spoke. “The problem is it’s a lack of education. We don’t teach the real American history. We don’t teach about the ancestry of black people and black leaders and what they did to get here. If they did what they did and it changed the world, then why are we here now? So apparently, the peaceful protests back then‚ the riots back then — they didn’t work. But this is what I love. " Mama" is being yelled once again. pic.twitter.com/SGbN4Xi1ak — Chris Franklin (@cfranklinnews) June 2, 2020 It was one of 21 demonstrations that were to take place on Tuesday, according to State Police Colonel Patrick J. Callahan, who said during Gov. Phil Murphy’s press briefing on Tuesday that police were monitoring all of them. On Monday, protesters took to the streets of Rio Grande. Online videos showed the protesters were chanting phrases such as “Black Lives Matter” and “I can’t breathe” while situated near the corner of Route 47 and Route 9. Demonstrations were peaceful in Asbury Park until about 9:30 p.m., when police in riot gear tried to disperse crowds that were in violation of an 8 p.m. curfew. Protestors march across the bridge into Ocean City, New Jersey on Tuesday. Thank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. Please consider supporting NJ.com with a voluntary subscription. Tell us your coronavirus story or send a tip here. Chris Franklin may be reached at cfranklin@njadvancemedia.com.

title: In N.J., progress is being made in policing. But u2018we still have a long, long way to go.u2019
themes: blacks, police, demonstrations and riots
text: Police officers embracing protestors. A police chief leading a march. And in an act of solidarity, both protestors and officers taking a knee. These are the images emanating from protests across New Jersey in the wake of George Floyd’s death at the hands of Minneapolis police. It’s in stark contrast to the destruction happening in larger cities across America, where looting and burning buildings and police cars have become a nightly routine. But that hardly means New Jersey doesn’t have its own law enforcement issues, officials and experts concede. Community leaders and law enforcement experts say more training and statewide use-of-force standards are needed. They also call for black communities to have a voice in the outcomes of investigations involving police-related deaths. “What happened there is reflective of the entirety of policing, so definitely New Jersey too,” said The Rev. Charles Boyer, a pastor and founder of the civil rights group Salvation and Social Justice, of the death of Floyd. Gov. Phil Murphy, speaking Monday at his daily coronavirus briefing, also acknowledged that much more needs to be done in the Garden State to upend systemic racism. “Racism exists here,” Murphy said. “It has held back generations of black and brown citizens, and still threatens the generations to come — inequalities in economic mobility, health care support, accessible housing and educational opportunities. And on and on and on.” The Force Report, a 2018 NJ Advance Media investigation of police use of force in New Jersey, found that a black person was three times more likely to face use of force than someone who is white. In Millville in South Jersey, black people faced use of force at more than six times the rate of whites. In South Orange, it was nearly 10 times. In Lakewood, it was an astronomical 22 times. Both Boyer and Bruce S. Morgan, the president of the New Brunswick area chapter of the NAACP, commended the state Attorney General’s Office for making improvements in police accountability. All investigations of officer-involved shootings are now handled by the attorney general, which police reform advocates lobbied for for years. “We still have a long, long way to go,” Boyer said. The criminal justice system “has proven to be a massive failure, and the only thing it succeeds at is to be racist,” he said. To change the system, Boyer says, black communities need to have more of a say in the outcomes of investigations involving deaths at the hands of the police. He said there needs to be more accountability when officers fail to turn on their body-worn cameras and officers who use lethal force need to be questioned immediately. “There can no longer be the police coverup system we have in place now,” Boyer said. Protesters shake hands with police after thousands of people assembled and marched in Asbury Park on Monday, June 1, 2020 to protest the police killing of George Floyd a week ago in Minnesota.Andrew Mills | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com Jon Shane, a retired Newark police captain who teaches at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York, said more training on the use of physical force is needed in police departments. He said there also needs to be a standardized use-of-force policy across all departments in New Jersey. The Attorney General’s Office has promulgated standards, he said, but departments adopt their own practices. “The business model itself has been created around a 24-hour, catch-all agency that assumes the responsibility for various services after hours,” Shane said. “Policing has such a wide variety of things to train on that you can spend an enormous amount of time and money on training. It would be so oppressively expensive and costly, you wouldn’t be able to maintain it. So you have to pick what you’re going to train.” Morgan, the NAACP president, agrees more training needs to be done, especially implicit biased training. But he also said it boils down to police simply using the tools they already have. “There’s really no need to re-event the wheel,” he said. “Just do the right thing.” One of the images from the weekend protests garnering attention in New Jersey is that of Camden County Police Chief Joseph Wysocki walking alongside protestors in the city of Camden. Wysocki said the culture of his police department is built around community policing. “Community policing for us is not a check-off-the-box,” he said. “It’s in our culture.” In August 2019, the department also introduced a use-of-force policy that’s more restrictive than most in the state. Police are instructed to use their service weapons and force as a “last resort.” Wysocki said cops are also told to intervene if they see a fellow officer doing the wrong thing, and that officers also critique each other when they review body-worn camera footage of interactions with the public. “NFL quarterbacks look at film to get better,” he said. “We do that with our officers with our professional development unit every day.” The protests of police brutality are in response to the death of Floyd, a black man who died after a white Minneapolis police officer pressed his knee on Floyd’s neck until he stopped breathing. Law enforcement officials around the country have condemned the officer’s use-of-force against Floyd. The officer, Derek Chauvin, was charged with murder, but many have called on Minneapolis officials to charge the other three officers on the scene who did not intervene. (Those officers have been fired from the Minneapolis police department, though they have not been charged criminally.) At a press conference on Monday, Newark Public Safety Director Anthony Ambrose denounced the actions of all four of the Minneapolis police officers and called Chauvin an “embarrassment to the badge." “That’s blatant murder,” Ambrose said. “Each and every day, all of us go out and do our job and our people do our job. There may be other cases that we have feelings (about), but this was a handcuffed black man with a knee on his neck. Usually, there’s no reason to use force when someone is handcuffed.” NJ Advance Media reporter Joe Atmonavage contributed to this report. Our journalism needs your support. Please subscribe today to NJ.com. Alex Napoliello may be reached at anapoliello@njadvancemedia.com.

title: More than 500 march down Bloomfield Avenue in Caldwell to protest George Floyd killing
themes: demonstrations and riots, murders and attempted murders

title: Keansburg march remembers George Floyd
themes: blacks, police, discrimination, demonstrations and riots
text: Keansburg march remembers George Floyd Hundreds of New Jerseyans marched in Keansburg June 2 to protest racism and instances of police brutality. Michael L. Diamond and Alex N. Gecan, Gannett

title: Video: Protest march in Caldwell over George Floyd killing
themes: quotation of the day, demonstrations and riots, murders and attempted murders
text: Video: Protest march in Caldwell over George Floyd killing More than 500 people turned out in Caldwell on June 2, 2020 for a solidarity march to end police brutality and protest the killing of George Floyd. NorthJersey.com

title: City leaders, clergy to March for Peace in Vineland, community welcomed
themes: politics and government, blacks, police, crime and criminals, demonstrations and riots, police brutality and misconduct
text: CLOSE VINELAND – The public is invited to join city and community leaders in a March for Peace, set to begin 11 a.m. Wednesday at City Hall. Mayor Anthony Fanucci, City Council members, and municipal first responders are planning to join local clergy and community organizations for the march along Landis Avenue to Delsea Drive. The police-involved death of George Floyd and protests erupting nationwide have “impacted people of all walks of life,” Fanucci said, noting it’s been the focus of discussions among his diverse network of family and friends. Floyd, a black man, was face down and handcuffed when a white Minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck for nearly nine minutes. “At this time of uncertainty and apprehension in our country, I believe it is important that we come together peacefully to pay our respects and stand against injustice in all forms,” the mayor said. More: In a peaceful demonstration, protesters in Vineland call for justice after death of George Floyd More: Mayor says looting was worst of Atlantic City, cleanup is its best The March for Peace is the result of a collaboration, Fanucci said. “It’s about the community coming together,” the mayor said, recounting how the Rev. James Dunkins reached out to him this week on behalf of area clergy. “It was something we were thinking about, it was something they were thinking about,” Fanucci said. The planned route is from City Hall to Seventh Street and then to Landis Avenue, headed west to the former Sears building at Delsea Drive, city officials said. Traffic will be detoured during the march. Speakers are expected to address the participants at City Hall as well as at the end of the march. All city employees are invited to attend. “For over 240 years, we have strived to achieve a more perfect union,” the mayor said. “While we have moved a long way towards this ideal, we still have work to do; we cannot solve our problems in an instant because they did not start in an instant.” “We must all recognize our shortcomings, as uncomfortable as that may be, and do the hard work necessary to overcome them,” he said. “No matter your race, religion, or sexual orientation, we are all Americans, entitled to the same rights and opportunities.” “Together we are stronger, and together we can effect meaningful change to make our community and our country a better place for all,” he said. This will be the second march in Center City this week. Vinelanders Tahira Davis and Mia Arbona organized a march demanding justice for Floyd that traveled down Landis Avenue on Monday and concluded with peaceful gathering in Landis Park. Deborah M. Marko is a senior reporter with The Daily Journal. Currently focused on breaking news and education issues, she also oversees community outreach programs that promote literacy and public safety. Got a story idea? Call 856-563-5256. Follow on Twitter: @dmarko_dj Instagram: deb.marko.dj Help support local journalism with a The Daily Journal subscription. title: George Floyd protests: Jon Bon Jovi pauses but doesn't hashtag for Blackout Tuesday
themes: blacks
text: CLOSE Groups of people from coast to coast protest police brutality after George Floyd died in Minneapolis police custody. USA TODAY Jon Bon Jovi has paused, but he didn't hashtag. That's a good thing, say critics of the music industry-wide movement called “The Show Must Be Paused,” hashtag #thshowmustbepaused, that’s meant to reflect on the events of the past week related to the death of George Floyd and the issue of institutional racism in the United States. It's also known as “Blackout Tuesday.” Bon Jovi, like other participants, posted a blank black screen on his social media platforms on Tuesday. He included #theshowmustbepaused in the lower center of the screen. A man screams with emotion as he sees a policeman take a knee while hundreds protest the death of George Floyd next to the White House on May 31, 2020 in Washington, DC. (Photo: ROBERTO SCHMIDT, AFP via Getty Images) But Bon Jovi did not include a hashtag #blacklivesmatter, or any other hashtags, in the description or comments and that's a good thing, according to critics who say that doing so ties up the lines of communication of the Black Lives Movement in a time of urgency among national protests. “We know that's it no intent to harm but to be frank, this essentially does harm the message,” said Black Lives Matter activist Kenidra Woods on Twitter on Tuesday. “We use hashtag to keep ppl updated. PLS stop using the hashtag for black images!!” George Clinton, Queen Latifah, the Bouncing Souls, Gaslight Anthem, Everett Bradley of Bon Jovi, Nicole Atkins, Jarod Clemons, and Patti Scialfa of the E Street Band were Jersey artists who posted blank screens, or message of support, without the hashtag #blacklivesmatter by Tuesday afternoon. They joined fellow Jerseyans Jay Sean of Demarest, Danny Clinch, Phish and more in the movement. Want to keep up with the latest in the Jersey music scene? Subscribe to APP.com and download our mobile app today so you don't miss thing. Brianna Agyemang and Jamila Thomas of Atlantic Records founded the movement as “an initiative created by two Black women in music in observance of the long-standing racism and inequity that exists from the boardroom to the boulevard,” according to the group's mission statement. “We will not continue to conduct business as usual without regard to Black lives.” Yet, many are wary of potential negative effects of the movement, intentional for not. “What I hate about it is that it completely takes the focus off of what you can do and places it on what we apparently shouldn't be doing,” said Graham Alexander, head of Victor Records near Camden. “The biggest negative of this is that at a crucial moment when protesters and Black Lives Matter organizers need the lines of communication that Instagram and Twitter and Facebook affords them, now you have a glut of hashtag #blacklivesmatter posts that are keeping protesters from connecting together.” More: Washington, DC, police chief says more than 300 arrested in protests over George Floyd More: George Floyd protests: Jersey musicians will, and won't, take a pause on Blackout Tuesday More: George Floyd: P-Funk legend George Clinton shows what unity looks like as nation teeters Instead of posting, Alexander says musicians should “get down to the protest.” “Change doesn't happen if you just talk about,” Alexander said. This is not a time to be silent, said Kurt Reil of Highland Park's Grip Weeds, who was upset over the actions of police and federal agencies who released tear gas and fired rubber bullets at protesters near the White House on Monday, June 1. “When a president orders the military to assault its people, a line has been crossed,” said Reil of the action. “Then, after crossing said line, he goes to church and holds up a Bible for a cynical photo-op, effectively using the church as a partisan political prop. I'm outraged and ashamed at how far we have fallen as a nation, and I won't be silent today.” Organizers have heard. They released a statement on Tuesday afternoon stating that the “purpose was never to mute ourselves.” Chris Jordan, a Jersey Shore native, covers entertainment and features for the USA Today Network New Jersey. His multiple awards include recognition for stories on both Bruce Springsteen and “Jersey Shore.” Contact him at @chrisfhjordan; cjordan@app.com. Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/06/02/george-floyd-protests-jon-bon-jovi-pauses-but-doesnt-hashtag-blackout-tuesday/3127520001/
