title: An Open Letter: Thank You Toms River For a Positive and Meaningful March Tuesday
themes: demonstrations and riots
text: Enter your number to get our free mobile app LET'S BE KIND TO EVERYONE Let me begin by saying "well done" to all involved in the Toms River Protest March on Tuesday. Thank you, Toms River for hosting a positive and meaningful march Tuesday. To the organizers, participants, and law enforcement, you made Ocean County & Toms River proud and we should see more events like the ones from Toms River on TV, showing a positive approach to a very worthwhile cause. Following the horrible death of George Floyd and the nights of unrest in other portions of the country, yesterday saw a day of speakers, prayer, and a look to the future to stop crimes like the George Floyd case from happening again. Hats off to the Toms River Police, Ocean County Prosecutor's Office, Ocean County Sheriffs Department and other Law Enforcement for not only keeping the peace, but for participating and being a part of the "solution". We must see community and law enforcement come together to stop future injustice and yesterday that was at the forefront in Toms River. Area businesses cooperated during the march. Some did decide to take precautions by boarding up their windows and frankly, you can't blame them. These local businesses have already been ravaged economically from COVID-19 and they did not need any senseless damage that could have possibly occurred. They were simply reacting to what they have seen every night on TV. These businesses are their life and their family's lives....so being cautious didn't interfere with the march and it gave them peace of mind, which is totally their right. I think if we saw more gatherings like the one in Toms River, fewer business people would be intimidated by these types of events. You may have been marching next to local business people, who took part as well. All in all, the community took time yesterday to remember and honor George Floyd and hopefully strengthened bonds between law enforcement and citizens. Let's celebrate yesterday's event and use it to move forward for change and equality and maybe today hug your neighbor (wait can we do that yet?) and spread peace to EVERYONE. Thanks to Vin Ebenau and 92.7 WOBM News for coverage of the event. That's my "open" thank you note. Let me know what YOU at home think. Post your comments below ~ Shawn Michaels

title: '¡Que se jo--! ¡Él es el problema!': Reportero del APP narra su arresto durante una protesta por George Floyd
text: ASBURY PARK — “¡Que se jo--! ¡Él es el problema!” Eso fue todo lo que escuché antes de que un oficial de policía de Asbury Park me tacleara y arrestara la noche del lunes mientras hacía mi trabajo cubriendo una protesta y ejerciendo mis derechos bajo la Primera Enmienda. Justo un momento antes había grabado con mi teléfono celular cómo varios agentes habían tacleado violentamente y luego arrestado a dos menores de edad que se retiraban ante el avance de los policías. Siguiendo las órdenes policiales, comencé a retirarme. El video — que estaba transmitiendo en vivo para la audiencia de APP.com en la plataforma Periscope de Twitter — se corta justo cuando me taclean, aunque quise seguir grabando. Otro agente participando en el arresto me asestó un golpe en la mano que me hizo tirar el teléfono. Al hacer esto dijo, “tira su jodi-- teléfono”. El oficial que me arrestó dijo, "no te resistas". Yo respondí, "No me estoy resistiendo. Soy reportero". Cory Booker: APP journalist arrest 'unacceptable' CLOSE APP reporter Gustavo Martinez's Periscope of the streets being cleared during the protest in Asbury Park shows him being arrested. Asbury Park Press Pronto me entregaron a otro oficial que preguntó qué hacer conmigo y le dijeron que me llevara a una camioneta en la que estaban cargando otros detenidos. Me preguntó qué era lo que colgaba de mi cuello y le dije que era mi gafete de prensa y que era reportero del Asbury Park Press. Me pidió que no le diera problemas y dijo que se portaría "bien" conmigo. Estuve tranquilo en todo momento. The trusted place to find the best home service providers. Find local pros. Me quitaron casco, gafas y mochila antes de subirme a la camioneta. Mi credencial de prensa aún colgaba de mi cuello cuando llegamos al cuartel central del Departamento de Policía de Belmar, que estaba ayudando a procesar a algunas de las personas arrestadas en la protesta. Me transportaron con otros cuatro prisioneros, incluidos los dos jóvenes que se ven en el video cuando fueron planchados contra el suelo y arrestados. Editorial: Reporters must not be charged or detained as they cover demonstrations Me conmocionó tanto la brutalidad que acababa de presenciar que realmente no pensé mucho sobre mi arresto, solo hasta más tarde. Me preocupaba más por lo que le había pasado a esos dos chicos. Estaba en la escena para cubrir las protestas provocadas por la muerte sin sentido de George Floyd a manos de la policía de Minneapolis, en un doloroso caso más de brutalidad policial. Mi deber era cubrir el final de una protesta que se había desarrollado pacíficamente en el transcurso de varias horas. Al caer la noche, comencé a transmitir escenas en vivo de lo que estaba sucediendo afuera de la sede de la policía de Asbury Park, incluido el momento en que los manifestantes pidieron a los policías que se arrodillaran con ellos. Si bien la mayoría de los agentes de policía lo hicieron, algunos permanecieron de pie, como lo muestra el video que grabé. Column: Arrest of APP reporter covering Asbury Park protest part of a troubling trend Alrededor de las 9:30 p.m., un oficial de policía usó el megáfono de su vehículo para decirle a la gente que se fuera a casa. También noté que casi al mismo tiempo, la policía con equipo antidisturbios comenzó a acercarse al área. Presintiendo una confrontación, me puse el casco y las gafas protectoras. Se emitió al menos una advertencia más, pero con todo el ruido apenas fue audible. Buy Photo Gustavo Martínez Contreras (Photo: (Photo: Tanya Breen)) Un oficial de policía de Asbury Park me dijo que ya había pasado el toque de queda fijado a las 8 p.m. y me preguntó por qué todavía estaba allí. Le dije que era un periodista del Asbury Park Press cumpliendo mi trabajo de comunicar las noticias. Él me dijo: “¿Con que quieres probar la acción? Tendrás una probada de la acción, entonces". El Asbury Park Press y otros medios de comunicación están normalmente exentos del toque de queda impuesto bajo una orden ejecutiva del gobernador. Antes de la protesta, el APP informó al jefe de policía de Asbury Park que estaríamos allí más allá del toque de queda y recibió garantías de que nuestros periodistas estarían exentos de la orden de regresar a casa. Otros policías me vieron grabando, miraron mi credencial y me preguntaron "¿con qué prensa estás?" Mi respuesta siempre fue la misma: estoy con el Asbury Park Press. George Floyd killing: Here's why bad cops remain on the force and what needs to be fixed Poco antes de las 10 p.m., la policía se agrupó con sus escudos y macanas, acorralando a los manifestantes entre ellos y los oficiales con los que los manifestantes habían tenido intercambios acalorados. Momentos antes, los oficiales se habían arrodillado con la multitud inconforme. Buy Photo Police take a knee outside Asbury Park, NJ, Police Headquarters as protestors fill the parking lot around 930pm Monday, June 1, 2020. A rally and march were held earlier to protest the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Photo: Thomas P. Costello) Al notar los escudos, los manifestantes levantaron sus manos y gritaron mientras avanzaban hacia los antidisturbios. Fue entonces que comencé a grabar de nuevo. Los manifestantes, otros medios y yo avanzamos lentamente hacia la policía antimotines y nos quedamos allí solo por unos momentos. Fue entonces cuando los oficiales que se habían arrodillado como señal de solidaridad un momento antes comenzaron a avanzar y empujar a la gente fuera de ahí. Fui empujado por un oficial de policía que inmediatamente se disculpó pero luego continuó empujando a la demás gente. Comencé a seguir a la multitud, deteniéndome para grabar intercambios y la carga de la policía. Traté de quedarme con otros periodistas que cubrían la protesta. George Floyd protest: Asbury Park rally was peaceful, but end of the night was not La acometida de la policía condujo a los manifestantes hacia el norte sobre Main Street. Los manifestantes, en su mayoría jóvenes negros y de otras minorías, giraron hacia el oeste en la avenida Monroe. La policía se paró en la intersección por unos momentos y luego continuó avanzando y exigiendo que la gente se fuera. Buy Photo People and police fill the parking lot outside the Asbury Park, NJ, Police Headquarters Monday night, June 1, 2020. The group earlier marched through the town in protest over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Photo: Thomas P. Costello) Algunos jóvenes gritaron y desafiaron a la policía mientras se encontraban en la intersección. Otros en la parte de atrás tomaron gravilla suelta que encontraron y comenzaron a arrojar rocas a la policía. Esto duró solo unos momentos. Cuando la multitud se retiró, vi a algunas personas volteando contenedores de basura, pero nadie estaba destruyendo o vandalizando propiedades. Los policías cargaron nuevamente y me retiré con el resto de los manifestantes mientras seguía grabando. A veces me encontraba marchando con la policía y otras veces caminando con manifestantes. Health: Will large George Floyd protests lead to a spike in NJ coronavirus cases? Escuché fuertes gritos y me giré para ver gente corriendo hacia las vías del ferrocarril en Memorial Drive. Me apresuré hacia el área bajo el sonido de las aspas de un helicóptero que volaba sobre nosotros. Cuando llegué a Memorial Drive, vi a la policía rociando gas pimienta y me dirigí en esa dirección para documentar eso. Después de que me dijeran que "me moviera al cara--", caminé por la calle junto a los agentes de policía. Me di vuelta cuando escuché a alguien gritar detrás de mí. Fue entonces cuando vi a los dos jóvenes siendo detenidos violentamente. Un momento después yo también estaría en el suelo esposado. La policía de Belmar fue respetuosa en todo momento. Nos dieron mantas térmicas y agua cuando les dijimos que teníamos frío y sed. Aproximadamente una hora después de mi detención allí, un oficial de policía vestido de civil vino a mi celda para hacerme algunas preguntas. Quería saber si estaba con Antifa, el movimiento antifascista que el presidente Donald Trump está culpando, sin evidencia, de agitar los disturbios. Me preguntó si sabía qué era Antifa y si me habían invitado a unirme a Antifa en algún momento durante la protesta. Le dije que sabía lo que era Antifa por mi trabajo como periodista. Me preguntó para quién trabajaba y le dijo que era reportero de Asbury Park Press. "¿Entonces solo estabas documentando lo que estaba sucediendo?" preguntó. Antes de irse, me dijo que Antifa es un grupo terrorista y que debería tener cuidado de no liarme con ellos. Alrededor de las 12:30 a.m., un oficial de policía de Asbury Park vino a hablar conmigo. Me preguntó si era reportero del Press y le dije que sí. Me preguntó si tenía mi credencial conmigo, a lo que dije que sí. Tomó mi información y dijo: "así que quedaste atrapado en medio de todo, ¿verdad?" "Estaba haciendo mi trabajo", dije. Se fue diciendo que no pasaría mucho tiempo antes de que me dejaran ir. Dijo que tenían que procesarnos y darnos una multa por conducta desordenada. Se me permitió usar el teléfono. Llamé a mi novia para hacerle saber que estaba bien y pedirle que llamara a mis editores para que supieran dónde estaba. Finalmente fui liberado alrededor de las 3:30 a.m. La policía me devolvió mis pertenencias y me entregó una citación por "deliberadamente" no obedecer una orden de dispersarse. Poco después, noté lo que había estado ocurriendo durante mi encierro. Decenas de mensajes llegaron una vez que mi teléfono recibió servicio nuevamente. Llamé a mi novia que ya tenía instrucciones de mis editores. Telefoneé al editor de proyectos especiales Shannon Mullen, quien vino a recogerme. Me llevó a mi auto estacionado en el centro de Asbury Park. Regresé a casa. No pude dormir sino hasta la mañana del martes. Horas más tarde, supe que el Fiscal General Gurbir Grewal se había disculpado por mi arresto y dijo que los cargos en mi contra serían retirados. Eso ocurrió aproximadamente una hora después. Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/news/2020/06/03/mi-arresto-mientras-cubria-una-protesta-por-george-floyd-como-reportero-en-asbury-park/3129241001/

title: Will large George Floyd protests lead to a spike in NJ coronavirus cases?
themes: education and schools, medicine and health, diseases and conditions, demonstrations and riots
text: The sight of hundreds and sometimes thousands of people crammed together on New Jersey streets to protest the killing of George Floyd has some infectious disease experts concerned there may be a surge in COVID-19 cases over the next month. The dozens of rallies, especially in the state's largest cities, have the potential to be "super spreader events" where young asymptomatic demonstrators could transmit the virus to dozens of other attendees. "This is absolutely the perfect storm for creating a cluster if not a second wave," said Mark Cameron, an infectious disease expert at Case Western Reserve University in Ohio. "We're not talking the fall. We're talking right now." The rallies come as Gov. Phil Murphy is touting how well New Jersey has reduced the risk of transmission through more than two months of strict social distancing and the shutdown of most businesses, schools and activities. But Murphy said this week that he has no intention of stopping the rallies on public health grounds — even though they defy his order to limit outdoor gatherings to no more than 25. "Given the gravity of the killing and the stain of racism in this country, we have to acknowledge there is a desire and there is a right to peacefully protest," Murphy said at his daily COVID-19 briefing Tuesday. "I would ask [demonstrators] to please wear masks and keep social distancing." NJ REOPENING: These are the NJ businesses and services that can reopen in the coming weeks 'We come in peace!': Hundreds flood Jersey City, where cops, protesters march together But while many demonstrators do cover their faces and protest organizers hand out masks, some participants remove their masks or don't wear any. And trying to maintain space has been difficult at some of the larger rallies, which began Saturday following the death of Floyd after a white Minneapolis police officer kept his knee on the African American man's neck for at least eight minutes. "It's certainly possible that they can become what we call super spreader events," said Stephanie Silvera, a professor of public health at Montclair State University. "What concerns me is that the rallies represent communities that have already been disproportionately hit by this virus," Silvera said. "The people most hurt by this pandemic will continue to be hurt." Of New Jerseyans who have died from COVID-19, almost 19% are black, while blacks make up 15% of the state's population. New COVID cases have dropped significantly over the past 45 days from 4,391 reported on April 15 to 708 on June 1. New Jersey has not seen a significant spike even though several rallies have been held to reopen New Jersey businesses. But those were minuscule compared to the George Floyd rallies that have attracted thousands in the state's biggest cities, including Newark, Jersey City and Camden, and have brought together groups in smaller communities, such as Englewood, Long Branch and Freehold. Most New Jersey rallies have been peaceful compared with places like Philadelphia and New York, where demonstrations have devolved into clashes with police and looting of stores. Murphy said there were at least 21 rallies scheduled statewide on Tuesday. Story continues after photo gallery The fact that the rallies are outdoors automatically helps curb transmission compared with something like an indoor business convention or church choir, where the virus was shown to spread like wildfire before the shutdowns. But protesters are also constantly yelling, chanting and cheering, which expels more droplets into the air and with greater force. "Even if it's outside, you run the risk of transmitting the virus if you can't maintain the proper distance and wear a mask," said Anna Yeung-Cheung, a virologist and infectious disease expert at Manhattanville College in New York. "You may see cases increase, but will we be going back to 700 dying a day like we saw at the height in New York? I don't think so." Reader — covering our local communities takes time and resources. Help us better support your community by becoming a subscriber today — see our special offers. On Tuesday, Murphy presented new data on the rate of "virus reproduction." It showed that on March 30, one infected New Jerseyan was likely to infect five other people. After Murphy's stay-at-home order was issued, that rate plummeted to 1.04 by April 14 — the peak of COVID-19 hospitalization. It now stands at less than a person, at 0.88, as of May 30. The chart shows that on March 30, one infected New Jerseyan was likely to infect five other people. After Murphy's stay-at-home order was issued, that rate plummeted to 1.04 by April 14 — the peak of COVID-19 hospitalization. It now stands at less than a person, at 0.88, as of May 30. Health officials want the rate below one. (Photo: New Jersey Department of Health) But contracting the virus is still very much a threat at outdoor activities so much so that Murphy and health officials have agonized over when and how to allow graduation ceremonies or limiting al-dresco dining. The time from exposure to COVID-19 to onset of symptoms is three to 14 days. But the real risk may not be to the protesters themselves, the vast majority of whom are young and are more likely to be asymptomatic or to develop minor symptoms. The risk is to older people with whom demonstrators come in contact. "It's when they go home to visit their parents when the real risk occurs," Cameron said. "Between the crowds you saw on Memorial Day weekend and now the rallies, you have a one-two punch that could really set this country back," Cameron said. "You have a lot of progress that can be wiped away." Scott Fallon covers the environment for NorthJersey.com. To get unlimited access to the latest news about how New Jersey’s environment affects your health and well-being, please subscribe or activate your digital account today. Email: fallon@northjersey.com Twitter: @newsfallon Read or Share this story: https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/coronavirus/2020/06/03/coronavirus-and-protests-nyc-nj-see-spike-george-floyd-protests/3125178001/

title: George Floyd: Asbury Park rally was peaceful, but end of the night was not
themes: politics and government, police, demonstrations and riots
text: ASBURY PARK - A day after a largely peaceful rally and march ended with rocks thrown, a dozen arrests and one officer in the hospital, tensions lingered in this city. About 5,000 attendees gathered around the Asbury Park Post Office building at 5 p.m. Monday to hear speakers address criminal justice reform issues. When the speeches ended, a majority of the crowd spontaneously left on their own and began to march onto Main Street, all the way into Neptune before looping back onto Springwood Avenue and up toward the boardwalk in Asbury Park. Duanne Small, a co-organizer of Monday's protest, urged the audience repeatedly to remain peaceful. "If you really want to help us, leave here peacefully," Small said. "Obey the law." Drone shots from the Asbury Park protest. (Photo: Anthony Abelardo) George Floyd killing: Here's why bad cops remain on the force and what needs to be fixed Organizers and city officials said a march was not one of the planned activities. But the march and rally largely dispersed by around 8 p.m., when the city-imposed curfew went into effect. The trusted place to find the best home service providers. Find local pros. A few hundred people gathered around Asbury Park police headquarters until 9:30 p.m., when police began enforcing the curfew and ordered the crowd to disperse. Then the scene changed. Officers carrying shields started to advance down Main Street, driving the remaining individuals away. "Our event was over. They were over there after curfew,” Small said, referring to the group gathered by the police station. “They were in no way associated with our event. They put a stain on what happened last night.” Derek Minno Bloom, an Asbury Park activist, said he stayed late by the police station to try to help de-escalate the situation. Minno Bloom said the closing events of the night dampened what had otherwise been a day of unity in the city. "Police were wildly professional," Minno Bloom said. "I was impressed at their de-escalation skills." He noted several officers took a knee in solidarity with protesters. "It was beautiful," he said. But he said once the cops began clearing the street of protesters, things changed. "When we were on Monroe (Avenue) right in front of The Saint, that’s when the rocks started being thrown. It’s like Asbury was militarized," Minno Bloom said. "I think that the armed and militarized police force was not necessarily needed," said Felicia Simmons, who helped organize the rally held earlier in the day. "I don’t think there should have been a curfew, but I understand the fear. I understand what was going on in the world, not just our town." Health: Will large George Floyd protests lead to a spike in NJ coronavirus cases? Buy Photo Rally organizer Felicia Simmons screams to the crowd to be heard at rally in Asbury Park protesting the police-involved death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Many marched peacefully in the streets after the rally was over. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) Small said he was pleased with the way the rally itself went forward cooperating with law enforcement. “They’re willing to work with the community. We look forward to working with them.” Sgt. Michael Casey, a spokesman for Asbury Park Police, said Monday night a dozen arrests were made. An Asbury Park officer was injured and brought to Jersey Shore University Medical Center. Among the people arrested was Asbury Park Press reporter Gustavo Martinez Contreras. Police charged him with failure to disperse as he was covering the events Monday night. Members of the media were exempt from the curfew orders imposed by the city. The charges were ordered dropped on Tuesday at the direction of Monmouth County Prosecutor Christopher Gramiccioni, and New Jersey Attorney General Gurbir Grewal offered a formal apology. He said the incident was being investigated. Sen. Cory Booker: APP journalist arrest 'unacceptable' Buy Photo Rally in Asbury Park protesting the police-involved death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Many marched peacefully in the streets after the rally was over. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) Asbury Park has long been considered to be an activist city. Protests, demonstrations, marches and rallies are held year-round in the city for a variety of causes and issues across the political spectrum. "I feel like Asbury Park, we’re professionals at these sort of events at coming together and organizing and protesting. It was powerful, a lot of people together," said Dani Boglivi-Fiori, owner of Sweet Dani B cookie shop. Prior protests: Crowds descend on Asbury Park to 'Stand United Against Hate' She said she was disappointed that some people didn't abide by the curfew. "They warned everybody about this," Boglivi-Fiori said. "It's so frustrating that people just like pushed back." Buy Photo Jamar Lewis holds 5 month old Amerius Lewis of Neptune during rally in Asbury Park protesting the police-involved death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Many marched peacefully in the streets after the rally was over. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) 'F--- him! He's the problem!': APP reporter tells about his arrest at George Floyd protest Rumors have circulated on social media on a possible protest to be held Friday in the city, but officials said they were unaware of any formal plans. "There’s no permits, there’s no special events, there's no nothing. They’ve had absolutely zero contact with the city," Deputy Mayor Amy Quinn said. Asbury Park Mayor John Moor and the entire City Council were in attendance at Monday's rally, though none of them spoke. "It was a nice event until the end," Moor said, referring to the rock-throwing and arrests. It's not clear how many — if any — of the people arrested in the end had attended the prior rally and march. Buy Photo Rally in Asbury Park protesting the police-involved death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Many marched peacefully in the streets after the rally was over. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) "We are disappointed in the actions of a few that tried to take our community’s peaceful protest in a different direction," Moor and the City Council said in a joint statement Tuesday. "We want to thank rally organizers and community leaders for holding a well-organized event and promoting a peaceful protest." The statement continued, "We’d also like to thank the Asbury Park Police Department, the Asbury Park Fire Department and all assisting agencies for the professionalism they exhibited yesterday." 'Misunderstanding': Rebel Supply Co. in Asbury Park can keep anti-KKK sign Moor declined to comment on the arrest of Martinez-Contreras. "I don’t know the particulars about it. I’d be wrong to comment," Moor said. Monday’s protest fell on the first day of June, historically designated as LGBTQ Pride Month. The modern gay rights movement was itself born in a moment of resistance on June 28, 1969, when a riot broke out at the Stonewall Inn in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village; police had raided the bar, enforcing a law against selling alcohol to homosexual patrons, and the community – including Edison native transgender rights activist Marsha P. Johnson – fought back. One year later, in June 1970, the Christopher Street Liberation Day Committee held the first Gay Pride March. The annual New Jersey LGBTQ Pride Parade, Rally and Festival had been scheduled to happen in Asbury Park on Sunday, but the coronavirus pandemic forced organizers Jersey Pride Inc. to postpone the event to National Coming Out Day on Oct. 11. Pride Month: How LGBTQ community, allies will be celebrating differently due to COVID-19 “Our movement was born out of fire, bricks and blood at the Stonewall riots, and trans and queer women of color led that charge,” said Christian Fuscarino, executive director of education and advocacy organization Garden State Equality. “So it felt appropriate to stand with our black brothers, sisters and siblings against these injustices yesterday. Anything less than solidarity during this time only undermines the spirit and value of what Pride truly means.” Fuscarino was in attendance at Monday’s gathering in Asbury Park, just blocks from Garden State Equality’s Main Street headquarters. Speaking with the Asbury Park Press Tuesday morning, he said he was aware of growing tension and police presence as the evening progressed. “Ultimately, everything was peaceful from our perspective until a curfew needed to be enforced,” Fuscarino said. “When it comes to curfew, officers will say that they’re just following orders. But when will the good guys, quote-unquote, draw a line and say ‘Enough is enough’? The president is encouraging law enforcement to turn fire on citizens. Will they follow orders, quote-unquote, then?” Austin Bogues spotlights the changing development scene in Asbury Park and Neptune. He can be reached at abogues@app.com. Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/news/local/communitychange/2020/06/03/george-floyd-asbury-park-rally-peaceful-end-night-not/3123071001/

title: George Floyd killing: Here's why bad cops remain on the force and what needs to be fixed
themes: politics and government, police
text: CLOSE Miguel Feliz struggled to extinguish his burning flesh after a car crash in Jersey City June 4, 2017. He needed help from the police. Instead he was kicked. Two years ago, the Asbury Park Press published a ground-breaking investigative series on police brutality called "The Shield." We exposed how government officials at all levels, even the courts, protected bad cops until they maimed or killed innocent people. The Press called for police reforms then and in subsequent stories. Some important changes were put in place, but in light of recent national and local events, much more still needs to be done. That is why we are bringing these stories back for you to read. Many recount uncomfortable, even horrific events, but each detail is necessary to understand what is happening in today's society. Police badge (Photo: heliopix, Getty Images/iStockphoto) As we saw with the George Floyd killing, a bad cop can turn into a killer within a matter of minutes. The Minneapolis officer charged with Floyd's third-degree murder, Derek Chauvin, had seven abuse complaints lodged against him since 2012 and three police-involved shootings, USA TODAY reported. He even held a teenager at gunpoint over a harmless Nerf toy gun. Looking for the trusted place to find the best home service providers? Find local pros. After each incident, Chauvin was investigated but remained on the force. That is, until he killed George Floyd as bystanders videotaped the horror. Then Chauvin and three assisting officers were fired. National protests and riots have gone on for a week. Four bad cops. A dead citizen. A nation torn apart. Buy Photo Protesters gather in Asbury Park to demand justice for George Floyd. (Photo: Peter Ackerman) All of these may have been prevented if police reform actually involved true reform. "The Shield" investigation found that a downward trajectory like Chauvin's is an all too familiar outcome in New Jersey and across the nation. Police chiefs, prosecutors, judges and even juries generally give police officers wide latitude in the use of force. Bad cops, we found, learn just one lesson — they feel emboldened to keep on hurting until someone is maimed or killed. Keith Briscoe died during a struggle with Winslow Police outside a Wawa convenience store on May 3, 2010. (Photo: DENISE HENHOEFFER/Courier-Post, Photo provided by the Briscoe fa) Police reform has come a long way since the racial unrest of the 1960s. But we still have a long way to go. The stories from "The Shield" go into great detail about what happened and what needs to be done. One story, called "Pile on the rabbit," mirrors the Floyd killing. The only element missing was a bystander's video clip of cops piling on the man until he stopped breathing. His supposed offense? Hanging out in front of a convenience store too long to an officer's liking. Police reform starts with knowledge. Please read these stories to inform yourself of the facts, understand the patterns of abuses and press your lawmakers for change. Protests in the streets today mean little if they do not lead to reforms of the law, and at the ballot box, tomorrow. Selected stories from 'The Shield' 1) Secret settlements keep bad cops on the street 2) "Pile on the rabbit" — inside a death by cop 3) Killer cop had decade of complaints before he shot his wife 4) What killed man during police restraint? 4) Money and silence push bad cops along 5) How bad cops are built 6) Atlantic City cop with host of complaints indicted 7) How police brutality can be stopped 8) Some reforms have come, but more needs to be done 9) Read the full "Protecting the Shield" series with updates 10) Innocent victims are most likely to die during police chases Know of a incident involving an abuse of police powers? We want to hear from you. Contact reporter Andrew Ford at aford3@gannettnj.com or @AndrewFordNews Read or Share this story: https://www.app.com/story/news/investigations/2020/06/03/george-floyd-killing-bad-cops-investigation-the-shield/3123435001/

title: 'F--- him! He's the problem!': APP reporter tells about his arrest at George Floyd protest
themes: recordings (audio), television, police, telephones and telecommunications, cellular telephones
text: ASBURY PARK - “F--- him! He's the problem!” That’s all I heard before an Asbury Park police officer tackled and arrested me Monday night while I was doing my job covering a protest and exercising my First Amendment rights. Just a moment before, I had recorded on my cellphone how several police officers tackled and arrested two minors who were retreating from advancing officers. Following police orders, I began retreating when police arrested me. The video — I was broadcasting live for APP.com viewers on Twitter's Periscope platform — cuts off right when they’re tackling me, although I tried to keep on recording. Another police officer assisting in the arrest slapped my phone out of my hand saying, “take down his f---ing phone.” The officer arresting me said, “don’t resist.” I replied, “I’m not resisting. I am a reporter.” Sen. Cory Booker: APP journalist arrest 'unacceptable' CLOSE APP reporter Gustavo Martinez's Periscope of the streets being cleared during the protest in Asbury Park shows him being arrested. Asbury Park Press I was quickly handed over to another officer who asked what to do with me and was told to take me to a van into which other prisoners were being loaded. He asked what was hanging from my neck and I told him it was my press badge and that I was a reporter with the Asbury Park Press. He asked me to not give him any trouble and said he would be "cool" with me. I was calm throughout. The trusted place to find the best home service providers. Find local pros. They took my backpack, goggles and safety helmet before loading me onto the van. My badge was still dangling from my neck when we arrived at the Belmar Police Department headquarters, which was helping to process some of the people arrested at the protest. I had been transported with four other prisoners, including the two youths seen in my video beingtackled to the ground and arrested. Editorial: Reporters must not be charged or detained as they cover demonstrations I was so shocked by the brutality I had just witnessed that I really didn’t make much of my arrest, until later. I was more concerned with what had happened to those kids. I was on the scene to cover the protests sparked by the senseless death of George Floyd, at the hands of Minneapolis police, in yet another painful case of police brutality. My duty was to cover the end of a protest that had gone peacefully over the course of several hours. As night fell, I began live-streaming scenes from what was happening outside the Asbury Park police headquarters, including the moment in which protesters asked police officers to take a knee with them. While most police officers did, some remained standing, as the video I recorded shows. At around 9:30 p.m., a police officer used his vehicle’s bullhorn to tell people to go home. I also noticed that about the same time, police in riot gear began nearing the area. Sensing a confrontation, I put on my helmet and protective glasses. At least one more warning was issued, but with all the noise it was barely audible. Buy Photo Gustavo Martínez Contreras (Photo: (Photo: Tanya Breen)) Column: Arrest of APP reporter covering Asbury Park protest part of a troubling trend An Asbury Park police officer told me it was way past the 8 p.m. curfew and asked me why I was still there. I told him I was a reporter with the Asbury Park Press doing my job of reporting the news. He said to me, “So you want a taste of the action? You’ll get a taste of the action, then.” The Press and other media outlets are normally exempt from curfews under a governor's executive order. Prior to the protest, the Press informed the Asbury police chief that we would be there past curfew and received assurances that our journalists would be exempt from the go-home order. Other police officers saw me recording, looked at my badge, asked me, “What press are you with?” My answer was always the same: I am with the Asbury Park Press. Shortly before 10 p.m., police lined up with their shields and night sticks, sandwiching the demonstrators between them and the officers with whom the protesters had been having heated exchanges. Moments earlier, the officers had taken a knee with the protesters. Buy Photo Police take a knee outside Asbury Park, NJ, Police Headquarters as protestors fill the parking lot around 930pm Monday, June 1, 2020. A rally and march were held earlier to protest the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Photo: Thomas P. Costello) George Floyd protest: Asbury Park rally was peaceful, but end of the night was not Upon noticing the shields, the protesters walked toward the police in riot gear, raising their hands and screaming. That’s when I began recording again. The protesters, other media and I slowly moved toward the police in riot gear and stood there only for a few moments. It was then that the officers who had taken a knee as a sign of solidarity began to surge forward and push people out of the area. I was shoved by a police officer who immediately apologized but then continued pushing people out of the way. I began following the crowd, stopping to record exchanges and the charge of the police. I tried to stay with other journalists covering the protest. Buy Photo People and police fill the parking lot outside the Asbury Park, NJ, Police Headquarters Monday night, June 1, 2020. The group earlier marched through the town in protest over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. (Photo: Thomas P. Costello) The police surge drove the protesters north on Main Street. The demonstrators, mostly black and brown youth, turned west on Monroe Avenue. Police stood at the intersection for a few moments and then continued charging forward and demanding people leave. Some young men screamed and challenged the police in the intersection. Others in the back began throwing loose gravel and rocks at the police. This lasted only a few moments. As the crowd retreated, I saw some people flipping trash containers, but no one was destroying or defacing property. The cops charged and I retreated with the protesters as I kept recording. Sometimes I found myself marching with the police and other times walking along with protesters. George Floyd killing: Here's why bad cops remain on the force and what needs to be fixed I heard loud screaming and turned to see people running towards the railroad tracks on Memorial Drive. I rushed to the area under the sound of the whirring blades of a helicopter flying above us. When we reached Memorial Drive, I saw police pepper-spraying people and I headed in that direction to document that. After being told to “f---ing move,” I walked down the street alongside police officers. I turned when I heard someone screaming behind me. That’s when I saw the two youth being violently detained. A moment later I would be on the ground getting handcuffed, too. We arrived at the Belmar police headquarters at around 10:30 p.m. Slowly they began processing the seven prisoners they had received, but they couldn’t do much because we hadn’t been charged with anything yet. I was locked in cell M4. Belmar police were respectful throughout. They gave us thermal blankets and water when we told them we were cold and thirsty. About an hour into my detention there, a plainclothes police officer came to my cell to ask me some questions. He wanted to know if I was with Antifa, the anti-fascist movement President Donald Trump is blaming, without evidence, for stirring up the riots. He asked if I knew what Antifa was and if I had been invited to join Antifa at some point during the protest. I told him I knew what Antifa was because of my job as a journalist. Health: Will large George Floyd protests lead to a spike in NJ coronavirus cases? He asked me who I worked for and told him I was a reporter with the Asbury Park Press. “So you were just documenting what was happening?” he asked. Before he left, he told me that Antifa is a terrorist group and that I should be careful not to hang out with them. At around 12:30 a.m. an Asbury Park police officer came to talk to me. He asked me if I was a reporter for the Press and I said yes. He asked me if I had my badge with me, to which I said yes. He took down my information and said, “So you just were caught in the middle of everything, right?” “I was doing my job,” I said. He left saying that it wouldn’t be long before I was let go. He said that they had to process us and give us a ticket for disorderly conduct. I was allowed to use the phone. I called my girlfriend to let her know that I was fine and to ask her to please call my editors to let them know where I was. I was finally released at around 3:30 a.m. Police returned my belongings and handed me a summons for "knowingly and purposely" failing to obey an order to disperse. Soon after, I noticed what had been transpiring while I was locked up. Dozens of messages came through once my phone received service again. I called my girlfriend who already had instructions from my editors. I called enterprise editor Shannon Mullen, who came to pick me up. He drove me to my car parked in downtown Asbury Park. I drove back home. I couldn’t fall asleep until early Tuesday morning. Hours later, I learned that Attorney General Gurbir Grewal had apologized for my arrest and said the charges against me would be dropped. They were, about an hour later. Gustavo Martínez Contreras covers Lakewood. Contact him at gmartinez@gannettnj.com or at 732-643-4061. title: New Jersey to require licensing of police, update use-of-force policy
themes: blacks, police, discrimination, demonstrations and riots, murders and attempted murders, police brutality and misconduct
media_name: Star News Group | The Online Home of The Coast Star & The Ocean Star
text: echo do_shortcode('[corner-ad id=1]'); ? TRENTON — State Attorney General Gurbir S. Grewal on Tuesday announced the launching of a five-point plan, expected to include the licensing of all police officers in New Jersey, to strengthen trust between the law enforcement officers and the communities they serve. The announcement comes in the wake of widespread protests against police brutality and racial injustice that have occurred across the nation since the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis on May 25. A white police officer — Derek Chauvin, who pressed a knee on Mr. Floyd’s neck for more than eight minutes while he was handcuffed during an arrest — has been charged with third-degree murder in the death of Mr. Floyd, a black man. “Like so many Americans in this difficult time, I’m still reeling from the footage of George Floyd’s murder” Attorney General Grewal said during Gov. Phil Murphy’s daily news briefing. He said he is angry “that a white officer suffocated a black resident in broad daylight” while “three white officers watched and did nothing. I’m angry that these officers disgraced their entire profession and undermined the good work that so many others perform on a daily basis. ADVERTISEMENT “Mr. Floyd’s death reminds us that our country has a long way to go, not only in healing our nation’s racial divides, but also in addressing the systemic and implicit biases that affect all Americans,” he said. Demonstrations occurred across the nation and New Jersey including in Newark, Camden, Trenton, Atlantic City. In Asbury Park, a dozen people were arrested Monday night for failing to disperse after hours of peaceful protest, with several held and processed at the Belmar police station under a shared services agreement between the two municipalities. Attorney General Grewal quickly dismissed the charge against one of those arrested, an Asbury Park Press reporter, saying “In America, we don’t lock up reporters for doing their job.” Attorney General Grewal said the initiatives described Tuesday were in the works long before this week’s protests. He said he endorses a plan to mandate professional licencing of all 36,000 law enforcement officers in New Jersey, a requirement already in place in 43 states in the nation. “We must ensure that police officers meet a baseline level of professionalism, just like doctors, nurses and lawyers,” he said. He is working with police unions and law enforcement leaders to develop the training and certification program, which will be considered by the Police Training Commission in June for possible implementation. Attorney General Grewal said one of the most effective ways to reduce police use-of-force and death-in-custody incidents is by expanding the use of crisis-Intervention teams [CITs], which help officers respond to situations involving individuals with mental health issues. His office plans to build a statewide CIT-training program and will launch a pilot program with police departments in Atlantic City, Paterson, Trenton, and Millville, as well as State Police troopers assigned in Trenton. The Attorney General’s Office also will revise and update the use-of-force policy in New Jersey, something that hasn’t been done in 20 years, he said. He will issue a directive to implement the new policy for all law enforcement officers in the state by the end of the year. Development of the new policy will draw on data collected through a pilot use-of-force information portal that was recently completed and will be expanded for statewide use in July. The Attorney General’s Office also intends to develop an incident response team within the Division of Civil Rights that can be deployed to towns “following a major civil rights incident to help diffuse tension and heal the community.” The attorney general said in recent years his office has undertaken policing reforms designed to increase police professionalism, accountability and transparency. These include requiring statewide implicit-bias training and de-escalation training of police officers. Subscribe today! If you're not already an annual subscriber to The Coast Star, get your subscription today! For just $34 per year, you will receive local mail delivery weekly, with pages and pages of local news and online access to our e-edition on Starnewsgroup.com.

title: Will large George Floyd protests lead to a spike in NJ coronavirus cases?
themes: education and schools, medicine and health, diseases and conditions, demonstrations and riots
text: The sight of hundreds and sometimes thousands of people crammed together on New Jersey streets to protest the killing of George Floyd has some infectious disease experts concerned there may be a surge in COVID-19 cases over the next month. The dozens of rallies, especially in the state's largest cities, have the potential to be "super spreader events" where young asymptomatic demonstrators could transmit the virus to dozens of other attendees. "This is absolutely the perfect storm for creating a cluster if not a second wave," said Mark Cameron, an infectious disease expert at Case Western Reserve University in Ohio. "We're not talking the fall. We're talking right now." The rallies come as Gov. Phil Murphy is touting how well New Jersey has reduced the risk of transmission through more than two months of strict social distancing and the shutdown of most businesses, schools and activities. But Murphy said this week that he has no intention of stopping the rallies on public health grounds — even though they defy his order to limit outdoor gatherings to no more than 25. "Given the gravity of the killing and the stain of racism in this country, we have to acknowledge there is a desire and there is a right to peacefully protest," Murphy said at his daily COVID-19 briefing Tuesday. "I would ask [demonstrators] to please wear masks and keep social distancing." NJ REOPENING: These are the NJ businesses and services that can reopen in the coming weeks 'We come in peace!': Hundreds flood Jersey City, where cops, protesters march together But while many demonstrators do cover their faces and protest organizers hand out masks, some participants remove their masks or don't wear any. And trying to maintain space has been difficult at some of the larger rallies, which began Saturday following the death of Floyd after a white Minneapolis police officer kept his knee on the African American man's neck for at least eight minutes. "It's certainly possible that they can become what we call super spreader events," said Stephanie Silvera, a professor of public health at Montclair State University. "What concerns me is that the rallies represent communities that have already been disproportionately hit by this virus," Silvera said. "The people most hurt by this pandemic will continue to be hurt." Of New Jerseyans who have died from COVID-19, almost 19% are black, while blacks make up 15% of the state's population. New COVID cases have dropped significantly over the past 45 days from 4,391 reported on April 15 to 708 on June 1. New Jersey has not seen a significant spike even though several rallies have been held to reopen New Jersey businesses. But those were minuscule compared to the George Floyd rallies that have attracted thousands in the state's biggest cities, including Newark, Jersey City and Camden, and have brought together groups in smaller communities, such as Englewood, Long Branch and Freehold. Most New Jersey rallies have been peaceful compared with places like Philadelphia and New York, where demonstrations have devolved into clashes with police and looting of stores. Murphy said there were at least 21 rallies scheduled statewide on Tuesday. Story continues after photo gallery The fact that the rallies are outdoors automatically helps curb transmission compared with something like an indoor business convention or church choir, where the virus was shown to spread like wildfire before the shutdowns. But protesters are also constantly yelling, chanting and cheering, which expels more droplets into the air and with greater force. "Even if it's outside, you run the risk of transmitting the virus if you can't maintain the proper distance and wear a mask," said Anna Yeung-Cheung, a virologist and infectious disease expert at Manhattanville College in New York. "You may see cases increase, but will we be going back to 700 dying a day like we saw at the height in New York? I don't think so." Reader — covering our local communities takes time and resources. Help us better support your community by becoming a subscriber today — see our special offers. On Tuesday, Murphy presented new data on the rate of "virus reproduction." It showed that on March 30, one infected New Jerseyan was likely to infect five other people. After Murphy's stay-at-home order was issued, that rate plummeted to 1.04 by April 14 — the peak of COVID-19 hospitalization. It now stands at less than a person, at 0.88, as of May 30. The chart shows that on March 30, one infected New Jerseyan was likely to infect five other people. After Murphy's stay-at-home order was issued, that rate plummeted to 1.04 by April 14 — the peak of COVID-19 hospitalization. It now stands at less than a person, at 0.88, as of May 30. Health officials want the rate below one. (Photo: New Jersey Department of Health) But contracting the virus is still very much a threat at outdoor activities so much so that Murphy and health officials have agonized over when and how to allow graduation ceremonies or limiting al-dresco dining. The time from exposure to COVID-19 to onset of symptoms is three to 14 days. But the real risk may not be to the protesters themselves, the vast majority of whom are young and are more likely to be asymptomatic or to develop minor symptoms. The risk is to older people with whom demonstrators come in contact. "It's when they go home to visit their parents when the real risk occurs," Cameron said. "Between the crowds you saw on Memorial Day weekend and now the rallies, you have a one-two punch that could really set this country back," Cameron said. "You have a lot of progress that can be wiped away." Scott Fallon covers the environment for NorthJersey.com. To get unlimited access to the latest news about how New Jersey’s environment affects your health and well-being, please subscribe or activate your digital account today.
